story:
ABOUT THE SCHOOL

Located in Altadena CA and serving the community since 1990, 25-Student member performing arts school, Classical Ballet Academy focuses exclusively on ballet and its many facets. Under the artistic leadership of Crystal Peterson, the Academy provides all students, regardless of age or reason for study, clear and sound information that lead to a solid, pure foundation in dance. Whether preparing for a professional career or just dancing for the joy of it, CBA is a positive working environment that empowers students with confidence, creativity and individuality, while fostering appreciation and respect for the art of ballet and fellow dancers.

CBA built a custom in studio mini theater to accommodate our intimate academy to keep the tradition of performing with little cost to our students and their families. This year we took a gamble when reflecting that our school has not performed in another theater since 1999, and therefore, made the decision to rent a full-scale theater for this years performance.

Creating memories and gaining experiences from going to the theater and performing on stage with the audience and lights projected on you is what every performing artists aspires to. Many hours and expenses are donated from the school and staff in order to keep up with the motto “the show must go on”.  Our current academy students have been training at the school for over 10 years and it’s truly an exciting time to be able to provide these essential opportunities to our youth for their development.

“We are thrilled to be able to showcase our talented group of dancers,” Ms.(Crystal) Peterson said. “I’m proud to be able to contribute to the Foothill region’s vibrant dance community.”

CBA’s Artistic Staff and Director donate a minimum of 6 months preparing, organizing and executing for the production of this year’s show. Your contribution will go to the cost of our 2014 Spring Concert production and give our community and staff a lift in spirits with your support to help put these shows on for current and future.

CBA’s 2014 SPRING CONCERT’S TOTAL BUDGET IS $10,600

GOALS WITH FUNDING: Our campaign goal is to raise $6,800 to cover the initial costs of our production expenses. Funds will go towards:

  • 15 Brand new, Custom and Professional Quality Costumes (8-Romantic Tutus ,5-Classical Tutus & Tiaras, 2-Men’s Tunics)
  • Theater Rental
  • Floor Rental
  • Backdrop and Props.

Reaching our $6,800 goal will assist to cover the initial costs of this year’s concert.  This will be a great accomplishment in funding by giving relief to the entire cost of CBA’s 2014 Spring Concert's budget of $10,600, with the help of donated hours by Artistic Staff. Extra funds raised will go towards the many costs associated with our 2014 Spring Concert production:

  • Music Editing
  • Stage Manager
  • Lighting Manager
  • Stage Hands
  • Administrative Staff
  • Insurance
  • Public Relations
  • Advertising
  • Photography
  • Videography
  • Graphic Design
  • Promotional Materials.

Our school is greatly appreciative for any amount donated towards the production of CBA’s 2014 Spring Concert and spreading the word about our campaign.  Reaching our goal will enable us to not only see, but also feel the support given towards making these performances a professional and magical experience for our youth and community.

ABOUT THE SHOW

The concert takes place Saturday, June 7, 2014 at 7:30 p.m. at the Lanterman Auditorium in La Canada.

The robust repertoire represents a culmination of the Academy’s year-long syllabus, including excerpts and variations from classical works of Sleeping Beauty and Don Quixote, as well as debuting an original Pas De Deux, danced by the Academy’s Intermediate and Advanced students.

Please help us share for success with the Indiegogo share tools. 

Thank you for visiting our page and we wish you well!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Matt Growden and I have two decades of professional experience performing magic for real people.  With a degree in chemistry, most of my presentational "hooks" revolve around science... or science fiction.  After all, it was Arthur C Clark who said "any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic". 

My passion is not only to entertain, but to inspire. 

What We Need & What You Get

Need more local audiences!  

Thanks to out of town corporate sponsors, this project exceeded it's monetary goal.  But I do not consider Pop Up Magic a success because engagement of the local Huntsville community has been low.  It's no fun planning, writing and rehearsing a show that no one sees. 

So here's the next chapter for this project:

One show will launch for every additional $50 raised OR each 5 new contributors.  That's right, you and four friends can go the ultra-budget route and experience your very own show for $5.  (But you might want to up your game a little and claim a perk).  

Heck, if you message me, e-mail or call asking for a FREE "Time Travel" show and can guarantee that at least five people will show up, I will probably do it. 

At this point, the community engagement is more important than the money (although again, I must point out that there are some pretty sweet perks).

"Time Travel" is an exclusive 15 minute close-up magic show to be performed in the downtown Huntsville Square.  Dates, and times will be announced on my website and the Matt Growden Magic Facebook page.

Another show "Mind Games" is in the works.  So when Time Travel runs it's course, we will just keep this crowdfunded party rolling ...

The Impact

Obviously, this project has a lot to do with self promotion within the local community.  But my intent is also to just raise general awareness and respect for magic as a performing art. It is also an experiment in public entertainment.  Instead of busking, think of Pop Up Magic as "prepaid" street performance. 

My hope is that this project will also inspire continued corporate and/or city sponsorship of variety performing arts in public spaces. 

Risks & Challenges

Hmm... really none.  Either I connect with a  group of magic aficionados in Huntsville, or not.... I know you all are out there, because I have already met some of you.  We might have to reschedule shows due to bad weather (which is a real possibility here in Alabama).   But apart from those concerns, the show has already been rehearsed and the script written.  I just need an audience.... 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. If you cannot monetarily contribute at this time, that's OK!  Please tell your rich friends, family and co-workers about my campaign... and maybe they will let you tag along for a show.  Share this indiegogo link on your social media!  Check out my website and Facebook page for public performances at area restaurants and taprooms.  The Pop Up Magic shows will not be repeated, but at least for the price of a beer you can see some of my "regular" magic :)

story:
About us: Siciliano Contemporary Ballet was born in Berlin in January 2014, after showing several works in Italy, Greece, Spain, Germany and Czech Republic, Salvatore Siciliano founded the company that had its debut with Orikbem, show that had a strong impact in Berlin's dance scene and that also gave the group the opportunity to grow and make more dance pieces that also were well welcomed.

Siciliano Contemporary Ballet keeps on evolving itself and it's characterised by a careful aesthetic research, it works with external artists of several kinds and it's formed by 11 dancers and some guest performers. The music for the shows are composed by Matresanch with whom Siciliano has a strong artistic bond.


Concept: The creation of this project is born from the will of communicating with the world in the most personal way we can and make sure that the show is 'therapeutic' for the audience.

The idea arises from the will of throwing a light on a mental process that occurs sooner or later in everyone's life and that's connected with the concept of loss. What arises in our mind when we lose something (or someone) really important? What mechanisms lead us to go through this loss? It's almost a disconnection from what's around you, like a step into the void.

The project is an open interaction between dance and music. What we want to analyze is the role that loss has in the process of growing up and experience of the human being. A person is deprived of his past, somebody physically steals it from him. This person knows his origins and his identity but after this theft and being conscious of it he must acquire a new one. From this moment on he starts a quest from an external viewpoint, bird's eye view. He sees all of his possible pasts and futures connected with his loss and imagines what it could be and what it will be. The goal is to accept and process this event, the grief and its consequences. This is what happens during the stages of grief. Once he has accepted the grief, this person has the right awareness to picture three possible futures and three possible endings. The idea is that the show ends with three different endings.

The company in November will be in artistic residence in the Choreographic Center of Heidelberg (Germany) to work in this new project. The centre will give us an economical support, but it is not enough to pay everything.

The crowfunding will be needed to pay the work of everybody that will take part to the making of the show (choreographer, composer, dancers, costume designer, photographer and film-maker, public relations). A part will be used for advertisement, theater costs, scenes and costumes.


Team:

Choreographer Salvatore Siciliano

Music Matresanch

Performance Giulia Del Balzi, Maria Carmela Giannoccari, Giulia Mandelli, Valentina Migliorati, Assi Pakkanen, Michela Rossi, Laura Signoriello, Marie Zechiel, Matresanch

Costumes Sara Migliorati

PR Alice Guglielmelli

story:
THIS JUST IN!!! We now have a videographer and makeup/hair artist lined up for the production and the costumes are well under way. Please continue to share! Only a few hours left! :-)

***Be sure to check out the Updates page for more developments and pictures!!!

Hello there!

My name is Hanna Rose, and I want to thank you for visiting our Indiegogo campaign! I am writing on behalf of a group of San Francisco based artists who are in the process of producing a new one act multidisciplinary performance. The title of the show is That Thing at That Place with That Person and it is a part of the Resident Artist Workshop (RAW) series at The Garage in San Francisco which will be performed on April 9&10, 2014 at 8:00PM. As the choreographer, I am the artist in residence. However, it is my dream to bring artists of various disciplines together in order to create a unique performance experience for the audience.

 I cannot emphasize enough what a collaborative process this has been and continues to be. I am honored to be working closely with six very talented dancers in order to generate unique, organic material, that I can then mold and shape in order to tell a story (Please check out their bios below!). I am also collaborating with local designer, Chad Leal, to create beautiful one of a kind costumes. Lastly, I have employed the help of two of my fabulous siblings. My sister, Hailey, is quite the poet, having some of her work already published at the age of 18. We will be using some of her work (spoken and possibly projected) throughout the piece. My brother, Joel, on the other hand, is the musician of the family. He and his band have composed a series of songs that we will be using as part of our musical accompaniment.

I hope that you have watched our video, and I urge you to read on and learn more about this unique collaborative project. Your comments and support are greatly appreciated!


What is the project?

That Thing at That Place with That Person is a theatrical dance performance created through the collaboration of several artists. The piece journeys through the experiences of six unique characters, whose personalities and costumes have been defined by the personification of physical objects and animals. The six identities include: thimble, flower, skeleton, blackbird, candle, and wave. I am working closely with our costume designer and dancers to create a distinct visual look and unique movement quality for each of these characters. The performance will explore the interactions of these characters with each other and themselves, delving into universal human emotions and experiences. We are anticipating the completed work to run about 20 minutes. Stay tuned for updates and come see the live performance on April 9&10 to learn more!  


What do we need?

There are many factors that go into producing a professional performance, and it is with the help of friends, family members, and other supporters of the arts that such work is made possible. It is going to cost $4000 to bring my dream to life. That $4000 will be used toward production costs such as costume design and construction and professional video documentation of the performance. Donations of any amount are graciously accepted. As a token of our appreciation for your generosity, all donors will receive a link to an online sneak preview of the production.  


Think Big!

$4000 is our minimum goal and with that we will be able put on the show. However, this project has the potential for so much more. Please spread the word and help us to reach our larger goal of $5000. All funds raised go directly to enhancing the performance experience for the audience members. Additional funding would be used for developments such as hiring a makeup artist, hiring an actor for spoken word and narration, and/or rental of professional audio recording equipment.


Ways you can help!

Yes, we need the money, but there are other ways to help out as well. Here is a list of all the ways that you can help this project grow to its fullest potential.

  1) Donate to the campaign. Donations of every shape and size are gladly accepted!

  2) Share this campaign on social media. Please use the tools listed below the video   at the top of the page in order to promote this project. Indiegogo has this great   feature called the GoGoFactor. The more we promote, the more they do. So SHARE   SHARE SHARE! It only takes a half a second to click and share.

  3) Come to the show! The performances will be April 9&10, 2014 at 8:00PM at The   Garage in San Francisco. Come show your support in person and see what three short months of intense collaboration can produce. Tickets are a sliding scale cash   donation at the door. All proceeds go to The Garage, which is not only a wonderful  performance space, but a supporter and facilitator of producing new performance art   in San   Francisco.  


Who is involved?

Hanna Rose Stangebye (Choreographer/Director) is a new performing artist to the San Francisco bay area. A Michigan native, she recently graduated magna cum laude from Western Michigan University with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance. At WMU, Hanna Rose had the opportunity to perform original faculty works as well as works by renowned choreographers, such Alonzo King, Antony Tudor, Gerald Arpino, and KT Nelson. In addition to her performance experience at the university, Hanna has also appeared as a guest artist in productions of The Nutcracker, The Emperor and the Nightingale, and, The Dancing Princess. In the spring of 2012, she was selected as part of the Student Global Initiative to teach, perform, and study dance in Taiwan and China. Since relocating to the west coast Hanna Rose has been working as an apprentice with Garrett + Moulton Productions as well as producing her own work at The Garage and Dance Mission Theater. When she is not performing, Hanna Rose works as a group fitness instructor for Cardio Barre San Francisco, where she shares her love of movement with others in a safe, low-impact, high energy, dance inspired class.

Chad E. Leal (Costume Designer) aspires to achieve within the fashion community to build an all American made brand from fiber to garment. Offering a modern take on men and women’s classic silhouettes and fit; incorporating new textiles and fabrics. He attended the Art Institute of California – San Francisco Bachelor of Arts Fashion Design program and graduated in June of 2012. During his attendance, Leal entered in five fashion competitions and charity shows, winning the title of “Most Creative Design” for his 2011 Condom Collection at the student fashion show “Fashion Lineup.” This is Leal’s first collaboration with dance and he is very excited for the challenge. He plans to use his fascination with textures and the draping of fabric to enhance the movement of the piece and bring the characters to life. 

Jessica Bagley (Dancer/Flower) grew up dancing in Washington state.  She built up her technique studying Ballet with Russian-inspired instructors as well as exploring Modern techniques under Graham and Cunningham influences.  She earned a BFA in Dance from Cornish College of the Arts under Department Chair Kitty Daniels.  After graduating, Jessica transitioned to the San Francisco bay area to explore the dance culture.  She performs continually in workshops and projects around the area gathering up knowledge and discovering her influence on the industry with every opportunity. 

Keryn Breiterman-Loader (Dancer/Wave) started dancing at the age of 6 at the Miami City Ballet School, where she continued to train in their pre-professional program until starting college in 2009. She attended summer programs at the Joffrey Ballet, American Ballet Theater, and the Washington School of Ballet. In June of 2013, Keryn graduated from Stanford University, where she majored in psychology and minored in dance. At Stanford, Keryn trained in modern and contemporary dance, working closely with Diane Frank and Robert Moses. Keryn moved to San Francisco this past fall to pursue dance professionally. She is currently a member of the Natasha Carlitz Dance Ensemble.

Gabby Grady (Dancer/Candle) is a mid-westerner from Detroit, Michigan who was raised on Red Wings Hockey, corn on the cob, and performing arts. Gabby began her dance training in the Great Lakes State before moving to California.  Gabby had the honor to attend California State University, Long Beach where she completed her BFA in Dance and really honed her skills as a modern dancer. Gabby has also studied ballet, contemporary, hip hop, and tap but considers herself largely influenced by Limon style, release technique. Gabby has studied with many influential artists such as Keith Johnson, Andrew Vaca, Holly Johnston, Summer Lee Rhatigan, Sophie Monat, Lorin Johnson, Christian Burns, and Alex Ketley among others. Gabby is currently working as a Pilates Instructor having completed her BASI Pilates Teacher Training course under the supervision of Karen Clippinger. Gabby has also studied voice and acting. She has performed in several musical theater productions such as Peter Pan, The Producers, Guys and Dolls, and Aida. 

Rose Kirshner (Dancer/Skeleton) graduated cum laude from Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle with her BFA in Dance in May of 2013. She studied with Michele Miller, Lodi McClellan, Deborah Wolf, Wade Madsen, Pat Hon, and IyunHarrison. She began her dance training at Berkeley Ballet Theater with Sally Streets, Sarah Marcus,and Susan Weber in her hometown. She has been performing for nearly fifteen years and has beenchoreographing for six years.

David McMahan (Dancer/Thimble) is a graduate of the dance programs at Orange Coast College and the University of Arizona,where he studied under Linda Sohl-Ellison, Jose Costas,Amy Ernst andDouglas Nielsen.David has performed with Marie de la Palme's motion/TRIBE, Backhausdance and Opera Pacific, as well as in works ofPaul Taylor, Merce Cunningham,Bella Lewitzky,George Balanchine and Sir Frederick Ashton. He has taught throughout Arizona, California and nationally, including California State University Long Beach and the University of Arizona. David has also been an international guest teacher in Canada, Italy, Japan and South Korea.A graduate of the Fletcher Pilates Comprehensive Program, David has studied extensively under master teacher Kyria Sabinand teaches on faculty for the Fletcher Pilates Program of Study.

Nicholas Stettenbenz (Dancer/Blackbird) began dancing in Monterey, CA under the training of Deanna Ross in ballet and modern techniques. Aspiring to pursue a dance career, he continued his training at the University of California, Irvine where he received his Bachelor of Arts Degree in Dance. At Irvine, Nicholas was an original member of Sheron Wray’s Insight Jazz Ensemble, as well as performing in many show choreographed by UC Irvine faculty, guest artists, and graduate students. Moving to New York after graduation, Nicholas joined TranscenDanceGroup under the guidance and training of Gabriel Chajnik and Hector Zaraspe. Following a two year stay in New York, Nicholas decided to make San Francisco his permanent home.

Hailey Stangebye (Poet) will be graduating from Saint Joseph’s High School in South Bend, IN this year and is currently in the process of deciding where she wants to attend college. Her written work has been published in Discovered, a collection of student poetry. Already an accomplished dancer, actress, and writer, Hailey is thinking about pursuing medicine in her academic future, while still holding the arts very close to her heart.

Joel Stangebye’s (Musician/Composer) main goal in the near future is to finish the 8th grade. He and his band The Electronical Phantom just formed this year and are thrilled to be a part of his sister’s professional production on the other side of the country. When not playing the piano or the drums, Joel eats, sleeps, and breathes basketball.

documentation of the performance. Donations of any amount are graciously
accepted. As a token of our appreciation for your generosity, all donors will
receive a link to an online sneak preview of the production.  
Think
Big!
$4000 is our minimum goal and with that we will be able
put on the show. However, this project has the potential for so much more.
Please spread the word and help us to reach our larger goal of $5000. All funds
raised go directly to enhancing the performance experience for the audience
members. Additional funding would be used for developments such as hiring a
makeup artist, hiring an actor for spoken word and narration, and/or rental of
professional audio recording equipment. 
Ways
you can help! 
Yes, we need the money, but there are other
ways to help out as well. Here is a list of all the ways that you can help this
project grow to its fullest potential. 
  1)
Donate to the campaign. Donations of every shape and size are gladly accepted!
  2)
Share this campaign on social media. Please use the tools listed below the
video   at the top of the page in
order to promote this project. Indiegogo has this great   feature called the GoGoFactor. The more we promote, the more
they do. So SHARE   SHARE SHARE! It
only takes a half a second to click and share. 
  3)
Come to the show! The performances will be April 9&10, 2014 at 8:00PM at
The   Garage in San Francisco.
Come show your support in person and see what three  short months of intense collaboration can produce. Tickets are a
sliding scale cash   donation at the
door. All proceeds go to The Garage, which is not only a wonderful  performance space, but a supporter and
facilitator of producing new performance art   in
San   Francisco.  
Who
is involved?Hanna Rose Stangebye (Choreographer/Director) is a new
performing artist to the San Francisco bay area. A Michigan native, she
recently graduated magna cum laude from Western Michigan University with a
Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance. At WMU, Hanna Rose had the opportunity
to perform original faculty works as well as works by renowned choreographers,
such Alonzo King, Antony Tudor, Gerald Arpino, and KT Nelson. In addition to
her performance experience at the university, Hanna has also appeared as a
guest artist in productions of The
Nutcracker, The Emperor and the Nightingale, and, The Dancing Princess. In the spring of 2012, she was selected as
part of the Student Global Initiative to teach, perform, and study dance in
Taiwan and China. Since relocating to the west coast Hanna Rose has been
working as an apprentice with Garrett + Moulton Productions as well as
producing her own work at The Garage and Dance Mission Theater. When she is not
performing, Hanna Rose works as a group fitness instructor for Cardio Barre San
Francisco, where she shares her love of movement with others in a safe,
low-impact, high energy, dance inspired class. 
Chad
E. Leal (Costume Designer)
aspires to achieve within the fashion community to build an all American made
brand from fiber to garment. Offering a modern take on men and women’s classic
silhouettes and fit; incorporating new textiles and fabrics. He attended the
Art Institute of California – San Francisco Bachelor of Arts Fashion Design
program and graduated in June of 2012. During his attendance, Leal entered in
five fashion competitions and charity shows, winning the title of “Most
Creative Design” for his 2011 Condom Collection at the student fashion show
“Fashion Lineup.” This is Leal’s first collaboration with dance and he is very
excited for the challenge. He plans to use his fascination with textures and
the draping of fabric to enhance the movement of the piece and bring the
characters to life.  
Jessica Bagley (Dancer/Flower)
grew up dancing in Washington state.  She built up her technique studying
Ballet with Russian-inspired instructors as well as exploring Modern techniques
under Graham and Cunningham influences.  She earned a BFA in Dance from
Cornish College of the Arts under Department Chair Kitty Daniels.  After
graduating, Jessica transitioned to the San Francisco bay area to explore the
dance culture.  She performs continually in workshops and projects around
the area gathering up knowledge and discovering her influence on the industry
with every opportunity. 
Keryn Breiterman-Loader (Dancer/Wave) started dancing at the age
of 6 at the Miami City Ballet School, where she continued to train in their
pre-professional program until starting college in 2009. She attended summer
programs at the Joffrey Ballet, American Ballet Theater, and the Washington School
of Ballet. In June of 2013, Keryn graduated from Stanford University, where she
majored in psychology and minored in dance. At Stanford, Keryn trained in
modern and contemporary dance, working closely with Diane Frank and Robert Moses.
Keryn moved to San Francisco this past fall to pursue dance professionally. She
is currently a member of the Natasha Carlitz Dance Ensemble. 
Gabby Grady (Dancer/Candle) is
a mid-westerner from Detroit, Michigan who was raised on Red Wings Hockey, corn
on the cob, and performing arts. Gabby began her dance training in the Great
Lakes State before moving to California.  Gabby had the honor to attend
California State University, Long Beach where she completed her BFA in Dance
and really honed her skills as a modern dancer. Gabby has also studied ballet,
contemporary, hip hop, and tap but considers herself largely influenced by Limon
style, release technique. Gabby has studied with many influential artists such
as Keith Johnson, Andrew Vaca, Holly Johnston, Summer Lee Rhatigan, Sophie
Monat, Lorin Johnson, Christian Burns, and Alex Ketley among others. Gabby is currently
working as a Pilates Instructor having completed her BASI Pilates Teacher
Training course under the supervision of Karen Clippinger. Gabby has also
studied voice and acting. She has performed in several musical theater
productions such as Peter Pan, The Producers, Guys and Dolls, and Aida. 
Rose Kirshner (Dancer/Skeleton) graduated cum laude
from Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle with her BFA in Dance in May of
2013.
She studied with Michele Miller, Lodi McClellan,
Deborah Wolf, Wade Madsen, Pat Hon, and IyunHarrison. She began her dance training at
Berkeley Ballet Theater with Sally Streets, Sarah Marcus,and
Susan Weber in her hometown. She has been performing for nearly fifteen years
and has beenchoreographing
for six years.
David McMahan (Dancer/Thimble) is
a graduate of the dance programs at Orange Coast College and the University of
Arizona,where he studied under
Linda Sohl-Ellison, Jose Costas,Amy
Ernst andDouglas Nielsen.David has performed with Marie de la
Palme's motion/TRIBE, Backhausdance and Opera Pacific, as well as in works ofPaul Taylor, Merce Cunningham,Bella Lewitzky,George Balanchine and Sir Frederick
Ashton. He has taught throughout Arizona, California and nationally, including
California State University Long Beach and the University of Arizona. David has
also been an international guest teacher in Canada, Italy, Japan and South
Korea.A graduate of the Fletcher
Pilates Comprehensive Program, David has studied extensively under master
teacher Kyria Sabinand teaches
on faculty for the Fletcher Pilates Program of Study.
Nicholas Stettenbenz (Dancer/Blackbird)
began dancing in Monterey, CA under the training of Deanna Ross in ballet and
modern techniques. Aspiring to pursue a dance career, he continued his training
at the University of California, Irvine where he received his Bachelor of Arts
Degree in Dance. At Irvine, Nicholas was an original member of Sheron Wray’s
Insight Jazz Ensemble, as well as performing in many show choreographed by UC
Irvine faculty, guest artists, and graduate students. Moving to New York after
graduation, Nicholas joined TranscenDanceGroup under the guidance and training
of Gabriel Chajnik and Hector Zaraspe. Following a two year stay in New York,
Nicholas decided to make San Francisco his permanent home. 
Hailey Stangebye (Poet)
will be graduating from Saint Joseph’s High School in South Bend, IN this year
and is currently in the process of deciding where she wants to attend college.
Her written work has been published in Discovered,
a collection of student poetry. Already an accomplished dancer, actress, and
writer, Hailey is thinking about pursuing medicine in her academic future,
while still holding the arts very close to her heart. 
Joel Stangebye’s (Musician/Composer)
main goal in the near future is to finish the 8th grade. He and his
band The Electronical Phantom just
formed this year and are thrilled to be a part of his sister’s professional
production on the other side of the country. When not playing the piano or the
drums, Joel eats, sleeps, and breathes basketball.

story:
I have been dancing since “mi eye deh ah mi knee”and my passion has flourished into a successful career, as I graduate this July from Codarts: Rotterdam Dance Academy,with a Bachelor of Arts in Performance, Dance. Learn more about me :

www.ajwanliss.com

As part of my vision, I am presenting a Gala Dance event:“DansWidMi” that showcases local dance companies that have had a significant impact on my dance career,such as L’Acadco: A United Caribbean Dance Force,Movement Dance Theatre,The Company Dance Theatre and Ardenne Dance Troupe, guest teacher/performer Eva Calanni,and international dance company DanceSpeak.

DansWidMi  will also feature the fusion techniques I have developed, as part one of my vision to bridge cultures through dance, takes life. 

By supporting DansWidMi you will assist with funding tuition for a student interested in Dance from the Jamaica Association for the Deaf.

I will also host a week long workshop for interested dance peers to introduce them to techniques I learned internationally.

What We Need

I am asking for donations towards the Production costs. Listed below you can see the overview of the production in United States Dollars (USD). 

BUDGET ITEM

COST

Production & Logistics

USD$ 7,000

Venue & Admin

USD$ 6,000

Marketing & PR

USD$ 4,000

TOTAL

USD$17,000

The Impact

I am forever grateful for the encouragement from my family, guidance from my dance teachers and peers, and the financial support from the C.H.A.S.E fund and other Jamaican Business philanthropists who have and continue to believe in my vision. Ultimately, I would like to establish a Performing Arts Stadium and Conservatory in Jamaica. I see this opportunity as a way to build bridges and connect with the rest of the world through the arts. I am proud of my heritage and  and want to give back to it as much as possible. So in supporting this event, you will be contributing to a larger vision.

Other Ways You Can Help

Call or email the DansWidMi Production Team for information on how you can donate in other ways. NatalieReid-Production Manager |876-483-4994| Natalie@anubiscommunications.com OR Donnah/ DaleWanliss-ExecutiveDirectors | 876-533-2927| donnahwanliss@gmail.com

Also, please share and encourage others to donate towards this campaign. Any donation, whether small or large, is greatly appreciated. :)

story:
WHO WE ARE

"...an essential part of the city's arts scene." – The Oregonian

Founded in 2004 by acclaimed dancer, mentor, and choreographer, Sarah Slipper, Northwest Dance Project is the nation’s premiere company for all-original world-class contemporary dance.

Based in the city that routinely tops “best of” lists, Portland, Oregon, Northwest Dance Project is dedicated to the creation and performance of innovative, contemporary dance works from the field’s top dance makers created in an open and artistically stimulating environment.


OUR NEW HOME

Now in our eleventh season and going strong, Northwest Dance Project is proudly expanding into a new home for creation, art, and movement. Our new home serving the entire Portland metro area will feature two spacious professionally equipped dance studios, and be a vital and vibrant artistic placemaker in the heart of the city.

"...some of the best dancers you will ever see." – Calgary Herald

STEPPING INTO THE STUDIO

Before our international award-winning dance company can take its first steps in the new studio and creative center, we need your support to lay the groundwork and secure — literally — the foundation of a professional dance studio: a sprung dance floor.

What make a sprung floor vital for dance? A professional sprung floor absorbs shock (over 60%) and energy to reduce injuries, and also returns just the right amount of energy to give lift to moves like jumps.


A sprung floor with a non-slip vinyl surface (marley) is crucial for all forms of dance and other movement activities, and is critical in preventing physical stress, injuries, and strains. Like a good racetrack, it should have just the right amount of give and it should not be too hard (which causes repetitive strain) or too soft (which is tiring). It has to be just right…

Sprung flooring is the best surface for any dancer to use, from absolute beginners to advanced professionals, and is standard for any equipped dance facility.

We go to the nation’s top dance floor producer to ensure we have the best floors money can buy. But it’s more than ordering the material, we will also need the nails to keep it together, marley and gaff tape for a smooth dance surface, and of course, most importantly, experts to put it all together.


WE NEED YOUR HELP

Join our construction crew and donate today! You can provide the legwork by supplying us with this vital resource! We need $22,000 to leap into the studio and get our choreographic cogs turning — so jump up and step in and help us meet our goal!

Not only will you have the pride of knowing you’re supporting one of the country’s top companies, and protecting the joints of all the dancers who come to us — we’ll also reward your support with cool "thank you"s!

Every dollar counts, no amount is too small.

story:
Our Story

When you infuse spoken word into a soul rockin' musical, you get A Taste of Chocolate. Believing there is more to life than becoming a small town preacher in Alabama, this tale follows Kofi through dance, rhythm and rhyme as he journeys to Hollywood to find his own voice. 


A TASTE OF CHOCOLATE, an original musical written by Timothy Ware, has been invited to make its NYC premier this July at the Midtown International Theatre Festival (MITF).


Every summer in midtown Manhattan, MITF celebrates the diversity of theatre in New York City and beyond. MITF welcomes theatrical storytelling across a broad spectrum of genres, forms, identities, cultures, and appetites. The MITF proudly hosts production companies from across the country and around the globe, uniting talent in one of the biggest theatre capitals in the world. 



The Impact

This festival will not only be used as a platform for Timothy Ware to showcase A TASTE OF CHOCOLATE, but it will be an introduction of himself to the NYC theatrical community as a playwright. 


What We Need & What You Get

In order to lay a strong foundation to thrust A TASTE OF CHOCOLATE from it's Off-off Broadway Premiere at MITF, to the hopes of one day seeing its title in the lights of a Broadway marquee, we need your help. It takes a lot of funds to produce a musical in NYC. Your generous donations will help fund the costs of actors, musicians, costumes, props, rehearsal space and other misc. needs in order to produce a first rate production.   


There are a list of perks you will receive for your contributions. But imagine if you were able to say, "I helped A CHORUS LINE raise money before it became a Broadway sensation," or "I believed in FELA before anyone else did and my donation helped get his story told." Will you be that angel for A TASTE OF CHOCOLATE? 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word. Share this link on your Facebook and Twitter accounts. Buy tickets to the show.


Stay up to date by visiting A TASTE OF CHOCOLATE's website: www.CHOCOLATE-MUSICAL.com

Also for perks of $200 contributions or more visit: www.DarkImageProductions.com

story:
It's summer! (Almost) 

And Terra Firma is getting ready to roll up our sleeves and make some  more dynamic, invigorating theatre!

We've got an incredibly exciting few months planned. 

First, we will be at The Figment Festival, performing our newest show, Manuscripts Don't Burn. It will run for free on Governors Island in June! This show will wander through the nooks and crannies of the island's historic architecture, filling the air with the magic, music, and devilish characters of Bulgakov's imagination.

Then, in August, we are back up in the Catskill Mountains, for our second artists retreat. This time the focus is on the playwright. What kind of work can a writer create when removed from the distractions of the city? How will the plays grow, when there is a whole group of actors assembled to work solely on the playwright's new pages? These questions will be answered over the seven day retreat, when three playwrights and four actors will live, breathe, and work new theatre. 

This summer, we will continue to create and produce the work we are known for - work that is collaborative, challenging, and adventurous. If this is enough to spark your support, give now, using the button on the top right. If you want to know more, read on for the details!

We thank you for your generous support! It's going to be a very creative, collaborative few months!


Manuscripts Don't Burn

The Figment Festival approached us in December about performing a site-specific show on Governors Island this summer. We, of course leapt at the chance to work in such a pristine, historic location. And we knew exactly what the piece should be about... 

Mikhail Bulgakov. 


Our dramaturgs, Rob Cohn and Colin Mannex, teamed up and began to furiously pour over Bulgakov's literature and documents. Working along side director Anna Jones, the three began shaping a story out of the masses of source texts that we had compiled. Among some of the texts which they pulled from are: The Master and Margarita, Dead Man's Memoir, The White Guard, Diaboliad, Morphine, and Flight of the Turbans.

To flesh out the literature, Joe Osheroff and Puppet Kitchen agreed to come on board to build original masks and puppets. Katie Vida and Boris Chesakov, two exceptionally innovative visual artists, will be designing the sets and props. Rebecca Welles, with the help of Liz Maher, will be creating our costumes. Actors Alexandra O'Daly, Ben Weber, Sophia Holman, Stephanie Bratnick, Ryan King, Ken King, and Stephanie Hayes are taking on the principle roles. They will be joined by 10 other actors and a few musicians, who will help flesh out the rest of the play.

And so, with our team all lined up at the starting line... 

                     We are off to Governors Island to begin this wild journey of creation!



THE Story

Manuscripts Don't Burn is a visceral romp through one writer's over-active imagination, where devils are your hosts, cats have human appetites, puppets are suicidal, and the best literary talents can't seem to catch a break. This 80 minute roving theatrical installation is cultivated from Mikhail Bulgakov's writings, including Master and Margarita, The Diaboliad, and The White Guard. Masks, puppets, and musicians create a world of shadow-agents and supernatural obstacles. As the journey unfolds, our audience follows a forlorn writer, tormented by his talent and wild fantasies. In each room, another puzzle piece of the story is revealed. Behind each door lies a secret waiting to be whispered to the audience through imagery, language, and movement. These fragmented vignettes slowly build together to reveal the true heart of our writer's plight and his fantastical redemption.

Trapped in a bureaucratic world, our hero faces unnerving challenges that--despite their surreality--inform our perspective on the difficulties facing artists in our own culture. How do we fight an oppressive regime when the drive for censorship takes hold in our hearts?

Our Company

Terra Firma Theatre Company is dedicated to sustainable artistic practice with a deep rooted commitment to the creation of new work. By creating, working, and living outside of the city for specific periods of time before bringing our work back to a larger audience, the company is able to dig further into our imaginations and challenge ourselves deeper. By utilizing whatever environment and tools we have at our immediate disposal, our ensemble strives to create theatre of exceptional quality that is aesthetically challenging and innovative, as well as being developed and produced in a unique and sustainable way.


For more information on our philosophy and work please visit: www.terrafirmatheatre.org.


The Festival and Terra Firma


The Figment Festival is a visual art festival that, since 2007, takes over Governors Island for three days each summer. Each year thousands of people attend to see the hundreds of art exhibits that fill every corner of the island.They encourage the artists to create work the patrons can participate in, blending the traditional rules of creator and audience. Their website describes it like this:

FIGMENT is an explosion of creative energy. It’s a free, annual celebration of participatory art and culture where everything is possible. For one weekend each summer, it transforms Governors Island into a large-scale collaborative artwork – and then it’s gone.

We got so excited about Figment, we decided to weave these principals into the fabric of our show. To us, theatre offers the unique opportunity to take all the art disciplines and mesh them together. We wanted to make the creation and performance of this play a truly collaborative undertaking. This is why we have pulled from so many art forms to create the play.


But why stop there? Figment offered us the challenge and opportunity to investigate how the audience participates in the creation of performance. By removing the barriers of a legitimate stage, our patrons are free to participate fully in the unfolding of our story. The line between who is making the art and who is watching it becomes blurred, since there is no physical boundary between performer and observer. We are also considering passing out disposable cameras to many of the audience members. These individuals would be encouraged and asked to take photos as they journey through the play. Each individual's significant and unique vantage point would be documented through the photographs they take. Thus, they are simultaneously making their own artwork, as they are experiencing art being made. These photos will be developed by the company and posted on our website following the show.


What We Need & What You Get

Help us make this show a reality! This entire show is being created on the small budget of $4,700. And we only have $3,000 left to raise!

$5, $10, $20, or $100 donations will go directly to helping us fill in the missing $3,500! And make sure you check out the amazing incentives you will receive when you donate! Details are listed on the right column. 

Read below to find out exactly where your money will be going -

Because we believe it is important for artists to be compensated for their passion, talent, and hard work, $2,000 of this budget is going directly towards actor stipends. 

$1,300 is going to designing the show. We have been very lucky to be accepted by Materials For The Arts as a member. They receive donations from all over the country of anything from office supplies to paint to wood to props. Then, non-profit art companies like us, get to use these materials for free to make our work! But we still need funds to design the beautiful costumes designed by Rebecca Welles. 

The final $1,400 goes towards the rental of rehearsal space and transportation to and from the island. Because of the amount of people participating in the show, as well as the puppets and mask work we are incorporating, it is vital we have large dance spaces to play in. These spaces coast anywhere from $8 - $30 an hour. And we need to pay for over 100 hours of rehearsal! We will also need to rent vans to move our set, costumes, and artists on and off the island via the free ferry.

Anything we raise over our initial budget will go to supporting our writers during the August retreat!

Pitch in and Make Great Art a Reality! Here Are Other Ways You Can Help -

Spread the word! There are many ways you can pitch in and help us. 


- Pass along our IndieGoGo site to friends, family, and colleagues. And encourage them to pass it along to their friends. This is a simple, but oh-so-effective way to spread the word.


- Find us and friend us on facebook! Or follow us on twitter!


- And don't forget to follow our blog at http://terrafirmatheatre.wordpress.com/

What kind of work can a writer create when removed from the distractions of the city? How will the plays grow, when there is a whole group of actors assembled to work solely on the playwright's new pages? These questions will be answered over the seven day retreat, when three playwrights and four actors will live, breathe, and work new theatre. 

This summer, we will continue to create and produce the work we are known for - work that is collaborative, challenging, and adventurous. If this is enough to spark your support, give now, using the button on the top right. If you want to know more, read on for the details!

We thank you for your generous support! It's going to be a very creative, collaborative few months!

Manuscripts Don't Burn
The Figment Festival approached us in December about performing a site-specific show on Governors Island this summer. We, of course leapt at the chance to work in such a pristine, historic location. And we knew exactly what the piece should be about... 

Mikhail Bulgakov. 


Our dramaturgs, Rob Cohn and Colin Mannex, teamed up and began to furiously pour over Bulgakov's literature and documents. Working along side director Anna Jones, the three began shaping a story out of the masses of source texts that we had compiled. Among some of the texts which they pulled from are: The Master and Margarita, Dead Man's Memoir, The White Guard, Diaboliad, Morphine, and Flight of the Turbans.

To flesh out the literature, Joe Osheroff and Puppet Kitchen agreed to come on board to build original masks and puppets. Katie Vida and Boris Chesakov, two exceptionally innovative visual artists, will be designing the sets and props. Rebecca Welles, with the help of Liz Maher, will be creating our costumes. Actors Alexandra O'Daly, Ben Weber, Sophia Holman, Stephanie Bratnick, Ryan King, Ken King, and Stephanie Hayes are taking on the principle roles. They will be joined by 10 other actors and a few musicians, who will help flesh out the rest of the play.

And so, with our team all lined up at the starting line... 

                     We are off to Governors Island to begin this wild journey of creation!



THE Story
Manuscripts Don't Burn is a visceral romp through one writer's over-active imagination, where devils are your hosts, cats have human appetites, puppets are suicidal, and the best literary talents can't seem to catch a break. This 80 minute roving theatrical installation is cultivated from Mikhail Bulgakov's writings, including Master and Margarita, The Diaboliad, and The White Guard. Masks, puppets, and musicians create a world of shadow-agents and supernatural obstacles. As the journey unfolds, our audience follows a forlorn writer, tormented by his talent and wild fantasies. In each room, another puzzle piece of the story is revealed. Behind each door lies a secret waiting to be whispered to the audience through imagery, language, and movement. These fragmented vignettes slowly build together to reveal the true heart of our writer's plight and his fantastical redemption.

Trapped in a bureaucratic world, our hero faces unnerving challenges that--despite their surreality--inform our perspective on the difficulties facing artists in our own culture. How do we fight an oppressive regime when the drive for censorship takes hold in our hearts?

Our Company
Terra Firma Theatre Company is dedicated to sustainable artistic practice with a deep rooted commitment to the creation of new work. By creating, working, and living outside of the city for specific periods of time before bringing our work back to a larger audience, the company is able to dig further into our imaginations and challenge ourselves deeper. By utilizing whatever environment and tools we have at our immediate disposal, our ensemble strives to create theatre of exceptional quality that is aesthetically challenging and innovative, as well as being developed and produced in a unique and sustainable way.

For more information on our philosophy and work please visit: www.terrafirmatheatre.org.


The Festival and Terra Firma

The Figment Festival is a visual art festival that, since 2007, takes over Governors Island for three days each summer. Each year thousands of people attend to see the hundreds of art exhibits that fill every corner of the island.They encourage the artists to create work the patrons can participate in, blending the traditional rules of creator and audience. Their website describes it like this:


FIGMENT is an explosion of creative energy. It’s a free, annual celebration of participatory art and culture where everything is possible. For one weekend each summer, it transforms Governors Island into a large-scale collaborative artwork – and then it’s gone.


We got so excited about Figment, we decided to weave these principals into the fabric of our show. To us, theatre offers the unique opportunity to take all the art disciplines and mesh them together. We wanted to make the creation and performance of this play a truly collaborative undertaking. This is why we have pulled from so many art forms to create the play.

But why stop there? Figment offered us the challenge and opportunity to investigate how the audience participates in the creation of performance. By removing the barriers of a legitimate stage, our patrons are free to participate fully in the unfolding of our story. The line between who is making the art and who is watching it becomes blurred, since there is no physical boundary between performer and observer. We are also considering passing out disposable cameras to many of the audience members. These individuals would be encouraged and asked to take photos as they journey through the play. Each individual's significant and unique vantage point would be documented through the photographs they take. Thus, they are simultaneously making their own artwork, as they are experiencing art being made. These photos will be developed by the company and posted on our website following the show.


What We Need & What You Get
Help us make this show a reality! This entire show is being created on the small budget of $4,700. And we only have $3,000 left to raise!

$5, $10, $20, or $100 donations will go directly to helping us fill in the missing $3,500! And make sure you check out the amazing incentives you will receive when you donate! Details are listed on the right column. 

Read below to find out exactly where your money will be going -

Because we believe it is important for artists to be compensated for their passion, talent, and hard work, $2,000 of this budget is going directly towards actor stipends. 

$1,300 is going to designing the show. We have been very lucky to be accepted by Materials For The Arts as a member. They receive donations from all over the country of anything from office supplies to paint to wood to props. Then, non-profit art companies like us, get to use these materials for free to make our work! But we still need funds to design the beautiful costumes designed by Rebecca Welles. 

The final $1,400 goes towards the rental of rehearsal space and transportation to and from the island. Because of the amount of people participating in the show, as well as the puppets and mask work we are incorporating, it is vital we have large dance spaces to play in. These spaces coast anywhere from $8 - $30 an hour. And we need to pay for over 100 hours of rehearsal! We will also need to rent vans to move our set, costumes, and artists on and off the island via the free ferry.

Anything we raise over our initial budget will go to supporting our writers during the August retreat!


Pitch in and Make Great Art a Reality! Here Are Other Ways You Can Help -
Spread the word! There are many ways you can pitch in and help us. 

- Pass along our IndieGoGo site to friends, family, and colleagues. And encourage them to pass it along to their friends. This is a simple, but oh-so-effective way to spread the word.

- Find us and friend us on facebook! Or follow us on twitter!

- And don't forget to follow our blog at http://terrafirmatheatre.wordpress.com/

story:
The Lonny Chapman Group Repertory Theatre is a membership company of Actors, Directors and Playwrights operating under the 99-Seat Actors Equity Waiver Plan. We have been in continuous operation for 38 years. In that time we have produced over 180 productions, including more than 40 original world premieres. Our membership dues and ticket sale revenues account for only half of our annual budget.  The remainder of our operating expenses are drawn from donations. This is where our campaign comes in to play.

The Group Rep is proud to be presenting Charles Marowitz’ “Sherlock’s Last Case” directed by Larry Eisenberg, produced by Drina Durazo.  Picking up where Arthur Conan Doyle's stories ended, the play centers on a death threat against Holmes by the "son" of his late nemesis, Professor Moriarty. Oddly enough, however, Holmes is warned of the plot by Moriarity's "daughter," to whom Holmes (who turns out to be quite a ladies man) is strongly attracted. The plot twists and turns until Holmes finds himself imprisoned in a dank cellar, trapped and for the first time in his illustrious career surprised by human behavior.  Part spoof, part loving tribute...all fun!

We are attempting to raise $2,500 to underwrite the production costs of “Sherlock’s Last Case.” This will include the cost of the royalties and costume design. With a character as tremendously popular as Sherlock Holmes, you can imagine that obtaining the rights to put on this production could get pretty pricey. His name may not be the first to come to mind when it comes to super heroes, but he’s the first person we’d go to if we needed a mystery solved.

As for the costumes, period pieces tend to make for difficult costuming when it comes to seeking and fitting. We often utilize our own resources, but don't have everything we need for this production. We will have to rent, which can be very pricey! Once costumes are found, they will usually need to be altered, repaired, and also dry-cleaned throughout the run of the show. Another pricey process! 

We can’t do this without your kind generosity and support!

You will notice we have a lot of great incentives for our donors. We would be eternally grateful if you could help our campaign in any way possible. Any amount, great or small, would be greatly appreciated! No amount is too little. If you aren't able to donate, please get the word out about our campaign! Let your friends, family, or pool guy know we're putting on a Sherlock production and need help solving The Case of The Group Rep Needs Your Support!

Another way you could help out is simply by letting your friends/fellow theatre lovers and fellow Sherlock lovers know about our theatre and production. Invite them to see the show with you, or simply recommend it to them. It's that simple.

Your help and support will not go unoticed. Thank you for taking the time to review our campaign. Please take a moment to utilize the Share tools and support us today!

 

Sherlock's Last Case

by Charles Marowitz

Directed by Larry Eisenberg, Assistant Directed by William Troy Whitaker, Produced for the Group Rep by Drina Durazo

Running November 30, 2012 - January 13, 2013

The Cast:

SHERLOCK: Chris Winfield
WATSON: Bert Emmett
MRS. HUDSON: Hersha Parady
LESTRADE: Patrick Burke
LIZA: Allison King

SHERLOCK u/s: Doug Haverty
WATSON u/s: Kent Butler


The Designers:

Costume Design/Stage Manager: Emily Doyle
Light Design: Kim Smith
Sound Design: Steve Shaw
Production Design: Chris Winfield
Special Fx/Prop Design: Drina Durazo

 

THANK YOU AGAIN!!!

Your donation is tax deductible.

www.thegrouprep.com

story:
Our Story

September 12th, 13th and 14th, at the Society Hill Playhouse, Kathy's Daughter will make its debut in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival. Kathy's Daughter, a stage play loosely based on the lives of Catherine Patterson and Katrina Deaton, also known as K.J., delves into the life of character Christina Leeds. Unable to deal with the baggage of her past, Christina wittingly shares her experiences with the audience as she inches closer to her final decision to take her life.

 

Creating awareness through art, writer, director, producer, Katrina Deaton, will use Kathy's Daughter as a platform to launch a non-profit in her mother's name called, "Cathy's Daughters." With a redemptive theme, the non-profit will implement programs transforming victims into activists with a heavy focus on domestic violence, physical and sexual abuse, and depression.

The Impact

Katrina Deaton and her mother Catherine Patterson, who passed away in 97', were both victims of domestic violence and suicide survivors. Katrina's attachment to the production and its purpose, pushed her to partner with organizations in the Phialdelphia area who work directly with populations affected by domestic violence and suicide. Each night of the production, an organization will be highlighted. They will be able to answer questions and offer resources before and after the play. They will also receive a donation from ticket sales that night.

 

Women in Transition, an organization that offers counseling and advocacy for women endangered by domestic abuse, have already partnered with the production and will be featured Monday night, September 12th. The American Suicide Prevention Association has also expressed interest in partnering with the production. Closing night will focus on Cathy's Daughters the non-profit. "Everything happens for a reason. To be a victim is not enough, when you can be empowered to use the pain and awareness you receive from a horrible experience to heal or save another."

What We Need & What You Get

The Philadelphia Fringe Festival allows artists to produce their own work while using their esteemed reputation. In addition to Fringe Festival fees, you must also pay for a venue to host your production as well as insurance to cover it. The money raised will be used to cover these costs in addition to casting (actors), stage management (props, costumes, set design, public relations (fliers, photography, website), miscellaneous (rental space for rehearsals, tech support, copies), etc.

 

Donations: We welcome any and all monetary donations

 

Director / $1,000 -  5 free tickets to the show,  a special invitation for four to our VIP reception September 3rd, promotion and special thanks to donator on all literature produced for the play

 

Stage Manager / $500 - 4 free tickets to the show, a special invitation for two to our VIP reception September 3rd, promotion and special thanks to donator on all literature produced for the play

 

Producer / $250 - 2 free tickets to the show, a special invitation for one to our VIP reception September 3rd, promotion and special thanks to donator in playbill

 

Actor / $100 - 1 free ticket to the show, a special thanks to donator in playbill

 

Audience / $50 Special Thanks

 

 

 


Other Ways You Can Help

 

Please spread the word about the production Kathy's Daughter and its mission. You can visit and refer others to:
 
 http://kathysdaughtertheplay.tumblr.com/ or purchase tickets at http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/188463

story:
About the Show

The Changeling
by William Rowley and Thomas Middleton
Adapted by Corbin Went
Directed by Emma Went

Sex and repression, danger and guilt, madness and murder. These are the currents that drive Middleton and Rowley's The Changeling, and make it one of the great Jacobean tragedies that have come to define the genre. Locked in a ruthless game of blackmail and violence, the central characters will stop at nothing to achieve their goals, and their ensuing romance unleashes an energy dark enough to threaten the morals of their entire world. Written in the 1620's, The Changeling is perhaps the most modern play of its period, and its stark universe is a discomfiting mirror to our own. As it careens from the brutal to the tender, probing issues of sin, authenticity, and sexual politics, The Changeling gives voice to our most frightening desires.

Easy Leap Theatre Company launches their fourth full-length production, taking a exciting risk with this Jacobean tragedy, and a large group of dedicated actors and designers. They have a team, a theatre, a script, and now they need you to help them really get off the ground!


How your Donation Helps: 

  • Theatre Rental - We are thrilled to have a home for The Changeling with the fantastic West End Theater at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, and a large part of your donation will go towards renting this amazing space!
  • Artist Stipends - Although we are a young theatre company, we still believe artists should be paid for their time and talent. And do we have some serious talent on this show! Our budget includes compensating our team. 
  • Set/Props/Puppet/Costume Materials -  The West End Theater is beautiful on its own but we'll need some extra funds for scenic painting, sourcing costumes for our actors, and materials to sculpt and bring to life some stellar puppets. 
  • Miscellaneous Expenses - Aside from from our designers' budgets and our space rental, there are miscellaneous expenses to take care of, including marketing costs (signs, postcards) as well as programs to be printed, event insurance and volunteer insurance to be acquired, props to be bought, etc...

    About Easy Leap Theatre Company

      Easy Leap is a New York City-based theatre company dedicated to viewing Shakespeare and other heightened language plays through the lens of contemporary youth culture.

      Through a blend of modern adaptations and more traditional productions, we are exploring how centuries old stories can speak to the present as our generation experiences it, and how newer works can tap into that classical poetic spirit. 

      Other Ways to Help

      We are so excited to be presenting this production in this space with this group of artists, and we thank you so much for your contributions. Our last time on Indiegogo, we met (and surpassed) our goal thanks to your generosity, and that campaign allowed us to kick-start our company's first year and produce two more full length shows. If you can't donate at this time, we hope you'll tell your friends, and join us in November when the show opens - you won't want to miss this!

      For updates on The Changeling and Easy Leap: 
      Follow us on facebook
      Check out our website
      Like us on Instagram @easyleaptc 
      Thank you for your donation - we look forward to seeing you at the show!

      *Trailer video shot and edited by Mike Hayhurst, at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew. Featuring Jovan Davis, Corbin Went, and Morgan Wolk.
