story:
The Film

This dance film short takes place in Western NY, in an old manor house, situated on a cliff overlooking Lake Erie.  The dancer, Helen French, portrays two characters, or rather two aspects of the same woman.  Indoors, we observe her isolated inside a starkly furnished room.  She is trapped inside the walls, inside her mind, possibly by old memories and habits or society.  She looks out the window and visualizes the freedom and endless possibilities that the outdoors have to offer.  Does she follow her vision of freedom?  Or does she remain confined behind closed doors?  

Named “best in dance” 2011 by Sarah Kaufman of the Washington Post, Karen Reedy Dance (KRD) is a professional modern dance company located in the Washington DC Metro Area. Devoted to nurturing artists through the exploration of new work and collaboration with other art forms, KRD performs in both traditional and site-specific venues.  This project marks Reedy’s first venture into the genre of dance for film, after years of interest in creating movement specifically for the unique perspective of the camera.  She was granted the Mathy Junior Faculty Award from the George Mason University College of Humanities and Social Sciences for this project.  Additionally, KRD received a project grant (requiring matching funds) from The Alexandria Commission for the Arts specifically for this film.  

Please help us to fully realize this project.  We are seeking funds to take the film from our raw footage, to the editing room and theaters!

What We Need & What You Get

We are half way to making our dreams come true! In September, the film cast/crew was in residence in Derby, NY where we shot all of the footage for the film.  Now, we need your support as we head into the post-production stages of the project.  During the fall and winter 2014-2015, the film must come together through editing, music composition and marketing.  We have the raw footage…now we need to turn this dream into a reality.  

We want you to be a part of this exciting process with us.  As a supporter of the film, you will receive rewards such as: updates from Reedy as the film moves through post-production, a copy of the DVD, invitations to preview screenings and VIP tickets to concerts and open rehearsals.  You may even see your name in the credits as an Associate Producer!!! Join us!

If we exceed our goal (yes please!!), the additional funding will directly support the artists and production expenses for the Karen Reedy Dance 2014-2015 performance season!  Performances include site-specific works throughout Alexandria and a weekend of performances at Dance Place April 11 and 12, 2015.  For this concert, we are thrilled to be hosting Project. B. from San Francisco.  This is the second half of our SWAP program…KRD shared the stage with Project. B. in San Francisco in 2013.  Please visit www.reedydance.org for more information about our upcoming season.

Meet Our Team

Karen Reedy (Director and Choreographer) is a choreographer, dancer and dance educator.  She has performed with D.C. Dance Theater, Eric Hampton Dance, Robert Battle, Sue Bernhard, Louis Johnson, Patricia Kenny, and the Mark Morris Dance Group.  Her work has been performed throughout the country, in venues including The Kennedy Center, Dance Place, ODC, ADI, Black Rock Arts Center, The 92nd Street Y, The Torpedo Factory and Joyce SoHo.  Ms. Reedy has been a recipient of the Kennedy Center Millennium Stage Local Dance Commissioning Grant, selected as a Metro Arts Incubator Artist at the American Dance Institute, and a Mathy Junior Faculty Award winner.  She has been on the faculty of the Juilliard School, the Mark Morris Dance Center and the Chautauqua Institution.  Ms. Reedy holds an M.F.A in Dance from George Mason University, where she is an Assistant Professor of Dance.  

Helen Hansen French (Dancer) received her B.F.A from The Juilliard School in 2001 under the direction of Benjamin Harkarvy. She joined Buglisi Dance Theatre upon graduating  and toured nationally and internationally as a principal dancer. Mrs. French is instrumental in re-staging BDT’s works on professional companies as well as colleges through out the United States. Her choreography has been shown at Studio@620, Kaatsbaan, and St. Petersburg College.  As a teacher of both dance and The Alexander Technique she has been on faculty at The Juilliard School, The Neighborhood Playhouse, George Mason University, and St. Petersburg College.  Helen joined Karen Reedy Dance in 2011. 

Ludovic Jolivet (Director of Photography), a native of Paris, France, is a choreographer, filmmaker, and dancer. He received his BFA in dance from the Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, and his MFA in choreography from the University of Maryland. Mr. Jolivet has created and directed dances for film that have been presented at venues and dance festivals worldwide; his choreography for stage has traveled the US and Europe. Awards for his works include the 2013 Maryland State Arts Council’s Individual Artist Award in choreography, the 2004 Maryland State Arts Council’s Individual Artist Award in Film and the 2003 Metro DC Dance Award for Emerging Choreographer; in 2006, his work was commissioned by the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Mr. Jolivet has taught dance and theatre courses at universities in the DC area and St Mary’s County. He has participated in four international 48-hour film festival projects, one of which won the Best Choreography award in 2006. He is currently teaching New Media and Dance for the MFA program at The George Washington University, and continuing his exploration of dance/choreography for both stage and film.

Yao Chen (Costume Designer) designs costumes for theatre, dance and film.  Most recently, she wrapped up her first international production Amadues in Teatro Espressivo in San Jose, Costa Rica. She is now designing a lovely children's show in Orlando Repertory Theatre that opens in March 2015. She designed Ti Jean and His Brothers and Rinoceros for University of South Florida from 2013 to 2014. In 2011 she won the Austin Critics Table Award for outstanding costume design for the production of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde at the University of Texas at Austin and she worked in Zach Sco

Carl Landa (Composer)  is currently the Music Director of the Dance Department at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, NY.  He plays piano, percussion, synthesizers and laptops.  Carl composes original scores for dance, videos, and audio books.

Lauren Burke (Sound Technician and Promotional Filmmaker) is a multimedia artist and professional video maker.

The Impact

The genre of dance for film, or screendance, is prominent in Europe and gaining exposure here in the USA.  KRD has a long history of collaborating with other artists and mediums, from visual artists to musicians, and the creation of a dance film is the next clear step for us in collaboration. Performance for the stage and the screen are very different mediums. Ms. Reedy is excited to explore the new challenges that choreographing for film has to offer.   She chose to work with Ludovic Jolivet as the Director of Photography for this project due to his experience in dance film, as well as his complimentary aesthetic.  When the project is complete, the film will be shown in concert with KRD as well as submitted to local, national and international  film festivals around the world!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please join us for this campaign!  No amount is too small to help support this project.  

Can’t contribute money, but would like to help?  Please share this campaign with others and help us get the word out!!
story_txt:
The Film


This dance film short takes place in Western NY, in an old manor house, situated on a cliff overlooking Lake Erie.  The dancer, Helen French, portrays two characters, or rather two aspects of the same woman.  Indoors, we observe her isolated inside a starkly furnished room.  She is trapped inside the walls, inside her mind, possibly by old memories and habits or society.  She looks out the window and visualizes the freedom and endless possibilities that the outdoors have to offer.  Does she follow her vision of freedom?  Or does she remain confined behind closed doors?  


Named “best in dance” 2011 by Sarah Kaufman of the Washington Post, Karen Reedy Dance (KRD) is a professional modern dance company located in the Washington DC Metro Area. Devoted to nurturing artists through the exploration of new work and collaboration with other art forms, KRD performs in both traditional and site-specific venues.  This project marks Reedy’s first venture into the genre of dance for film, after years of interest in creating movement specifically for the unique perspective of the camera.  She was granted the Mathy Junior Faculty Award from the George Mason University College of Humanities and Social Sciences for this project.  Additionally, KRD received a project grant (requiring matching funds) from The Alexandria Commission for the Arts specifically for this film.  


Please help us to fully realize this project.  We are seeking funds to take the film from our raw footage, to the editing room and theaters!
   
What We Need & What You Get
We are half way to making our dreams come true! In September, the film cast/crew was in residence in Derby, NY where we shot all of the footage for the film.  Now, we need your support as we head into the post-production stages of the project.  During the fall and winter 2014-2015, the film must come together through editing, music composition and marketing.  We have the raw footage…now we need to turn this dream into a reality.  
We want you to be a part of this exciting process with us.  As a supporter of the film, you will receive rewards such as: updates from Reedy as the film moves through post-production, a copy of the DVD, invitations to preview screenings and VIP tickets to concerts and open rehearsals.  You may even see your name in the credits as an Associate Producer!!! Join us!
If we exceed our goal (yes please!!), the additional funding will directly support the artists and production expenses for the Karen Reedy Dance 2014-2015 performance season!  Performances include site-specific works throughout Alexandria and a weekend of performances at Dance Place April 11 and 12, 2015.  For this concert, we are thrilled to be hosting Project. B. from San Francisco.  This is the second half of our SWAP program…KRD shared the stage with Project. B. in San Francisco in 2013.  Please visit www.reedydance.org for more information about our upcoming season.

  Meet Our Team

Karen Reedy (Director and Choreographer) is a choreographer, dancer and dance educator.  She has performed with D.C. Dance Theater, Eric Hampton Dance, Robert Battle, Sue Bernhard, Louis Johnson, Patricia Kenny, and the Mark Morris Dance Group.  Her work has been performed throughout the country, in venues including The Kennedy Center, Dance Place, ODC, ADI, Black Rock Arts Center, The 92nd Street Y, The Torpedo Factory and Joyce SoHo.  Ms. Reedy has been a recipient of the Kennedy Center Millennium Stage Local Dance Commissioning Grant, selected as a Metro Arts Incubator Artist at the American Dance Institute, and a Mathy Junior Faculty Award winner.  She has been on the faculty of the Juilliard School, the Mark Morris Dance Center and the Chautauqua Institution.  Ms. Reedy holds an M.F.A in Dance from George Mason University, where she is an Assistant Professor of Dance.  
 

Helen Hansen French (Dancer) received her B.F.A from The Juilliard School in 2001 under the direction of Benjamin Harkarvy. She joined Buglisi Dance Theatre upon graduating  and toured nationally and internationally as a principal dancer. Mrs. French is instrumental in re-staging BDT’s works on professional companies as well as colleges through out the United States. Her choreography has been shown at Studio@620, Kaatsbaan, and St. Petersburg College.  As a teacher of both dance and The Alexander Technique she has been on faculty at The Juilliard School, The Neighborhood Playhouse, George Mason University, and St. Petersburg College.  Helen joined Karen Reedy Dance in 2011. 


Ludovic Jolivet (Director of Photography), a native of Paris, France, is a choreographer, filmmaker, and dancer. He received his BFA in dance from the Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, and his MFA in choreography from the University of Maryland. Mr. Jolivet has created and directed dances for film that have been presented at venues and dance festivals worldwide; his choreography for stage has traveled the US and Europe. Awards for his works include the 2013 Maryland State Arts Council’s Individual Artist Award in choreography, the 2004 Maryland State Arts Council’s Individual Artist Award in Film and the 2003 Metro DC Dance Award for Emerging Choreographer; in 2006, his work was commissioned by the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Mr. Jolivet has taught dance and theatre courses at universities in the DC area and St Mary’s County. He has participated in four international 48-hour film festival projects, one of which won the Best Choreography award in 2006. He is currently teaching New Media and Dance for the MFA program at The George Washington University, and continuing his exploration of dance/choreography for both stage and film.

Yao Chen (Costume Designer) designs costumes for theatre, dance and film.  Most recently, she wrapped up her first international production Amadues in Teatro Espressivo in San Jose, Costa Rica. She is now designing a lovely children's show in Orlando Repertory Theatre that opens in March 2015. She designed Ti Jean and His Brothers and Rinoceros for University of South Florida from 2013 to 2014. In 2011 she won the Austin Critics Table Award for outstanding costume design for the production of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde at the University of Texas at Austin and she worked in Zach Sco

Carl Landa (Composer)  is currently the Music Director of the Dance Department at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, NY.  He plays piano, percussion, synthesizers and laptops.  Carl composes original scores for dance, videos, and audio books.




Lauren Burke (Sound Technician and Promotional Filmmaker) is a multimedia artist and professional video maker.

The Impact

Performance for the stage and the screen are very different mediums. Ms. Reedy is excited to explore the new challenges that choreographing for film has to offer.   She chose to work with Ludovic Jolivet as the Director of Photography for this project due to his experience in dance film, as well as his complimentary aesthetic.  When the project is complete, the film will be shown in concert with KRD as well as submitted to local, national and international  film festivals around the world!


Other Ways You Can Help 

Please join us for this campaign!  No amount is too small to help support this project.  
Can’t contribute money, but would like to help?  Please share this campaign with others and help us get the word out!!

story:
About Bad Habit Productions

Bad Habit Productions, Inc. is a 501(c)3 non-profit theatre dedicated to creating dynamic, innovative productions. We celebrate literary merit, examine human nature, and explore imaginative design. BHP is committed to providing audiences with high-quality, professional theatre experiences that are accessible and affordable.  We foster new talent in the Boston theatre scene, thereby encouraging a vibrant, connected environment for artists while enriching the Boston arts community.

What We Need & What You Get

Ticket sales comprise only a small portion of the funding we need to support the work we bring to you each season.  This campaign will help us produce the work we care about, and will allow us to continue to expand our programming to include theatre for all ages! 

Check out the perks!  Depending on how much you choose to give, you could be one of the first to know what's coming up in Season 8!  Signed posters, tickets to our productions, and endless love on Facebook; we've got a lot to offer you in return for your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with other theatre-lovers in your circle!  It's only $8.

story: Hello my name is Kelly Daniels and together with my husband we built the Grand View Drive-In Theater in May of 2007.  Together with our families we run the theater 6 months a year and enjoy it very much, but we need your help.  We are facing permanent closure if we don't convert to digital.  We are a small community and closing would be devastating to the community because it is one of the only activities to do in the area.  Please help us raise 75K so that we may stay in business and continue showing those great movies that bring families together all night long during the summer.  Thank you for your help in considering us for you gracious donations and please stop by next time you are around Grandview, IA.

story:
__________________________________________________

WHAT'S THE STORY?

Albert Cobb was going to be a farmer, so his Army buddies called him “Plowboy”. One buddy, Larry Doyle now dying, has come for a last visit hoping to content himself that he did one good deed: saving Albert's life during a wartime scrimmage. He finds a man who has failed at farming and everything else, including marriage. With a disabled child, deceived by his wife and his own beliefs, Albert's attempts to deceive Larry only make the deception more evident, leaving him alone with his own self-delusions. By the author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play The Subject Was Roses. 


ABOUT THE PLAYWRIGHT

Frank Daniel Gilroy is an award-winning playwright, producer, screenwriter and director. After graduating from Dartmouth College and the Yale School of Drama, he contributed profusely as a writer to the golden age of television. His impressive first play, Who'll Save the Plowboy?, won an Obie Award in 1962. In 1965, his Off Broadway play The Subject Was Roses won the Tony Award for Best Play, the Obie Award, and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama, and reached the Broadway stage two years later. That Summer, That Fall, an adaptation of the Hippolytus-Phaedra story, premiered to positive reviews in 1967. In the 1970's Mr. Gilroy moved onto films, directing such successes as Desperate Characters, From Noon Till Three, and The Luckiest Man in the World. Mr. Gilroy and his wife Ruth Dorothy Gaydos have three sons.

__________________________________________________

WHY WE NEED FUNDS TO MAKE IT HAPPEN

We’ve assembled a team of artists and designers to bring Gilroy's work to the stage for the first time since 1962. Ultimately we want to stage Who'll Save the Plowboy? in a intimate setting just like it was performed Off Broadway 50 years ago with the audience following Albert and Larry's journey of discovery.  We have over 50% of the funding raised and for the rest, we need your help to save the plowboy.

We would love for you to become a part of this theatrical experience by generously helping to support the following:

  • Four weeks of rehearsal space and three-week theatre rental
  • Technical equipment rentals
  • Set, costume, and other design materials
  • Stipends for our creative artists (actors, designers)
  • Insurance costs
  • Publicity and outreach to the community

Our production of Who’ll Save the Plowboy? will be performed for three (3) weeks from November 4 – 22, 2015 in the Black Box at the Davenport Theatre. Housed in a remodeled firehouse conveniently located in the heart of Manhattan’s theatre district, the Davenport Theatre offers two unique and fully equipped performance spaces. The Main Stage Theatre is the only jewel box in midtown with a seating capacity of 149, while the Black Box upstairs offers a more intimate experience. The theatre owner, Ken Davenport, is an active and successful theatre producer on Broadway. The Black Box features plush fixed seating for sixty (60) audience members as well as heat and air conditioning. Located on the upper level of the Davenport Theatre complex, the Black Box is accessible by elevator and stairs, and offers an intimate theatre experience with lobby space, where we look forward to greeting our supporters on Opening Night!

__________________________________________________

MEET THE ARTISTS

THE CAST OF WHO'll SAVE THE PLOWBOY?

OUR CORE PRODUCTION TEAM

Marcia Haufrecht (Director) graduated from Performing Arts High School as a dancer and got her first job on Broadway in Plain and Fancy, followed by a national tour with Can Can. As an actress she has appeared on Broadway, off, and off-off Broadway, as well as on television and film, in roles ranging from Tondeleyo in White Cargo, to Queen Elizabeth opposite Al Pacino in Richard III. For three years (2006-2008) she has directed extremely successful productions in Lisbon, Portugal, of “Collected Stories” at the Communa Theatre, and at The National Theatre “Frozen”, and the Portuguese premiere of Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt’s “Oscar & The Lady In Pink”. She was a student of Lee Strasberg’s and subsequently a teacher at The Lee Strasberg Theatre Institute (including NYU courses) for five years. She also worked as an adjunct professor in the film graduate program at Columbia University for 2 years. She has taught and coached privately for over thirty years. Her students include Ellen Barkin, Alec Baldwin, Janine Turner, Debbie Mazur, Loren Dean, David Duchovney, Uma Thurman, John Leguizamo. Most recently she coached Harvey Keitel. She has taught, and continues to teach in Australia, Austria and Portugal, and currently is retired as a professor of acting at The New School University in the MFA drama school. She is a long-standing member of The Actors Studio, Ensemble Studio Theatre and Founder and Artistic Director of The Common Basis Theatre.

Jerry Rago (Executive Producer) is the driving force behind this production and will be playing the role of ‘Albert Cobb’ in Who’ll Save the Plowboy. He’s a former semi-professional baseball player in the Tigers Organization turned professional actor. He trained at the Terry Schreiber Studio, the American Musical & Dramatic Academy, and the London Academy of Music & Dramatic Arts, among private tutelage from distinguished artists. Theatre work has included many productions in London, New York City, and regionally around the U.S. Favorite roles include Bottom in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Lopakhin in The Cherry Orchard, Ted in Barking Sharks and Cornelius in Hello Dolly. Jerry has also worked in films, most recently playing principal roles in three independent feature films.

Lauren Rayner (Producer / General Manager) is an independent freelance producer and has masterminded over 75 stage, film and multi-media projects since 2005. Favorite producing credits include Take Me Home, the show in a taxi (dir: Meghan Finn, extended by 3LD & popular demand), Radiant Baby (Joe’s Pub at the Public), A Food Odyssey (The Invisible Dog, dir: Pirronne Yousefzadeh); My Machine is Powered by Clocks (New Ohio's Ice Factory), Madame Infamy (New York Musical Theatre Festival, Alice Griffin Jewel Box Theatre at Signature), disOriented (dir: Carlos Armesto; Peter Jay Sharp Theater), Binding (Theatre C, extended by PS 122 & winner of 3 NY Innovative Theatre Awards), One Arm and A Leg (dir: Calla Videt; Theater for the New City & HERE), Daughters of Lot (Edinburgh Festival Fringe). She holds a BA in Theatre & Education from the University of Southern California. For more, visit Lauren Rayner Productions { LRP } at laurenrayner.com

__________________________________________________

WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP

Our goal is to raise $8,230 by the time we start rehearsals in September. Please give whatever you can: anything and everything will help us on this journey! Your contribution will be tax-deductible. Check out all of the perks to see how you can be involved in the process with sneak-peeks along the way!

Hear from our director, Maria Haufretch about why it's important to support independent theatre in New York City:


__________________________________________________

RISKS, CHALLENGES & POTENTIALS

Who’ll Save the Plowboy? has not been produced in New York since its Obie Award-winning run in 1962. We believe that now is the perfect time to resurrect this long-forgotten play by an important American playwright. Frank D. Gilroy, now in his nineties, has personally given his express permission to Jerry Rago to present this play in New York City in the Fall of 2015. The licensing rights have been secured and are provided by Samuel French Inc. 

The budget has been determined by the Producer under careful consideration of the Production Company’s access to discounted resources in the industry and a detailed breakdown of the play. This play will be produced under the Actors’ Equity Association’s NYC Showcase Code. Should production fund donations exceed our expectations, the Producer would raise the budget line items for production materials, adding a week of theatre rental, additional skilled production crew, and increased marketing and advertising costs. The run of the play will take place over three weeks in a Manhattan venue with 60 seats over fifteen performances. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Just because you may not be able to contribute doesn’t mean you lose your chance to help make this project happen!

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to make it super easy.
  • Post this campaign link to your Facebook profile or Twitter feed
  • Tell people how much you want to see this show come to New York and pass this onto your fancy friends with deep pockets!

story:
SexBombe Kabaret is a Nouveau Weimar Kabaret Experience and we are Invading DustFish at Burning Man this year! 

SexBombe Kabaret first premiered in October of 2012 at Masquerotica in San Francisco as a late night uber sexy Variety Show. In February of 2013 we decided to change the game a bit and came up with a scripted version of the show and took it to the Night Light in Oakland, CA. Thanks to our stellar cast and our fabulous fans it was completely sold out and a HUGE hit! Since then we have been working hard on the re-writes and fixes to smooth the show out. Due to the constant buzz around town about when the next show is, we have decided to take a break from the main project in order to bring our love of 1920s Weimar Culture, Bob Fosse, Theater, Vaudeville and  the complete and utterly absurd to our favorite Burning Man camp right on the Esplanade, DUSTFISH!

SexBombe Kabaret is a full length Theater Style Audience Immersed Variety show. The Cast is an eclectic group comprised of some of San Francisco's BEST Talent INCLUDING members of Vau de Vire Society, Hubba Hubba Revue, Fou Fou Ha & Trapeze. We are also excited to be able to feature Guest Artists from Portland and Denver this time around. During the show we will take you on an adventure into the Weimar Berlin Culture on a journey of a WWI fighter pilot that is dying to, well, "run away with the Kabaret"! Along the way we meet the Kabaret performers one by one in a evening of filth, jealousy & promiscuity.

The SexBombe Kabaret cast/band/crew has grown to over 20 hard working artists and we need funding for help with the following:

* Costuming (wigs, thigh highs, shoes, etc.....)

* Props (supplies to build, chairs, etc.....)

* GIANT "SexBombe Kabaret" Sign

* VIP Perks (Champagne, horderves, etc....)

VIP Treatment on the Playa!

As part of the Immersive Audience experience we will have 4 VIP seats at the show on the playa! VIP Treatment includes the following:

* Table and Chair with Premium Table Cloth!

* Bottle of Champagne!

* Horderves Playa Style!

* Your very own Bar Wench!

* Cast Members IN YOUR FACE!

Please "LIKE" our Facebook Page!

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sex-Bombe-Kabaret/339885119451131?fref=ts

Long Term Goal?

SexBombe Kabaret's long term goal is to do several runs of the Scripted Show AS WELL AS continue to do Variety Show versions in the San Francisco Bay Area. This means that all props, costumes, set pieces, etc WILL be used again and again!!!! 

Who are the Producers?

SexBombe Kabaret is brought to you by Mz.K & Theater MadCap! To find out more about us please take a second to check out the links below:

Mz. K : http://kirstenegerding.com/

Theater MadCap : https://www.facebook.com/theatermadcap?fref=ts

Other Ways YOU Can Help Our Campaign?

SexBombe Kabaret is grateful for any and all help. Whether you donate $1, $5, $10....$50....$100..... We are grateful for ALL HELP! Another way YOU can help is by getting the word out there for us. Please "Share" this campaign with your friends and on your Facebook wall. Another HUGE help is to go to our Facebook Page and "LIKE" us!

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sex-Bombe-Kabare...

We love all of our fans and are extremely appreciative for word of mouth promotions!!!!! Don't forget to use the Indigogo Share tool!

DON'T MISS THE SHOW at Burning Man!!!!

SexBombe Kabaret will be 6-9pm, Thursday August 29th on the playa at DUSTFISH! Remember, this is a "theater style" show so feel free to bring your chairs & get comfy for the ride!

DUSTFISH is at 8 o'clock & Esplanade!!!!!

http://playaevents.burningman.com/2013/playa_ev...
story_txt:
SexBombe Kabaret is a Nouveau Weimar Kabaret Experience and we are Invading DustFish at Burning Man this year! 
SexBombe Kabaret first premiered in October of 2012 at Masquerotica in San Francisco as a late night uber sexy Variety Show. In February of 2013 we decided to change the game a bit and came up with a scripted version of the show and took it to the Night Light in Oakland, CA. Thanks to our stellar cast and our fabulous fans it was completely sold out and a HUGE hit! Since then we have been working hard on the re-writes and fixes to smooth the show out. Due to the constant buzz around town about when the next show is, we have decided to take a break from the main project in order to bring our love of 1920s Weimar Culture, Bob Fosse, Theater, Vaudeville and  the complete and utterly absurd to our favorite Burning Man camp right on the Esplanade, DUSTFISH!
SexBombe Kabaret is a full length Theater Style Audience Immersed Variety show. The Cast is an eclectic group comprised of some of San Francisco's BEST Talent INCLUDING members of Vau de Vire Society, Hubba Hubba Revue, Fou Fou Ha & Trapeze. We are also excited to be able to feature Guest Artists from Portland and Denver this time around. During the show we will take you on an adventure into the Weimar Berlin Culture on a journey of a WWI fighter pilot that is dying to, well, "run away with the Kabaret"! Along the way we meet the Kabaret performers one by one in a evening of filth, jealousy & promiscuity.
The SexBombe Kabaret cast/band/crew has grown to over 20 hard working artists and we need funding for help with the following:
* Costuming (wigs, thigh highs, shoes, etc.....)
* Props (supplies to build, chairs, etc.....)
* GIANT "SexBombe Kabaret" Sign
* VIP Perks (Champagne, horderves, etc....)
VIP Treatment on the Playa!
As part of the Immersive Audience experience we will have 4 VIP seats at the show on the playa! VIP Treatment includes the following:
* Table and Chair with Premium Table Cloth!
* Bottle of Champagne!
* Horderves Playa Style!
* Your very own Bar Wench!
* Cast Members IN YOUR FACE!
Please "LIKE" our Facebook Page!
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sex-Bombe-Kabaret/339885119451131?fref=ts

story:
Ryan Li

     Ryan Li is a 7 year old girl, who recently discovered that dancing is more than wearing a pink tutu and floating around a room like a fairy. As a matter of fact, it was as recent as yesterday! Moments after walking off stage of her 2nd Spring Recital, she walked up to me and said, "Mommy, I reeeeeeally want to go to dance camp -I can do this." Although it made me beam, that she had finally found something she was passionate about- AND extremely good at, I almost instantly thought about having just spent well over a thousand dollars on her 2013-2014 tuition for only 2 hours a week, and over $400 on costumes, shoes, uniforms and recital fees! Not the best first thought ever- after watching your 7 year old  transform into a completely different person and own the stage! But hey!- It was reality. So I told her we'd think about it. As we were about to walk out of the door, the owner of the studio, pulls away from her conversation and  stops me to say..."This one has potential, I've peeked in her classes from time to time, and have told her teacher that Ryan is one to watch."

       -Wait! Does the OWNER of these 3, very heavily populated, dance schools  know my daughter's name?

She continued, "We need to get her in company. I have every confidence that she can do it."

        Immediately, it felt like I had received my confirmation.  After all, we ALL know that nothing great comes without sacrifice and hard work, so we'd just have to make it happen.

     With your help, I am sure that we will be on the path of saving the arts by creating an AMAZING cultivator to stand guard at its door. Not to mention- affording a little girl the opportunity to develop discipline, and honor commitment through the expression of dance. 

What You Can Do

With your help, we need to raise $1,000 for Ryan to attend 10 weeks of Dance Camp at the Academy of The Arts, for 8 hours a day!

Ryan will receive:

  • Training in multiple disciplines (Ballet, Jazz, Tap, and Modern)
  • Training in tumbling, acting, and performance basics.
  • The experience of a lifetime!

The Impact

For your generous donation, you will receive one of 3 Thank You Packages.

The "Practice Makes Perfect", the "A Star Is Born" and the "Encore" 

The Impact of your donation extends beyond anything that even I can fathom. Because what kind of world would we live in without the arts? Not any world I'd care to be a part of! Your investment in the future of performing arts today, will resound in the years to come!

If we do not reach our fundraising goals, the funds will still go towards Summer Dance Lessons, but if we exceed it, it will also be put towards Ryan's 2014- 2015 tuition.

Every little bit helps! Even if you are unable to make a monetary contribution,, please pass  this along to someone who may be interested.

After all," It Takes A Village..."

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
The Deal

Dell'Arte's Joan Schirle and Matt Chapman met Lloyd Nyikadzino at the Theatre Communications Group annual conference in June 2011 in Chicago.  Lloyd was among a group of artists from around the world invited by TCG; his attendance was facilitated by the United States Public Affairs Office in Zimbabwe.  Lloyd is recognized as an emerging leader in the field in his home city of Harare; he is a performer, writer, director, and the Founder and Director of African Youth Arts Project (AYAP), one of Harare's leading youth arts based organizations.


After meeting Dell'Arte faculty in Chicago, Lloyd learned more about the school, has applied and been accepted.  He is hungry to study the work of the devising actor- the work of the actor/creator- here at Dell'Arte International in Blue Lake, CA.  He wants to bring the perspective he will gain here back to his community.


We are waiving his tuition.  What we need are funds for his travel, housing, and food for the year. 

What We Need

As we mentioned, we are waiving Lloyd's tuition.  That's $12,500 for nine months of full-time training.

We are looking for another $12,500.

This includes: $3500 for travel expenses, $8000 for housing (and deposit), food, etc., and $1000 in case of emergency.

Every small donation is extremely helpful! 

$10, $20, $50, $100...  we can do this!

If by chance we raise more money than we're looking for (through this and other fundraising efforts, including Lloyd's own efforts in Harare), or if the amount he needs in the end is less than we projected (cheaper travel, etc.), the remainder will go into the Carlo Mazzone-Clementi fund (named after our founder), which provides scholarship opportunities for foreign students in need (similarly, if something unforseen happens to prevent Lloyd's departure from Zimbabwe, the money will all be donated to this fund for future ranks of theatre artists).

Words From Lloyd

"Coming from a background of a deteriorating arts industry in Zimbabwe, I believe I can make a contribution to the process of reviving the sector through the knowledge that I would have get from the training [at Dell'Arte], thereby complementing the efforts of development workers in the sector. The program will also facilitate a transformational phase in my career which is much needed for both personal and community development.

I would want to explore diverse approaches that will help break down artificial socio-economic and political boundaries using the approaches of physical theatre. Zimbabwe has few if not no practitioners that are practising physical theatre as actors, designer, directors and even writers. This gives me the desire to represent the youths in as far as their potential and capacity is concerned, having experienced this challenge in my country.

The other major challenge is that they are few theatre institutions and are not even regarded as educational institution in Zimbabwe.

Accomplishment of the programme will definitely transform me into an asset in improving the lives of marginalized youths through theatre. This gives me the desire to represent the youths and to assist in setting new trends for them."

Other Ways You Can Help 

Post the link to this page on Facebook!  Send it around to your contacts!  Thanks to everyone for supporting this partnership!

story:
Hell on Earth in New York City

This April, Broken Glass presents INFERNO, an all-new adaptation of Dante's Inferno. Our original production, written and directed by Artistic Director Kate Moran, sets the scene in what appears to be modern-day New York City. As Dante, a foreigner, makes his way across a bizarro urban landscape with the help of his hipster guide Virgil, it is slowly revealed that not everything is as it seems. Over the course of 24 hours, Dante and Virgil encounter dozens of the peculiar creatures that populate this nightmarish city and eventually come face to face with Lucifer herself.

INFERNO will be very rewarding for fans of the classic poem on which the play is based. Whole scenes and characters are transplanted directly to the stage with a unique, very American twist. Those unfamiliar with The Divine Comedy will find a play that, like Dante's original, is a political satire that calls out specific, recognizable individuals and assigns them a grotesque punishment in their own circle of hell.

INFERNO opens April 21st at the Under St. Marks Theater.

Starring:
Robbie Baum, Danielle Devine, Sarah Knittel, Whit Leyenberger, Kamelle Mills, Clint Okayama, Nicole Roberts, Christina Stone, Terence Stone and Marchelle Thurman.

Where Your Money Goes

$10 = 1 hour of rehearsal space
$25 = Fireguard license
$50 = 2 gallons of stage blood
$75 = 100 programs
$100 = 5 of the 50+ costume pieces that we need
$150 = A/V equipment
$200 = 100 posters
$250 = Theatre rental for dress rehearsal
$500 = 1/3 of our total theatre rental costs for performances


Who is BROKEN GLASS?

BROKEN GLASS is a company of collaborative theatre artists. Using classic texts as our inspiration, we seek to create new and original works that address and illuminate today's pressing sociopolitical issues. Our goal is to provide audiences with an extremely relevant theatre experience. We believe that our work is only as good as the conversation it provokes.

In 2011, we are working on three major projects: 

First, we present INFERNO, a retelling of the immortal epic The Divine Comedy by Dante Alighieri. The world premiere of this original play, written and directed by Artistic Director Kate Moran, opens April 21st at The Under St. Mark's Theater. INFERNO brings hell to earth - specifically, New York City, or at least, a place very similar. 

Up next is ANN, OR OTHER PEOPLE, a new exciting work by Jonathan Mayer, directed by Production Director Taylor Tobin. This cunning and satirical play provides a glimpse into the world of everyone's favorite political pundit, Ann Coulter. ANN, OR OTHER PEOPLE has been submitted to the 2011 FringeNYC Festival and is set to open in July 2011. 

 Finally, we bring our season to a close with a new adaptation of William Shakespeare's CYMBELINE, directed by Executive Director Nathan Zebedeo, scheduled to perform in August 2011. A play of coincidence and chance, CYMBELINE looks for miraculous good fortune in the wake of tragic bad luck.

story:
WAITING FOR WAITING FOR GODOT

A Comedy by Dave Hanson

Hansburg Productions and our friends at The Collective NY are thrilled to present the world premiere of WAITING FOR WAITING FOR GODOT at the 17th Annual New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) this August. 

In WAITING FOR WAITING FOR GODOT, two understudies stuck in backstage limbo grapple with art, life, the “biz,” and their absurd existence.  

Broadway’s Chris Sullivan (Nice Work If You Can Get It, Chicago The Musical, Lombardi), Dave Hanson (Chelsea Lately, Off-Broadway’s The Boss), and Amy Weaver (NBC’s The Office, Riverdance) star in this sharp new comedy written by Dave Hanson and helmed by renowned director Alex Harvey (Balm in Gilead, O Lovely Glowworm).

FringeNYC brings together over 190 productions from around the globe in a celebration of new works, and we are honored to be part of such a collaborative effort. Our FringeNYC premiere is only the beginning for this play, and we hope to stand out as a Broadway-caliber production on a black box budget.  

To do that... we need YOU.

WHAT FringeNYC PROVIDES:

As a participant of FringeNYC, we are generously provided a venue, ticket distribution, and a small percentage of final ticket sales. The rest is up to us!  
 

WHAT YOUR DONATIONS PROVIDE:

Rehearsal Space
Insurance Fees
Costumes, Set & Props
Marketing & Advertisement (Postcards, Posters, Publicity)
Production & Design Fees
Graphics & Video Design
Food & Drink for Volunteers
Printing & Mailings 
 

YOUR IMPACT:

By visiting this fundraising site, making a donation, or spreading the word of our campaign, you are helping us bring WAITING FOR WAITING FOR GODOT to FringeNYC to perform among hundreds of fascinating artists from around the world. Every pledge assists us with covering production costs so we can stand out in this festival and grow a following for future stages.
 

WHAT WE GIVE BACK: 

*$25 pledge will get a SIGNED POSTCARD BY THE PLAYWRIGHT
*$50 pledge will get a SIGNED POSTER BY THE ACTORS
*$100 pledge will get a SIGNED COPY OF THE SCRIPT BY THE PLAYWRIGHT
*$500+ pledge will get an ASSOCIATE PRODUCER CREDIT ON OUR SITE & SIGNED COPY OF THE SCRIPT BY THE PLAYWRIGHT
 
 
Thank you for your support and for being a part of our journey. We'll see you in a theater seat soon! 
 
 
-Hillary Burgess, Victoria Dicce, Dave Hanson, Chris Sullivan & Amy Weaver

 

Please visit our website for more details: www.wfwfgodot.com

story:
Update

The research is well underway thanks to our Indiegogo donors and other supporters! To make additional contributions or to learn more about the latest research and events, please visit us at: www.act-sf.org/wlp

Thank you for joining us on this journey towards a more equitable future for the arts!

Above video: Professional theater artists, administrators, students, and scholars discuss what obstacles might be keeping more women from reaching leadership positions in the American theater.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Women’s Leadership Project

American Conservatory Theater and the Wellesley Centers for Women are launching a research study into the gender equity of leadership opportunities in the nonprofit American theater.

Women currently hold 19% of artistic director positions, and have never held more than 27% of leadership positions in American nonprofit theater. Why? In a field in which “representation” is important to the stories we present to the public, the persistent underrepresentation of female leadership is puzzling and problematic.

This project has grown out of our recognition that while A.C.T. has two women in leadership positions, this is the exception and not the norm. We have become increasingly concerned that there are not enough women poised to take up the reins, and that there is no data to explain why. Using the theater field as a starting point, this project will explore what can be done to increase the participation of women at the higher reaches of the arts in America.

The Research

Guided by A.C.T. Artistic Director Carey Perloff and Executive Director Ellen Richard, WCW’s Associate Director and Senior Research Scientist, Sumru Erkut, will lead an experienced research team in this investigation through a study model designed to answer two research questions:

  1. Why are there so few women in artistic and executive director positions?
  2. What can be done to achieve greater diversity in theater leadership? 

Searching for answers to these questions will require an examination of the career development of women in theater and also the institutional factors related to how searches for leadership are conducted and finalized. This research will lead us to identify the ways in which artistic and executive directors are currently being selected, and will point to recommendations of how candidate evaluations could change to make the selection more gender balanced.

The Convening

Once the study has been released, we will reach out to organizations both in and out of the theater field to help us disseminate our findings to further the conversation. We are engaged in discussions with HowlRound Center for Theater Commons, a national online community based at Emerson Arts in Boston, as well as Mills College, a prominent women’s institution in the Bay Area, to host one or more convenings as the capstone of the research to share our study findings and facilitate a dialogue about this issue with a diverse group of academic, artistic, and policy leaders.

The hope is to address infrastructure problems such that the pipeline for leadership talent is more open, inclusive, and representative of the field.

The Impact

The performing arts enhance how we view ourselves and our place in the world by giving voice and shape to diverse experiences, feelings, actions, and thoughts. Promoting women’s leadership in the arts will make the field more inclusive of diverse talents, broadening our overall vision.

This project will be valuable to the entire arts field by providing real data about female leaders and a clearer understanding of career development. We envision an arts field with leadership that is truly representative of the diverse perspectives of those who participate at every level.

Where You Come In

Your support will enable the critical next steps to start the research and launch this project. We will be holding performances, talks, and parties exclusively for our supporters.

Above video: Professional theater artists, administrators,
students, and scholars discuss what obstacles might be keeping more women from
reaching leadership positions in the American theater.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Women’s Leadership
Project
American Conservatory
Theater and the Wellesley Centers for Women are launching a research study into
the gender equity of leadership opportunities in the nonprofit American
theater. 
Women currently hold 19%
of artistic director positions, and have never held more than 27% of leadership
positions in American nonprofit theater. Why? In a field in which
“representation” is important to the stories we present to the public, the
persistent underrepresentation of female leadership is puzzling and
problematic. 
This project has grown
out of our recognition that while A.C.T. has two women in leadership positions,
this is the exception and not the norm. We have become increasingly concerned
that there are not enough women poised to take up the reins, and that there is no data to
explain why. Using the theater field as a starting point, this project will
explore what can be done to increase the participation of women at the higher
reaches of the arts in America.
The ResearchGuided by A.C.T. Artistic
Director Carey Perloff and Executive Director Ellen Richard, WCW’s Associate
Director and Senior Research Scientist, Sumru Erkut, will lead an experienced
research team in this investigation through a study model designed to answer
two research questions:
Why are there so few women in artistic and executive director
positions?
What can be done to achieve greater diversity in theater
leadership? 
Searching for answers to
these questions will require an examination of the career development of women
in theater and also the institutional factors related to how searches for
leadership are conducted and finalized. This research will lead us to
identify the ways in which artistic and executive directors are currently being
selected, and will point to recommendations of how candidate evaluations could
change to make the selection more gender balanced.
The Convening
Once the study has been
released, we will reach out to organizations both in and out of the theater
field to help us disseminate our findings to further the conversation. We are
engaged in discussions with HowlRound Center for Theater Commons, a national
online community based at Emerson Arts in Boston, as well as Mills College, a
prominent women’s institution in the Bay Area, to host one or more convenings
as the capstone of the research to share our study findings and facilitate a
dialogue about this issue with a diverse group of academic, artistic, and
policy leaders. 
The hope is to address
infrastructure problems such that the pipeline for leadership talent is more
open, inclusive, and representative of the field.
The Impact
The
performing arts enhance how we view ourselves and our place in the world by
giving voice and shape to diverse experiences, feelings, actions, and thoughts.
Promoting women’s leadership in the arts will make the field more inclusive of
diverse talents, broadening our overall vision.
This project will be valuable
to the entire arts field by providing real data about female leaders and a
clearer understanding of career development. We envision an arts field with
leadership that is truly representative of the diverse perspectives of those
who participate at every level.
Where You Come In
Your support will enable the
critical next steps to start the research and launch this project. We will be
holding performances, talks, and parties exclusively for our supporters.

story:
MEDIA


TV3 Firstline: 'Kiwi scores 'rugged' ballet scholarship' ... view

 Kiwiblog: 'Help a young kiwi reach the top' .... view

 Greatfun4kids: 'Billy Elliot, Eat Your Heart Out' .... view

Rogue Ballerina: 'Dancer Fundraising to get from NZ to CA' .... view

The Western Leader:  'Destiny meeting' sees Joel dance at the top'  .... view

 

I am Joel Walsham, a young New Zealander who has been accepted into the LINES Ballet/Dominican University of California Bachelor of Fine Arts (Dance) program. 

I was also offered admission to New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts and The Ailey School/Fordham University. These programs are unlike anything that can be offered in New Zealand, or elsewhere in the southern hemisphere.

 I have chosen to attend LINES and I need your help to get there. 

The Bachelor of Fine Arts (Dance) is a joint program of the LINES Ballet and the Dominican University of California. This program is four years to complete, producing dancers who are training in a facility that also houses the LINES Ballet Company. LINES believe in training dancers who are instinctual, and who are artists in their own right. With its direct relationship to Alonzo King, one of the foremost choreographers of our time, the program offers students unique access to the process and environment in which current dance thought and practice is being shaped.

Based on a conservatory style training, it is creating not just excellent technicians, but thinking artists, that can advocate for the arts and become warriors for its progress. LINES in the only program of its kind and one of the best schools in the world, at what it does. They are producing cutting edge performers that become leaders who are shaping the dance industry. No New Zealander has ever been accepted into this program. In fact, there are no international students currently in the Bachelor Fine Arts program. 

Visit joelwalsham.com and share this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

-----------------

The Cost

My parents have saved for my tertiary education from my birth, however they did not anticipate that I would be attending an American University. Despite their foresight, I am now facing the considerably higher costs of an American University. Over the four years, the total costs are around US$240,000.

Annual Cost of Attendance (US$) :

Tuition $40,150

Fees (Campus Comp/Activity)$450

Room and Board$13,380

Medical Insurance$3,800

Books/Supplies$1,710

Transportation$892

Personal Expenses$ 2,278

Total Budget $63,160

 

I have been the recipient of the Dominican University of California Presidential Scholarship, which is worth US$17,000 each year. This is the higher than the maximum amount that the University will give to an international student. I am extremely grateful, but there is still a large funding gap. 

I am hoping to raise $20,000 which would mean that my first year of tuition would be almost covered, so that my family can have some more time to save for the future years. 

My family has financed my dancing since I was born and made a significant investment in my dancing.  

Your support would mean that I can live out this opportunity, which has been 15 years in the making.

story:
UPDATE: We have received $2,500 from the very generous Minor Critics, which is not reflected on this page. This means we have less than $800 to go to reach our goal, as of 1pm on our last day!! Can you help us get there??


“Look closely at the present you are constructing: 
it should look like the future you are dreaming.” 
Alice Walker
 

WHAT IS THE SHAKESPEARE FORUM?

 The Shakespeare Forum is a home for students, actors, directors and lovers of Shakespeare to play, share, develop, and flourish. The Shakespeare Forum believes in reaching out and building community through education, outreach and performance with an emphasis on providing low-cost, high-quality classes, workshops and productions. 

The Shakespeare Forum is dedicated to providing services to all members of our New York community and we believe that financial constraints should not prohibit members from gaining the tools and confidence to make their way in New York, both as conscious artists and as parts of a greater artistic alliance.

THE PAST- WHAT WE CONSTRUCTED:

5 years ago, we didn't have a dream. We simply had an idea, a small downtown loft space and a handful of brave NYC actors who dared to climb the endless stairs in a dingy building to reach an unknown destination labeled "The Shakespeare Forum". 

Over the past 5 years we have, with the incredible support of The Shakespeare Forum community, developed into a company which has:

  • Offered 400+ free/ donation-based workshops hours to actors and artists in NYC
  • Donated 100+ free workshops hours to Public Schools in NYC
  • Developed 3 semester-long school residencies in Queens and East Harlem (The Merete Baird and Carolyn and Stanley Bauer Scholarship Funds)
  • Produced 4 Equity Showcase productions, offered at a low cost to the audience
  • Determined that cost should never be a barrier to education and therefore created a scholarship program for actors/ students who would not otherwise be able to afford to take classes


HELP US BUILD THE FUTURE- WHAT WE DREAM:

  • We aim to have our own space as a base for educational work and productions.
  • We aim to provide 5-10 free school residencies annually.
  • We aim to annually produce 2 high-quality productions at a continued low cost to NYC audiences.
  • We aim to work with more D75 schools and students with special needs by developing a focused and sustainable curriculum to serve both teachers and students in those schools.
  • We aim to provide a variety of high quality free/ donation-based workshops and events to the NYC community.
  • We aim to have an actual office to work in.
  • We aim to have at least 3 part-time, salaried staff members.
  • We aim to have 6-10 teachers on staff.
  • ...and we aim to have office supplies.....


 HOW YOU CAN HELP:

  • We need to compensate our incredible teachers, teaching artists, administrative staff and The Shakespeare Forum Outreach Division.
  • We need money for production costs and actor stipends.
  • We need money to invite world-class actors, artists and specialists on relevant topics to speak to our community at no cost to the audience.

                                                                        AND

  • We desperately need a permanent space for The Shakespeare Forum to reside. A space in which to work, rehearse, teach and welcome our ever-growing member base. If you are unable to support us financially, perhaps you can help us in this quest for a place to call home.

story:
About Red Quill Productions:


Red Quill Productions was founded in Nashville, TN by a group of young students thriving for unending opportunities to create, and establish their own opportunities.  As "starving artists" in an urban community, the way to get work is to be seen.  The way to be seen is to be on stage.  Joining the "create your own work" trend started by the likes of Mindy Kaling, Lena Dunham, Zooey Deschanel, and Tina Fey to name a few... Red Quill Productions was born.


Our first production in the summer of 2013 was a nod to Mindy Kaling, a woman who has consistently created her own work.  We produced, funded, and put on a sold out production of Kaling and Brenda Withers' hysterical satire of Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, Matt and Ben.  From that point on, we knew there was room to grow and it was time to take one more step up the ladder with a musical.  Thus, The Last Five Years project surfaced.


Rights alone for this project are roughly $1,500. $250 will go to rental of the venue. We are budgeting roughly $600 for set, this includes: lumber, paint, props, etc.. The remaining funds will go towards technical needs.  The cast and crew are taking no paychecks from this endeavor.  Any leftover funds will be graciously saved for future productions.

We need at least $1,500 to begin this process. If you can help us fund that, the rest will fall into place! This $1,500 cannot happen without your support!


A Note From the Director:


It's always a scary thing when you dive head first into the unknown. The Last Five Years is my "unknown." Jenna, Michael and I had joked around about doing a show from scratch one evening. We talked about all the "wish list ideas" and the "what ifs." All of a sudden, we thought, "Wait, we could actually do this." Thus, the journey began. 


All three of us have had our hands in the world of theatre. While yes, it's often unpaid community theatre, it's quite the cut-throat business. We got tired of waiting for opportunities on the agenda of others. So we decided to do something about it. We decided to make our "what if" a reality. 


With many musicals, so many things get lost in the big sets and the bright lights, that you miss the essence of the story. That's why we settled on Jason Robert Brown's The Last Five Years. It's so simplistically beautiful. This show is so unique because not only is it a two person cast, but because it happens in two time lines. Cathy starts at the end and moves backward, while Jamie starts from the beginning. As a director, you break down those fancy, shiny facets and find a story. Because of the show's unique quality, you can't rely on those bright lights and colorful set, you must rely on your actors entirely. Michael and Jenna are so extremely talented, that I wanted to give them a chance to live out their dream roles. In turn, living out one of mine - directing. 


While a veteran of the stage, directing a full production will be a first for me. This is why we are asking for your help. Unfortunately, this is not a "free" opportunity. We need your help in funding this process. Our goal is to raise $2,500. This will help pay for rights, venue rental, costumes, set, etc. By helping, you will be kick starting a new era of theatre. Instead of relying on someone else to give you a chance in the spotlight, you make your own. You tell the world, "This is my dream, and I will do what it takes to make it happen." By helping fund, you will be giving all three of us the chance to turn our dreams into a reality, and hopefully inspiring others to do the same, whether it be in the arts, or something entirely different. A monetary donation is not the only way to help either! Spreading the word to friends and family help us network and reach more people! Every little bit helps!  


We, as a team, are so grateful and blessed by this opportunity and thank you for all of your support, monetary and otherwise. It truly could not happen without each and every one of you. 


Rebekah Thoe

Director, The Last Five Years


THE TEAM: 

Director- Rebekah Thoe

Music Director- Sam Hagler


Cathy Hyatt- Jenna Pryor

Jamie Wellerstein- Michael Adcock


Performances will take place at the Murfreesboro Little Theatre in Murfreesboro, TN.

Friday, September 26, 2014 @ 7:00 PM

Saturday, September 27, 2014 @ 2:00 PM & 7:00 PM

Sunday, September 28, 2014 @ 2:00 PM

Tickets are $10 at the door.


The Last Five Years is presented through special arrangement with Music Theatre International (MTI).  All authorized performance materials are also supplied by MTI, 421 West 54th Street, New York, NY 10019.  Tel.: (212) 541-4684  Fax: (212) 397-4684  www.MTIShows.com


Red Quill reserves the right to change the production team slate at any time with no refunds on the donations being affected, as long as the show goes up.  Refunds will only be issued if the production does not occur.

story:
Light the Way for
Hedgepig Ensemble Theatre
How far that little candle throws its beams!
So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
- Merchant of Venice
Friend,

Whether you come by chance, by curiosity, by way of a gentle prod or kick in the pants, welcome.  We are glad you made it.

Perhaps you are a lover of classical theatre. Perhaps you believe in the great heights to which your friends/relatives/countrymen can climb. Perhaps you come with an unquenchable desire to support good people doing good work. Regardless of your inspiration, we raise our glasses to you.

This is an exciting moment for Hedgepig Ensemble Theatre. It’s the beginning of a wild ride, and we wouldn’t want you to miss out.  We are counting on you to be our family, our muses, and torchbearers. Take some time to read about our project, watch our video, and click on that donate button. Even the smallest donation counts in a major way.

Our most sincere thanks,

Gwen, Mary/Molly, and Adam
co-founders
Hedgepig Ensemble Theatre
O! For a Muse of Fire that would ascend the brightest heaven of invention.
- Henry V
WHO WE ARE:
A group of good people who want to do good work.

WHAT WE BELIEVE:
Theatre should be based in trust and joy. The way to achieve that kind of theatre is by building a strong ensemble.

WHAT IS A HEDGEPIG, ANYWAY?
A hedgepig is a young hedgehog. A term coined by Shakespeare, hedgepigs are unique creatures that deliver the unexpected. Just like us.
THE PROJECT:
Our first project is a staged reading of Twelfth Night in April. We will gather our ensemble members, potential ensemble members, a trusted artistic mentor, and a director to lay the foundation for our ensemble. Not only will we take our first step together as a company, we will begin a journey toward a full production of Twelfth Night in the summer.

Why Twelfth Night, you ask. Twelfth Night is the perfect ensemble building play. It allows for a small cast where everyone has an equal role in the story.
WHERE IS YOUR MONEY GOING EXACTLY?
We are aiming to raise $4,501.52.

The first $250 will go to a performance venue.
The next $400 will go to rehearsal space.
The $200 will go toward our amazing director.
The following $200 will compensate our fabulous stage manager.
The next $1200 will compensate our fine actors.
The next $800 will go toward an amazing and trusted movement coach.
The final $996.52 will go toward all the administrative expenses: membership to fractured atlas, various fees, letterhead, stamps, the like :) It's not as exciting, but just as necessary.

story:
About


Hey everyone!! Brigid here! Thanks for visiting my Indigogo page! 

Why did I make this page you ask? For those of you who know me well, or maybe not so well, know that I have been an Irish dancer for 13 years now. I have jigged my feet past the best of the best and finally am one of the 12 dancers in New England selected to complete in the 2014 World Irish Dance Championships! Which is basically the Olympics of Irish dancing, pretty cool ehh?

Andddd...heres where you come in! I need to raise money to get there! SO any little bit helps! If you donate I promise to break off a little piece of the gold metal that I win and give it to you. Maybe. Or you might just receive a goodie from me in the mail. Have you tried my cookies? They're to die for! I am also willing to do babysitting or other services as well! So make me a proposition!

Right now I am aiming to raise $4,000! Help me get there!

I have jigged my feet past the best of the best and finally am one of the 12 dancers in New England selected to complete in the 2014 World Irish Dance Championships! Which is basically the Olympics of Irish dancing, pretty cool ehh?
Andddd...heres where you come in! I need to raise money to get there! SO any little bit helps! If you donate I promise to break off a little piece of the gold metal that I win and give it to you. Maybe. Or you might just receive a goodie from me in the mail. Have you tried my cookies? They're to die for! I am also willing to do babysitting or other services as well! So make me a proposition!
Right now I am aiming to raise $4,000! Help me get there!

story:
Short Summary

To kick off The Agency's most ambitious season, we are presenting At the Center, our third original world premiere play. We need your help to bring this important work to the stage.

The Agency Theatre Collective is a new non-profit theatre company that seeks to tell stories directly relevant to our audiences with engaging performances and innovative theatrical style.

About the Play

Elizabeth Harvey has spent 19 years putting the pieces of her life back together following a brutal assault. Hector Reyes has spent 19 years in prison for a crime he didn't commit. When innocence lawyers intervene on Hector's behalf, the painful truth about their shared story begins to emerge. Inspired by the work of the Center on Wrongful Convictions at Northwestern University's School of Law, At the Center explores the issues surrounding wrongful convictions and asks how we can move forward after a miscarriage of justice.

What We Need & What You Get

Over the past year, we have devoted hundreds of hours interviewing exonerees, innocence attorneys, victims of crime, restorative justice workers, social workers and others touched by the issue of wrongful convictions. Your donation will help us honor their stories and make them live vividly in our audiences hearts and minds. Every dollar you give goes to: 
- lights, costumes, and dynamic design work 
- post-show discussions with some of those who inspired our play
- set construction
- theater rental
- promotional materials
- honoring the work of our artists 
Every little bit gets us closer to putting up a show worthy of these stories and this community. Not only is your donation tax-deductible, we also have some amazing perks from our collaborators ranging from show tickets to signed books to an intimate dinner with the executive director of the Center on Wrongful Convictions! 

The Impact

Since 1989, over 2,000 exonerations have freed innocent people from prison and death row. This play seeks to humanize something we hear a lot about, but that remains abstract to most of us. We’re asking hard questions with no easy answers.

We know there’s a lot of art in this city jockeying for your donation. With At The Center, we are proud to be telling an honest and emotionally charged story that we hope will inspire conversation and change. Your help allows us to tell more stories like this one and we couldn’t appreciate it more. 

Every amount helps, from $1 - $1000. Please donate today!

Other Ways You Can Help

There are more ways you can help. Please spread the word about the show and its subject matter! Bring a friend to the show, share this campaign, like our Facebook page and visit our website. We are The Agency. So are you.

story:
Who We Are

Jasmine (BQAC President) - Jasmine recently moved to Chicago from Kansas. In Kansas, Jasmine was Vice-Chair of the Center of Wichita and facilitated a weekly youth group for LGBT teens.

Chris (BQAC Vice-President) - Chris has been volunteering at the Center on Halsted since 2009 including hosting the Center's bi* programming and acting as their Bi Liaison.

BQAC (yup... B-quack!) was founded to address the need for visibility, resources and community building for Chicago-area bisexuals. They've done this not only at the Center on Halsted, by creating all of the bi-specific programming there, but also by attending the Chicago Pride Parade, hosting smaller events around the city, and showing up to rallies and protests in support of larger LGBT issues.

BQAC wants to do more though

We want BQAC to attend and host more events, to directly help more people, to create the educational resources desperately needed in healthcare, legal aid, and housing that are bi-specific. To do that we need to become a 501c3 non-profit organization, and start doing the real work as the only organization in Chicago focused on the needs of the bisexual community.

What We Need & What It's For

It's pretty simple, there's a lot of fees associated with filing the paperwork. By helping us, Jasmine and Chris, out today, you're enabling us to help more people in the future with education, resources, and community.

Key expenses:

  • IRS filing fee  - $400
  • Other state filing expenses - $100
  • Legal and financial advice - $100

Money beyond the $600 will go towards:

  • continuing to grow our presence at events like Chicago Pride
  • paying for space, performers, and food at our own annual Celebrate Bisexuality Day
  • developing and purchasing bisexual educational materials and disseminating them to the public
  • creating new events and forming new networks within the larger LGBT community

    Find Out More

    To find out more about BQAC you can visit the Facebook page at www.facebook.com/BQAChicago to learn all about our mission, our events (like the upcoming Celebrate Bisexuality Party), and our random bi-musings.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't contribute, that's cool, but sharing is caring! Forward our campaign and tell your friends why they should help us!

story:
The M.A.C.Y Scholarship Campaign

  •  Theater and Arts Students are overlooked for scholarships.
  • Your donations created 500 awards and 17 scholarships.
  • Your recognition will be remembered for life. 

The M.A.C.Y. Awards gives high school students the opportunity to take their love for theater to a higher education. With your support, their lives will be changed. 

D'Arcy Green our 2014 winner says, "This opportunity has made me a better person and performer. It has inspired me to work even harder to conquer my future goals. I could not have asked for a better way to close out my high school career."

Theater students don't receive the recognition they deserve.

  • Arts education improves all academic performance. 35% higher in math.
  • 95% of theater students go on to a 4 year college, versus 64% of others.
  • When they succeed, we need to recognize them for a job well done.
  • Successful students don't just happen. They are nurtured, trained, and most of all; recognized and encouraged.

Our Goal 

  • Every dollar goes directly to a student in need of a scholarship to achieve their higher education. 
  • Scholarships are sent directly to the college for each student ensuring all donations directly go to a student's education.


The Impact

Crowd funding allows each of us to participate in the arts when budget cuts are threatened. 


About M.A.C.Y. 

www.macyawards.com

M.A.C.Y. Awards is a 501c3 Non-Profit volunteer organization. 100% of your donations are tax deductible. 

The top Actor and Actress will once again be sent to New York to represent M.A.C.Y in the "National High School Musical Theater Awards". www.nhsmta.com

For over 45 years, The Childress M.A.C.Y. Awards has granted over 19,000 awards and scholarships! Your donation will be remembered throughout their lives and allow Arts Education to continue in our schools. 

The 45th Annual Childress M.A.C.Y. Awards will be held at Segerstrom Center on Sunday, May 31,  2015 at 12:00 PM. Please come join us.

None of this would be possible without your support.

Thank you again!

Childress M.A.C.Y. Awards.


Wayne Odekirk, President 951 836-2468

story:
Debuting in 2008, the annual Gelb Dance has since become one of the most anticipated social events of the school year. It provides a night of relief and fun to a stressed and overworked student body.

The following is an excerpt from an article published in the online Phillipian on September 17th, 2014:

“Last February, beakers and flasks spilled out of shelves and tumbled off of lab benches, resulting in the cancellation of the popular “Gelb Dance”…the destroyed equipment cost around $200 to replace and more than an hour of [time] to clean up.”

The full article can be found at the following link: http://www.phillipian.net/articles/2014/09/17/g...

The purpose of this campaign is to raise money to compensate for the financial damage that the Academy suffered at the hands of its student body as well as to pro-actively establish a fund to pay for any possible future damage of a similar nature. Between the Academy’s current students and the six years of alumnae with fond memories of the Gelb Dance, the authors of this campaign are cautiously optimistic that such a hit to the Academy’s $800 million endowment can be overcome.

Please, be the Kevin Bacon that our increasingly Footloose high school needs.

Proof of donation will be provided for all funds raised during this campaign.

story:
Who We Are

Seeing Other People Productions is a new theatre company founded by Chet Wilson, London Bauman, Ethan Cockrill, Amity Hanson, and Devon Roberts, all recent college graduates from Portland State University. We strive to make important, fun and independent theatre that will challenge both our performers and audiences in Portland, Oregon and beyond. 

 

What We Are Doing

One of our first projects is a play called Gayface, written by Chet Wilson, and we need your help to send it to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer in Edinburgh, Scotland. This is the largest performing arts festival in the world and will help us gain exposure and other partners for our company’s future.

 

Our Budget

 

Housing for our team of five people   $6733

Venue Rental $3664

Registration $413

Set/costumes $200

Insurance $263

Marketing  $727

 

Total $12000

 

How You Can Help 

In order to perform at the festival, we need housing for the month of August and a venue in which to perform. We are definitely going and we have secured these locations at great deals, but this is the most expensive time of the year for Edinburgh. Every donation will go towards helping us make it to the festival and give Seeing Other People Productions and Gayface a boost towards full realization. Thank you for your support.

story:
What is Roundtable Theatre Lab?

Roundtable Theatre Lab treats actors as the primary artists in the creation and development of its productions. In this way we are able to create theatre that comes out of a playful actor-led collaboration, while the director operates as a third eye. In exploring the work of the playwright through the lens of the actors, we can find a multi-dimensional vision, illuminating the plays fully and in all their glory. 

 

The Inspiration

When two actors explored a scene without deciding who would play which role until just before the performance, they were thrilled by the freedom they discovered. Choices could be thoroughly explored as a team without having to worry about impinging upon each other’s personal practice. For all you non-actors out there, the work we do is typically regarded as preciously personal and the biggest crime a fellow actor can commit is to interfere with a colleague’s autonomous process. While we don’t disagree with this in the final stages of work, our rehearsal method, involving an open line of dialogue, communal text analysis, and active exploration, aims to free the actor from these concerns in a way that translates in the ultimate performance.

 

Why we need your help

The venue will cost us nothing, the props will cost us nothing, the costumes will cost us (next to) nothing…. However, as actors ourselves, we know how rare and important it is to get paid for the work we do and we want to make sure that each of the talented actors who have generously joined us for our first production receives a stipend for their hard work and dedicated hours. Please consider making a donation to support (and pay!) our theatre artists. We can’t do this without you. Please peruse our donation offers and prizes with excitement and generosity.

 

If you would like to help in ways other than through monetary donation, please spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools on Facebook, email, twitter, and don’t forget word-of-mouth – we are grateful for any and all of the help you can give us! Many, many thanks.

 

The Venue – We’re in the cozy confines of an apartment living-room.

Are we all sitting comfortably? Good.

Now, let’s tell a rather uncomfortable story.

We know that the apartment setting can transform the play, but we’re also interested in how the play can transform the space. It may look cozy and inviting, with its original brick walls and fancy fireplace, (it’s appropriately called ‘The Parlor’), but how will it feel and look after the effects of the play have rippled through the unsuspecting audience?

In the intimate environs of this unconventional theatrical space, audiences will experience what it is to be complicit in the story; not only in its midst, but part of it.
