story:
About Us

Hello friends, family, and greater artistic community! We have been granted the wonderful opportunity to attend Steppenwolf West's Summer Intensive program in Long Beach...together! We're each at different points in our process as artists and actors, but we have a whole lotta love for the work and for each other and are so excited to take what feels like a much needed step in our professional training this July and August. 

Many of you know us, but for those who don't:

WARREN is an aspiring actor, musician, and designer looking to re-start his formal education in the arts beginning with Steppenwolf West's summer intensive. He has been working as an actor for the past four years and has come to accept storytelling as his life's work. Now all he needs is to cultivate a deeper theoretical understanding and hone his technical skill set in the studio ensemble environment in order to become the artist he dreams to be! Thank you for your time and consideration and may love be with you.

HANNAH is an actor and sometime director and educator originally from the San Francisco Bay Area. She earned her B.A. in theatre from the University of California, San Diego and after serving as an ensemble member and co-director of education for the Hungry River Theatre Company has, in the two years since, been working as an actor wherever and whenever she can. After participating in Steppenwolf West's 2011 intensive, she looks joyfully forward to re-grounding, re-grouping, and re-connecting to her artistic and actor-self with some of her most important and influential mentors and teachers this summer, as always with an eye on her future as a working professional actor.

That being said, we wish wish WISH that money didn't matter and that we didn't even have to ask, but it does and we do. We've both been gifted with generous financial assistance from the lovely folks at Steppenwolf West, but need a little over $2000 more to make it all the way. We're not interested in pressuring anyone, just in asking with love (good vibes are also happily accepted). Any little bit can help! Your generosity is received with our intense and undying gratitude.

"The essence of all beautiful art, all great art, is gratitude."                                       - Friedrich Nietzsche

Thanks and love,
Hannah & Warren

About the Intensive

Steppenwolf Classes West @ The Beach is a four-week ensemble acting course for professional and professionally-bound theatre artists.  The program takes place on the campus of California State University Long Beach and is open to actors and theatre makers from across the country and around the world.  The program features instruction from Steppenwolf Classes West faculty and guest artists, offering a one-of-a-kind opportunity for student actors to train, explore, and perform together in a supportive and challenging environment.

Students spend four weeks learning and exploring Viewpoints training, improvisation, scene study, text analysis, mask work, on-camera work, and Michael Chekhov Technique, as well as rehearsing together for a public performance at the end of the program.

The teaching faculty includes Jeff Perry (Steppenwolf Theatre and Steppenwolf Classes West Co-Founder), Alexandra Billings, Eric Hunicutt, Kim Rubinstein, and features Master Classes taught by Hugh O'Gorman, Christopher Shaw, and Emmy-winning Casting Director Linda Lowy. 

These artists need your help!  All funds raised go directly to those students who are offered a spot in the program.  Your contribution will assists artists in payment of tuition.  By contributing, you are playing a vital supporting role in the future of these creators, helping them to train and grow in their lives and their art.

story:
A PROJECT OF THE HEART

We (Deanna Palazzo and Tanya Sand) have joined as a team to produce Daniel MacIvor's award winning play, Marion Bridge. We're local actors in Toronto and wanted to delve into and bring to the stage a subject matter and story that meant something unique to each of us, as well as challenge us as artists. Upon researching we discovered our mutual love for Daniel MacIvor's play. It's the story of three young women who come "home" to Cape Breton to tend to their dying mother. It's quick,  funny, and touching, exploring not only death, but what memories mean and what expectations we put on life itself. 

"In some ways, this moving drama, which tiptoes toward sentimentality without ever reaching it, is the most surprising play that [MacIvor's] ever written." ... "They have all come home to see their dying mother, but while Mr. MacIvor often writes about death, this resolutely hopeful play is as much about making the most of life (despite all its flaws and disappointments)." 

- New York Times

We are producing this play independently, so we would like to respectively ask for your assistance. Please note that all contributions given to this campaign will be put directly toward production costs entirely (theatre rental, play rights, printing costs, honorariums for the creative team, etc.). You've heard it before, but no contribution is too small and adds up! So please donate if you can!

Let's Break It Down

Our goal is $3500, which covers our production costs ONLY. We do not plan to pay ourselves from this campaign - we hope only to do right by our creative team and be able to compensate them and break even ourselves if at all possible. The fruition and success of this project itself is payment enough for us :)

As a breakdown, all contributions will go towards the following:

  • Theatre Rental for a 6 show run.
  • The rights to the play for a 6 show run.
  • Honorariums for our creative team (actor, director, lighting designer, stage manager, graphic designer, publicist, etc.)
  • Printing costs and promotion (programs, posters, etc.)
  • Set design costs

Your Impact

As we mentioned, this is most definitely a project of the heart! We are doing this for the love of theatre. For the love of acting. For the love of art. We are creative people and are overjoyed to be able to include other very talented and creative people in our project and to be producing such a well respected Canadian play by an equally respected Canadian playwright. But as we all well know, costs add up quickly. 

We have fronted all the money so far on our own, have worked hard to do so and will continue to, but any other help as seen below would be so GREATLY appreciated:

    Ways You Can Help

    • Donate here! It's a great way for those who are far away or out of town to support as well!
    • Attend the play! We would love for you to support our project in the way of attendance whether you are or are not able to make a donation.
    • Talk about it! Spread the word and share on social media! 

    Show Times & Tickets:

    Tickets are available online ($15.50 each + service fee) at: http://marionbridge.bpt.me, or at the door ($18 each) at:

    The Theatre Machine (formally Unit 102)
    376 Dufferin Street
    Toronto, ON

    Tuesday, October 14th @ 8pm

    Wednesday, October 15th @ 8pm

    Thursday, October 16th @ 8pm

    Friday, October 17th @ 8pm

    Saturday, October 18th @ 8pm

    Sunday, October 19th @ 2pm


    And thank you so much in advance! THANK YOU!

story:
JULIETTE BURTON: LOOK AT ME


As featured on John Lloyd presents...Quite Interesting Edinburgh on 20th August 2013.


"Comedy you can learn from." BBC Edinburgh Festival


From award-winning actress and writer Juliette Burton comes her brand new multimedia docu-comedy for Edinburgh Fringe 2014 - 'LOOK AT ME'

Juliette's appearance has changed over the years - she's been a size 4 and a size 20 and everything in between. And now, she will change even more. From wearing a hijab to dressing provocatively, being male, obese, old and nude: can changing our outsides affect who we are on the inside? And is who we appear to be who we really are?



Following her 5- star, sell-out Edinburgh Fringe 2013 run of her debut solo show 'WHEN I GROW UP' (see here http://youtu.be/9Yts_7g3Dts) her new show 'LOOK AT ME' promises to be just as bright, life-affirming, enthusiastic and joyous. Using exciting graphics and technology, original music and interviews with a diverse range of people (thalidomide, physically disabled, cystic fibrosis sufferers, cancer patients, obese people, girls who self harm, models, 70 year old women, a range of ages and genders), this project aims to be an uplifting docu-comedy which celebrates diversity and body confidence!



RESEARCH SO FAR...

So far Juliette has been working with the facial disfigurement charity Changing Faces, the body image charity B.O.D.Y. the eating disorder charity B-eat and MWAE (Muslim Women's Association of Edinburgh) in research for this show. Juliette confronts complex and difficult issues, effectively using entertaining comedy to raise mental health awareness. Juliette wants to uncover what we know about a person by appearances, the beauty myth and the idea of self-perception ... All in a comedy show.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP...

Juliette has been lucky enough to be granted some funding from Arts Council England, which has made the writing and research for the show possible. However, it does not count towards the cost of producing the show itself. All money pledged will help towards the costs of putting on the show: venue hire, staff at the venue, materials, publicity costs, marketing, flyering ... the list goes on.


But don't take our word for it, this is why others are helping:



Please donate whatever you can, whether it is 50p, £5, £10 or £50, every penny is appreciated. 


JULIETTE'S HISTORY...

Juliette is an award-winning actress, writer and ex-BBC broadcast journalist who co-founded comedy duo Mace and Burton in 2010. Their show Rom Com Con won the Argus Angel award for excellence and was Top Nominee for the Best Comedy in the Latest Awards at Brighton Fringe in 2012. Juliette has appeared in 15 short films and has presented many web series including Cambridge Fold Festival's Folk TV videocasts.


Juliette's mental health is relevant as well as it's the personal story that will be at the heart of the show. She has lifelong issues, all of which she is still dealing with: OCS, acute anxiety, manic depression, bipolar, anorexia, bulimia, compulsive overeating disorder. She's been an inpatient in mental hospitals 4 times, sectioned aged 17. Juliette now blogs for Time to Change, Mindfull and has strong links with the mental health charity Mind. She is an ambassador for the eating disorder B-eat and works with the facial disfigurement charity Changing Faces and the body dysmorphic disorder charity B.O.D.Y.


Mental health is provoking a discussion that Juliette wants to be part of. Recently, she has been a guest on BBC World Service and interviewed for the Independent's article: 'Study finds comedians are more inclined to have 'high levels of psychotic personality traits'.


Her debut solo show 'When I Grow Up' was a 5-star, sell-out docucomedy hit at Edinburgh Fringe 2013 and was featured on 'John Lloyd's Quite Interesting Edinburgh' at BBC Edinburgh Festivals. Her Gilded Balloon performances were listed as one of the Top 10 shows at the Fringe by FringeReview, and a Top 10 show by Chortle.


See more at: http://www.julietteburton.co.uk/about/#sthash.8fpesbJJ.dpuf

  


What the money will go towards*:

Venue hire: £2,000

Flyers and Posters: £500

PR and Marketing: £2,500

Design: £3,000

Music Video Studio Hire: £500

(*estimated costs)


Your help is so very much appreciated and will contribute to a better understanding of who we are as opposed to who we appear to be!

THANK YOU!

(All perks are inclusive of UK delivery, however overseas delivery will incur an extra charge)

story:
Imagine surrendering so fully into the flow of the wheel that all time ceases to exist, just you, the wheel and daring feats that break the barriers of what was once "impossible" to become possible.  My name is Josiah and my desire is to bring Spinnovation to Portland! to help more people let go, overcome fears and doubts and awaken to a more expanded, liberated sense of self.  
 
Spinnovation is a group of performing artists, coaches, gymnasts, and friends that have created a network of Cyr wheel spinners across the United States. Workshops, after school programs, classes at performing arts schools, and free spin sessions are being held by Spinnovation from New York to San Francisco, Los Angeles, Detriot, Chicago, Tennessee, San Lois Obispo, and Wisconsin! 

 I am a 11 year professional circus artist, licensed Holistic Health Practitioner, and visionary craftsmen. I am experienced in training circus arts with full awareness of how to safely bring this to the public. Come see me perform at various shows, recieve a private lesson to learn how to spin, and stay tuned for the unfolding visionary performace art videos!

The funding will be used to purchase 3 more wheels which cost $1500 a piece. That makes $4500! For start up program costs rental space fees is another $1000. The reason we need many wheels is due to the size of all the different people! 3 wheels of different heights will allow anyone 5'2" or taller to have a wheel comfortable to their height. Once all the gear and wheels have arrived I will be holding private sessions and small workshops in Portland and occasionally surrounding areas such as Seattle and Eugene.

The Perks are awesome! Backers can choose private sessions, class packages, Alchemical Bodywork sessions local to Portland, Visionary art installations custom built for each backer, visionary carpentry for larger backing amounts, and even small pendants of Spinnovation Portland's logo!

More on Spinnovation and what we have been doing:
In 2010 Spinnovatoin has helped students earn physical education requirements in the private school sector in Orange County, CA. Orange Lutheran High School.

In 2011 Spinnovation provided the ﬁrst high school in the US with an inventory of wheels to integrate with other performing arts studies. Milton High School in Atlanta, GA. We now provide ongoing support to their performing arts department. A few of their graduates will be participating at 2013 Worlds Championships.

In 2012 Spinnovation provided inventory to expand our US networks to STREB in NY. Vespertine Circus in San Francisco, Aloft in Chicago, Harmonic Hoops in Detroit and Hoop Exchange in Knoxville, Tennessee. Spinnovation also provided necessary support to both our Team Spinnovation members Eli Cherweznik and Shayna Swanson, who won National Championships for both men and women respectively.

Summer 2013 Spinnovation embarks on the ﬁrst west coast tour. Founder of
Spinnovation Sam Tribble and National Champion Eli Cherweznik bring the art and education of Mono Wheel to San Francisco, Portland and Seattle. immediately following the road tour similar workshops where held at Project in Motion in New Mexico, MHS Atlanta, GA and Knoxville, Tennessee.

Winter 2013 Spinnovation has submitted it’s outstanding curriculum to the Fullerton College in Fullerton, CA. Credited courses are scheduled to being in the Fall of 2014.

My Bio: At the age of 13 (11 years ago) I began training circus arts in a community circus know as The Great Y Circus in Redlands, Ca. My mother always encouraged us to do what we loved. Since then I have forever been a performing artist and found my love for arts flourished from there. I grew up building houses with my father learning the ways of creation and going off into the forest regularly to learn about herbal medicine and how to survive with mother nature. These seeds that were planted at such a young age have grown into who I am now.

Through college I built and designed sets for the theatre and continued training and performing my circus arts. Two days before my 20th birthday on a warm and sunny day in August I was breathing fire and felt that I had inhaled fumes and possibly had chemical pneumonia. The trip to the ER revealed a tumor in my chest and that the condition was worse... Nine days later I was diagnosed with stage 2 Hodgkins Lymphoma (blood cancer). Forever I was changed, turning away from western medicine I treated myself using herbal medicine, meditation, chi gong, colon hydrotherapy and other modalities over the past 4 years. In this process of healing myself I became a true healer. I flowered into a Holistic Health Practitioner, Herbologist, and shifted my building into the realm of visionary art. Crystals are a large part of my healing and they play a vital role in my work with others. I feel eternally grateful and blessed to have come on this healing journey!

Eventually I burst out of living in the city and moved to Boulder Gardens, a beautiful healing sanctuary in Pioneer Town, Ca where I built my first magical earthen home! The creation of this home sparked a huge transformation inside that led me to follow the call to build here in Portland at Onedoorland! Soon after arriving and wanting to train wheel I found there was no one spinning wheel in Portland. Now here we are bringing the art form to the beautiful north west so that we can all play, love, laugh, and create...

story:
Short Summary

The 2014 Fringe Festival, at the Just Off Broadway Theatre, will host one of the most unique theatre experiences of the year, A-Cop-Alypse!  

The story follows hard-nosed, no-nonsense cop Thorburg as he tries to avenge his father's death.  Thorburg is soon joined by the wise-cracking, heavy drinking, former partner of his father, Geyser.  Together, with the help of friends, they set out to bust drug lord and dad murderer, Dr. Devious.  Then there are zombies.  Cool.  Zombies.

  • My name is Jeff Smith and I'm the writer of A-Cop-Alypse.  This has been a dream project for me, in that I'm obsessed with the buddy-cop genre.  Never before has a buddy-cop, blockbuster based story been attempted on the small stage.  Myself and my creative team looked at the diverse theatre landscape here in Kansas City and wondered, why not? We can do this!  And do it well!
  • This campaign is very important to us in that we are trying to make the story and visuals as compelling as possible. This campaign is dedicated solely to the effects of the piece (ie, make-up, make-up design, special effects.)
  • With your help, you can attribute to the true vision of this small piece.  With theatre, I think we are all always chasing magic.  You will help us find that magic.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for 1,000.  This amount is going to go two places:

  • Make-up costs (design by Dylan Thomas).  In the show, we will have over 8 people in zombie make-up!  We have a make-up designer that has worked on numerous movies, television shows, and theme park haunt concepts.  Turns out that the good make-up is expensive. 
  • Costumes - We are bringing in professional based costumes for our legion of zombies.
  • Special lighting.  We are planning on bringing in LED and special lighting for the show.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds acquired will still go to the two designated places. 

The Impact

Again, this show is something very special and meaningful to me.  Is it a comedy? Yes.  Is it a spoof? Obviously.  But I'm looking to accomplish a show that is funny, visually stimulating, impressive, and draws people who may not typically go to theater.  Then make those people want to experience more of what Kansas City has to offer.  This show has the potential to be a gateway drug for new theatergoers.  (Pun intended.)

    Risks & Challenges

    This show is a large risk.  For a small show in Fringe I am investing a large amount of my own money to cover cost that may often be overlooked: set design, lighting design, sound design, stage management, rehearsal rental space, performance space, costumes, props, payment of the teams and actors.  I'm happy to do so to get this show off the ground, but do realize that I will need a little help.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Thank you to all that already came out to fundraising events we had in April.  Your support is very much appreciated and we thank you so much.  (Also, special thanks to Barry Linduff for providing our sweet graphics and poster!)

      Another way you can help is to come to the show!  Excited to see you there! 

      Showtimes are:

      Friday July 18th at 6pm

      Saturday July 19th at 8pm

      Monday July 21st at 10pm

      Wednesday July 23rd at 6:30pm

      Friday July 25th at 9:30pm

      Saturday July 26th at 4pm

story:
Who

Hi, I’m Amanda Miller! I’m presenting my solo comedy How To Suffer Better at this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and I would deeply appreciate your support. 

For the past nine years I have been performing my solo shows in venues and festivals across New York City and the United States, shows that include One Breath, Then Another: An Interactive Yoga Show about my life changing journey to an ashram in India to study yoga to avoid the self destructive path of my father, which inspired me to move and empower others through interactive solo performance work—in One Breath, Then Another, I invite the audience to chant, move, and meditate as if they are ashram participants, and to reflect on their own journeys.

My follow up show Camp Smile Power: Curing Anger One Smile at a Time explores the anger of a male teen activist who is sent to an anger management camp on a plea deal after committing a protest action, a camp that forces campers to smile all the time. While attempting to complete a presentation about what he’s learned about managing anger, he cracks, encouraging audience members to yell alongside him the things about society that make them angry and, once they’ve gotten it out of their systems, to hug each other, then draw their feelings and march with them. 

In addition to being a writer and performer, I am a massage therapist, yoga instructor, and teaching artist, all practices that I view as having the same ultimate goals: to facilitate human connection and reduce suffering, goals to which I have dedicated my life. I'm especially passionate about using comedy to explore the human condition, believing that collectively laughing at the absurdity of our experiences can help us both lighten our loads and build community.

I have performed in fringe festivals, comedy fests, theaters, bars, synagogues, classrooms, apartments, a massage school, a yoga studio and on rooftops. After all this experience and craft honing, I decided this year to fulfill my dream of performing in the world renowned Edinburgh Fringe, the largest performing arts festival in the world. To make this dream a success, and to move, empower and impact as many people as possible, I need your help. Thank you in advance for being a partner in my journey as an independent artist and supporting the arts as a vital component of our global culture. 

Why Edinburgh?

Performing at the Edinburgh Fringe gives me the opportunity to connect with a global audience. As well as attracting a huge number of shows, Edinburgh attracts the largest and most diverse audience of any Fringe Festival in the world. Performing at the festival can also open up opportunities to tour my show internationally, earn some development funding for the future, and meet potential collaborators from around the world. Every generous donation helps me get closer to these goals, no matter how big or small.

What I Need & What You Get

I have created a funding goal of $4000 to contribute towards a variety of costs that come along with my slot in the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. The costs are broken down as follows..

  1. Festival Participation Fees: Programme Fee: $316.02, Free Festival Fee: $101.60, East To Edinburgh Production Fee (59E59 Theaters): $450
  2. Accommodation: $1069
  3. Travel:  $291.80 (Flight)
  4. Publicist: $2226.43
  5. Promotional & Marketing Materials: $375

In exchange for your generous contributions, I have created a list of perks that include personalized writing and videos from characters from the show, tickets to performances at 59E59 Theaters this July, books, yoga sessions and massages.

Risks & Challenges

Performing a show at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival is notoriously risky and comes with multiple challenges. The biggest risk is the accruement of personal financial debt. The biggest challenge is getting people to come and see the show when there are over 3000 shows to see, which is why I’ve chosen to hire a publicist, my largest expense. Even with her expert assistance, I plan to be out on the Royal Mile and near my venue every day as one of my show’s characters, engaging with people about the ways in which they suffer and what it means to suffer better in an effort to get them interested and excited about the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute, doesn't mean you can't help;

  1. Share my campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, MySpace, Google+, Bebo, everywhere. Encourage your friends to contribute! Make some noise!
  2. Email this campaign to your friends and colleagues (this is the best way to help, according to science).
  3. Get me in touch with anyone you know who is looking to support a project like this. I want to meet them!

Special Thanks!

HOW TO SUFFER BETTER is a solo show, but it would not have been possible without the creative contributions of the following incredible individuals:

Carol Lee Sirugo Carol Lee Sirugo is an actor, writer, theater clown/physical comedienne, teacher and coach. She has appeared in numerous theater productions in NYC and has toured the Canadian Fringe Festival Circuit with her one-act comedies. She currently teaches Comic Gold, Clown Discovery Workshops, in NYC.  www.CarolLeeSirugo.com

Annie Barry has collaborated with Amanda Miller in various ways from improv, to podcasting to directing her shows. She currently performs and teaches at the Washington Improv Theater in DC.

Shawn Shafner is an artist, educator, activist and founder of The People's Own Organic Power Project www.thePOOPproject.org. 

Lorin Taylor is a graphic artist with unmatched studio skills who's been working professionally in NYC for over 10 years in addition to being a painter, jewelry designer and photographer. http://thelorintaylor.com/

Amy Dupcak is a writer, editor, teacher and author of DUST: Short Stories, published on Lucid River Press. Her fiction and creative nonfiction have appeared in numerous online and print journals. http://www.amydupcak.com

Scott Alexander Hess is a novelist and teacher. HI novels include The Butcher's Son (a Kirkus Reviews Best Book of 2015) and Skyscraper (a 2016 Lambda Literary Award Finalist). http://www.scottalexanderhess.com/

Britt Canty is a writer, publicist and event coordinator. Her writing has appeared in online publications and she is a founder and curator of HIP Lit, an NYC reading series.

story:
Short Summary

Five days in Belgrade with The Belgrade Philarmonic Orchestra (about 60 members) and a choir of 30 singers.The musicians will be recorded one by one to permit much more adaptation in the recording room.

Band and music voice will be add in the recording studio.

What We Need & What You Get

To be able to produce the recordings mentioned above, we need to cover: travel expenses to Belgrade, the recording studio rental charge, the orchestra and all the sound technician costs. These things total 30.000.

What we will create 

We will keep all the Casanova Rock Opera tracks in digital format which will be available for download or in a special Cd album. The fully mixed recording will be also used in the live show when we don't have the orchestra.

 

Thank you for your time and help, we hope to be sending out the fruits of our efforts soon!

story:
Short Summary

Deep in the bowels of the New York City subway system is a mysterious stop called Park Place, where no one enters and no one leaves. An homage to 80s horror films, Park Place takes us on a trip... what may be the worst commute of your life.

Park Place is the first play by Lindsay Hope Simon to be professionally produced, directed by Lizz Hudman. While the festival provides the venue, publicity, and tech (no small contribution), it takes far more than that to make a show! We believe in paying all creatives for their work. Your contribution will support an all-female creative team and also pay actors, in addition to funding the use of professional production resources like rehearsal space and a stage manager.

What We Need & What You Get

The festival provides the space, insurance, and helps promote us. That's a big deal! However, we don't get any of the proceeds from ticket sales. Your funds will help pay for:

  • Rehearsal space
  • Actor stipends
  • Costumes & props
  • Director & stage manager stipends
  • Graphic designer for promotional materials

The result will be a positive process for all involved, leading to a stage production at The Secret Theatre this July, where we will compete to make it to the finals. The final competition night presents the opportunity to be published in the festival anthology, as well as win cash prizes for best play, best director, and best actor and actress.

Performances are:

July 13 9pm

July 19 7pm

July 22 7:30pm

July 28 5:30pm

August 1 7pm

The Impact

This show could be done for free if we rehearsed outdoors and didn't pay anyone, but we value the work of everyone involved in this project and want to create a professional process and product. We value our team and their work and want to pay them for their time and talent. Your support helps us in our commitment to providing opportunities for working actors, directors, and other theatre creatives.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds to contribute at this time, no worries! Please share this campaign to spread the word, and come see us at The Secret Theatre in July to vote for Park Place!

story: Hi friends! As you may know us, we are a bunch of young artists just trying to make our way in the world! In working on creating this unique and original devised performance, we've realized we need a couple of dollars to purchase props, costumes, and to make our masks (gotta love that sweet mask work). We don't need the full $500, but just around $125. If we have any extra money, we will try to put it towards a videographer and/or photographer and/or dinner for the cast the nights of the show, which are May 20th and 21st at Live Theatre Workshop. Everything helps and, with such a small goal, literally every dollar helps!

story:
Hi! We’re Brandon and Brigette, and we wrote a play. Over the last two years, we’ve worked hard on crafting this piece and we look forward to sharing this play with you all through a virtual live-streamed reading on February 28th at 3 pm EST. We’re looking to help cover some of the expenses for producing this virtual event.

The Event Page: https://www.facebook.com/events/1100669297046034/?acontext=%7B%22event_action_history%22%3A[%7B%22mechanism%22%3A%22your_upcoming_events_unit%22%2C%22surface%22%3A%22bookmark%22%7D]%7D

 

Afternoon Delight by Brandon Bacorn and Brigette Valois

Levi Hines has fallen in love with an exotic dancer. He has fallen hard. And willing to isolate those closest to him just to chase after his fantasy.  Meanwhile, Cinnamon is ready to break free from her job to pursue her artistic dreams.  Afternoon Delight is a slice of life comedy that explores the importance of our ambitions, how friendships change, and how much of a mess love can truly be.

 

We are looking to raise $500 to ensure that all involved receiving some type of stipend for their work on this show. 

What you will get is recognition with your name on a slide during the stream. As well as some other perks depending on the tier you choose.

$5- The First Timer: Your name will appear during the stream as a funder of the stream including a link to the stream.

$10- The Regular: A shout out on the Facebook event for the live stream. In addition to the perk from the “First Timer.”

$25- The Chicken Feeder: You will get a personalized thank you card signed by Brandon and Brigette as well as a special “Chicken Feeder” title card to appear on stream. In addition to the perks from the “Regular.”

$100- The Fan Club: You will be invited to our virtual cast party to take place sometime after the stream in addition to a special “Fan Club” title card to appear on stream. In addition to the perks from the “Chicken Feeder”

$500- The Club Owner: Your name will appear as a producer above the title for the live-stream. As well as get the perks below.

If we don’t reach our goal; the overall stipend for our performers will be smaller.

 

This is our first campaign on Indiegogo and we are really excited to share this with all of you. Your contributions to this live-stream will help present two new dramatic voices present their work to the world. 

 

After the events of this past year, we understand that everyone can contribute to this campaign.  If you could help pass along this project to your friends via the social media links above and be sure to join our Facebook event to get all of the updates regarding the stream.

story:
Hurricane House the Musical

The video above is an abstract interpretation of Hurricane House the Musical and it was created to showcase one of the original compositions from the show.

This is not a very complicated campaign. It is designed to give you the information you need about the show and why we would need and appreciate your contribution. One of the things we did not want to do is belabor this process, because, frankly, none of us reads as much as we should. Lol, I don't. With that said, on this page you will find a synopsis of the show, original music, what we need the money for and the creative team bios.

Hurricane House the Musical Synopsis

Delta Mason, 22, leaves home one steamy summer night in her North Carolina town for some ice cream and does not return. The frantic family (mother Caroleena, father Bruin, brother Leavell and identical twin Delia) searches for her, a search complicated by the appearance of a hurricane bearing her name. Hurricane Delta is so massive that the townspeople must evacuate. But the Masons believe they have a compelling reason to remain. Only the athiest Leavell seems to understand that they will all be killed. But does the rest of the family know something about God and the spirit that Leavell must re-learn? Will his lack of belief kill them all, or will it save them?

We need $7500 to complete the second draft of our musical. If we can raise this amount, it will push us one step closer to mounting a workshop production in New York City. Workshop productions are a necessity to attract producers who will invest in our full Off-Broadway production. Although we managed to create the first draft via Skype, it is imperative that we all meet in person, in a room with a piano, the script, and the creative energy of New York City.  That's right, we have never met in person and that is a testament to the power of technology. But, this is the point in our process when we have to create face to face.

Here is what your monies will be used for:

**offset the legal costs of the option and collaboration agreements between the creative   team

**accommodations and flight for the lyricist who lives in Italy

**Rehearsal space in NYC for a week of intensive work on the second draft of the show

**fee to have second draft evaluated by the Producer's Perspective before we mount the workshop production

**any other incidentals pertaining to the production of Hurricane House the Musical(per diem, copies, supplies, fees etc.)

In closing, we want to stress that theatre is a collaborative effort. That collaboration is not only between the creatives; it extends to those who can recognize the vision and decide they would like to help that vision come to life. Without you, what we love to do would not be possible. You have our sincere THANK YOU!!

Unfortunately, we have chosen not to offer any perks because we would have to ask for additional money to pay for them. What we will offer is recognition at every level of our production and updates on the various stages of the show.

Hurricane House Creative Team Bios

Wendell Edward Carter: Book

Wendell Edward Carter hails originally from Charlottesville, Virginia.  Educated at Haverford College, Stanford and Cornell Universities, he became a playwright after the tragic death of a younger sibling lead to the near-spontaneous genesis of a play about the experience and its aftermath (Hurricane House).  Wendell is the author of some 14 plays.  As a theatre producer or playwright, he has had productions in the George Houston Bass Play-Rites Festival at the Rites & Reasons Theatre (Providence, RI), The Acting Studio (NY, NY), The National Black Theatre Festival (Winston-Salem, NC), The Goldman Theatre of the Jewish Community Center (Washington, DC), the American Theatre Project (Washington, DC), The Harmony Hall Regional Arts Center (Fort Washington, MD), and at the Source Theatre (Washington, DC). His most recent production was the premiere of his play RARA AVIS (Rare Bird), at Temple M in New York City in June 2009.  He is currently writing his first novel, Melting the Snow. He resides in New York City.

Matthew A.C. Cohen: Music

Matthew A.C. Cohen was born in 1989 in Merrick, New York. He has earned a B.S. degree in Music Composition and Theory, with a special interest in film scoring, arranging, and Jazz saxophone. Matthew has studied saxophone with Dave Pietro, Alejandro Aviles, Jeff Newell, and Andy Middleton, and studied Jazz improvisation and arranging with prominent arranger and pianist Dr. David Lalama. He studied composition with Herbert Deutsche, Dr. Matthew Van Brink, and award winning composer, Dr. Kenneth Lampl, and has an M.F.A in Scoring for Motion Picture at Columbia College Chicago.

 Simon Mas: Lyrics

After studying jazz and popular music in Italy for years, Simon Mas attended the prestigious Berklee College of music in Boston ending on the Dean's list for two semesters in a row. After arriving at Newcastle University in 2004, Simon was awarded entry to the Year Abroad Exchange Program on academic merits and ended up studying at the University of Texas in Austin. Upon returning to the UK, Simon earned a BMUS degree in Music in 2008 and a MMus degree in Composition and Musicology in 2009, both from Newcastle University. Since graduation, Simon has produced 3 albums and 1 EP.

W. Jeffery Jelks: Producer/Director

 As a theatre producer/director, it has been his pleasure to bring to life the eclectic work of these intelligent, colorful and prolific artists. The Further Adventures of Gussie Mae in America by  Letitia Guillory, Daddy’s Home,  Curious Child, Brussel Sprouts and Monsters by Renee Flemings; In the Dark with the Walter Lees by Wendell Edward Carter; Imperfection Flawed by Lillie Marie Redwood; Playin’ the Wall by Michael Mayson; Friend of the Family by Michael Monasterial; Watermelon, Git it While it’s Hot by CeCe Antoinette, and Oscar Grant’s Roommates were all directed by Jeffery in various venues in New York City, Maryland, Cincinnati, Connecticut and Texas. He also has served as Creative Consultant for the plays Grim Foster’s Love Songs by T. Tara Turk and Brown Gal’s Rising by Cece Antoinette.  Jeffery studied acting with Tony-award winning Uta Hagen and Oscar-winning Sandy Dennis and directing with Bill Alton. He was honored to be chosen as a participant in the prestigious Lincoln Center Director’s Lab and is a recent recipient of a 2013 Spring Lowcountry Quarterly Arts Grant.

But, this is the point in our process when we have to create face to face.
Here is what your monies will be used for:
**offset the legal costs of the option and collaboration agreements between the creative   team
**accommodations and flight for the lyricist who lives in Italy
**Rehearsal space in NYC for a week of intensive work on the second draft of the show
**fee to have second draft evaluated by the Producer's Perspective before we mount the workshop production
**any other incidentals pertaining to the production of Hurricane House the Musical(per diem, copies, supplies, fees etc.)
In closing, we want to stress that theatre is a collaborative effort. That collaboration is not only between the creatives; it extends to those who can recognize the vision and decide they would like to help that vision come to life. Without you, what we love to do would not be possible. You have our sincere THANK YOU!! 
Unfortunately, we have chosen not to offer any perks because we would have to ask for additional money to pay for them. What we will offer is recognition at every level of our production and updates on the various stages of the show.
Hurricane House Creative Team Bios
Wendell Edward Carter: Book
Wendell Edward Carter hails originally from Charlottesville, Virginia.  Educated at Haverford College, Stanford and Cornell Universities, he became a playwright after the tragic death of a younger sibling lead to the near-spontaneous genesis of a play about the experience and its aftermath (Hurricane House).  Wendell is the author of some 14 plays.  As a theatre producer or playwright, he has had productions in the George Houston Bass Play-Rites Festival at the Rites & Reasons Theatre (Providence, RI), The Acting Studio (NY, NY), The National Black Theatre Festival (Winston-Salem, NC), The Goldman Theatre of the Jewish Community Center (Washington, DC), the American Theatre Project (Washington, DC), The Harmony Hall Regional Arts Center (Fort Washington, MD), and at the Source Theatre (Washington, DC). His most recent production was the premiere of his play RARA AVIS (Rare Bird), at Temple M in New York City in June 2009.  He is currently writing his first novel, Melting the Snow. He resides in New York City.
Matthew A.C. Cohen: Music
Matthew A.C. Cohen was born in 1989 in Merrick, New York. He has earned a B.S. degree in Music Composition and Theory, with a special interest in film scoring, arranging, and Jazz saxophone. Matthew has studied saxophone with Dave Pietro, Alejandro Aviles, Jeff Newell, and Andy Middleton, and studied Jazz improvisation and arranging with prominent arranger and pianist Dr. David Lalama. He studied composition with Herbert Deutsche, Dr. Matthew Van Brink, and award winning composer, Dr. Kenneth Lampl, and has an M.F.A in Scoring for Motion Picture at Columbia College Chicago.
 Simon Mas: Lyrics
After studying jazz and popular music in Italy for years, Simon Mas attended the prestigious Berklee College of music in Boston ending on the Dean's list for two semesters in a row. After arriving at Newcastle University in 2004, Simon was awarded entry to the Year Abroad Exchange Program on academic merits and ended up studying at the University of Texas in Austin. Upon returning to the UK, Simon earned a BMUS degree in Music in 2008 and a MMus degree in Composition and Musicology in 2009, both from Newcastle University. Since graduation, Simon has produced 3 albums and 1 EP.
W. Jeffery Jelks: Producer/Director
 As a theatre producer/director, it has been his pleasure to bring to life the eclectic work of these intelligent, colorful and prolific artists. The Further Adventures of Gussie Mae in America by  Letitia Guillory, Daddy’s Home,  Curious Child, Brussel Sprouts and Monsters by Renee Flemings; In the Dark with the Walter Lees by Wendell Edward Carter; Imperfection Flawed by Lillie Marie Redwood; Playin’ the Wall by Michael Mayson; Friend of the Family by Michael Monasterial; Watermelon, Git it While it’s Hot by CeCe Antoinette, and Oscar Grant’s Roommates were all directed by Jeffery in various venues in New York City, Maryland, Cincinnati, Connecticut and Texas. He also has served as Creative Consultant for the plays Grim Foster’s Love Songs by T. Tara Turk and Brown Gal’s Rising by Cece Antoinette.  Jeffery studied acting with Tony-award winning Uta Hagen and Oscar-winning Sandy Dennis and directing with Bill Alton. He was honored to be chosen as a participant in the prestigious Lincoln Center Director’s Lab and is a recent recipient of a 2013 Spring Lowcountry Quarterly Arts Grant.

story:
The Show

We're bringing Russian Roulette to the Edinburgh Fringe! A show that combines Russian literature and gambling! We're hoping to raise £2000 for accommodation, travel, marketing and theatre costs. Without it, we may end up having to live in the street and store our costumes in the sewer for the month. We've got a great venue in Just the Tonic at La Belle Angele and we're confident the show will be really well received at the Fringe, we just need that extra financial push to get us there!

What You Get

Now for the important bit, the perks of donating to us!

A £2 donation will get you a thank you tweet from the Russian Roulette twitter page!

A £4 donation will get you a thank you tweet and a picture of gratitude from one of the cast!

A £6 donation will get you a ticket to the preview at the Hounslow Arts Centre!

A £10 donation will get you a preview ticket and a thank you video from one of the cast!

A £20 donation will get you a preview ticket, thank you video and a handwritten letter from a character of your choosing!

A £30 donation will get you a preview ticket and a special Russian story podcast exclusively for donators!

A £40 donation will get you a preview ticket, thank you video, and a Russian Roulette T-Shirt!

A £50 donation will get you a video where an actor of your choice gets borscht thrown at them!

A £100 donation will get you 4 VIP tickets for the Hounslow Arts Centre Panto with drinks!

A £250 donation will get you Sullivan  Brown and William Seaward coming round your house to commentate on your FIFA games all evening!

A £300 donation will get you Jonathan Ashby coming round your house as a butler to serve you afternoon tea!

A £500 donation will get you William Seaward coming round and entertaining you and your guests with ghost stories all evening as well as a personal thank you at the end of every show!

A £1000 donation will get you Russian Roulette in your living room! We will do a show wherever you may be (as long as you're within the M25 or a reasonable distance away) and you'll get a personal thank you at the end of each show!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, don't fret, come and see us at the fringe or at our London preview on July 27th!

story:
(French below / version française ci-dessous) 

Why donate?

Very often, a Prix de Lausanne Prize Winner must do his/her own crowdfunding campaign to be able to pay for the expenses to get to his/her partner school or company. Thanks to your help, the dream will much more easily come true for two dancers!

1. Help the Audience Favourite AND the Web Audience Favourite Prize Winners 2019 to pay for their travels, hotels and food to get to their chosen partner school or company!

2. Contribute to open the doors to the world’s finest schools and companies for these young dancers.

3. Contribute to the Prix de Lausanne's mission which is to reveal the potential of exceptionally talented young dancers from around the globe by having them perform in front of a jury composed of world-renowned dance personalities.

What are the Audience Favourite Prize and the Web Audience Favourite Prize?

The funds raised by this campaign will be shared between both the Audience Favourite and the Web Audience Favourite Prize Winners. 

This Audience Favourite Prize reflects a “favourite preference” that the Beaulieu Theater’s audience has during the Finals. This prize rewards the Finalist having earned the most votes expressed by the audience the day of the Finals. To vote, send the code PDL followed by the number of your favourite Finalist to the number 939 (20 cents per SMS). Example: PDL 143. This service is only available to people with Swiss mobile phones.

The Web Audience Favourite Prize is attributed to the most voted candidate by the web spectators that watched the competition through the live streaming. Vote online directly on Arte Concert’s website the day of the Finals.

More information about the Prix de Lausanne, click here & do not hesitate to follow us on our social media: 
> Facebook
> Twitter
> Instagram

Photos: ©GregoryBatardon ©RodrigoBuas

Pourquoi faire un don ?

Très souvent, les lauréats du Prix de Lausanne doivent faire leur propre campagne de récolte de fonds pour pouvoir payer les frais liés à l'intégration dans leur nouvelle école ou compagnie partenaire. Grâce à votre aide, les lauréats 2019 du Prix du public et Prix du public web pourront plus facilement réaliser leur rêve !

1. Soutenez les danseurs qui remporteront le Prix du public et Prix du public web lors de la prochaine Finale du Prix de Lausanne, en participant à leurs frais de voyage, de logement et de repas pour leur entrée dans l’école ou la compagnie partenaire qu'ils auront choisie.

2. Aidez à ouvrir les portes des plus grandes écoles et compagnies de danse du monde à ces jeunes danseurs !

3. Contribuez à la mission du Prix de Lausanne qui est de révéler le potentiel exceptionnel de jeunes danseurs du monde entier en leur donnant l'opportunité de se présenter devant un jury composé des plus grands noms de la danse !

Qu'est-ce que le Prix du public et le Prix du public web ?

La somme récoltée lors de cette campagne de crowdfunding sera partagée entre les deux gagnants (Prix du public et du Prix du public web). 

Le Prix du public est l’expression d’un coup de coeur que le public du Théâtre de Beaulieu a pour l’un/e des finalistes. Ce prix est décerné au/à la finaliste qui remporte le plus de voix exprimées, dans la salle, le jour de la Finale. Pour voter, envoyez le code PDL suivi du numéro de dossard de votre finaliste préféré par SMS au numéro 939 (20cts par SMS). Ex : PDL 143. Seules les personnes ayant un opérateur suisse peuvent procéder au vote.

Le Prix du public web est décerné au candidat ayant remporté le plus de votes auprès des web spectateurs qui ont suivi le concours grâce au live-streaming. Les votes se font en ligne le jour de la Finale, directement sur le site d’Arte Concert.

Pour plus d'informations sur le Prix de Lausanne, cliquez ici & n'hésitez pas à nous suivre sur les réseaux sociaux : 
> Facebook
> Twitter
> Instagram

Photos: ©GregoryBatardon ©RodrigoBuas

story:
Short Summary

Kaleid Theatre (as in kaleidoscope, as in collide) is creating a new piece about hate and love and grief. Scape-ing is an exploration of hate in space and in the body, as well as a ritual of compassion. We need your help to reach the last 12% of our goal and bring this work to audiences in Philadelphia.

 

Description of the Piece:

We see hate all around. Hatred of seasons, colors, bodies, foods, accents, siblings, religions – everything in between and beyond. We watch as our neighbors eject lyrics, partnerships, strangers, dance moves, and children from their lives, communities, and country. We carry it too – in our veins and breath and fears and dismay. We find ourselves the recipients of hate one moment and then enacting it on others in our turn.

Scape-ing is an exploration of hate in space and in the body. Told through dance, poetry, and news articles, Scape-ing is a theatrical investigation of violent human emotions, a personal reflection on the first months of a new administration, and a ritual of compassion.

Scape-ing will be presented in partnership with The Drama Group in Germantown on April 27-29.

 

How can I help?

Well, we do need money, so anything you might be able to contribute will be deeply useful to us (we’ve gotten $5 contributions and $500 contributions in the past, and they both go a long way).

Even if you can’t donate, we are really excited about this show and the possibilities of being in community together, and we’d love it if you were able to attend and be part of that. We probably should have put this first, because it is the most important part for us. We really do hope to see you there.

It would also mean the world to us if you were able to share the show and/or this campaign. There are even share buttons on this page just for that purpose!

 

What is the money for?

We need money to pay for things you see on stage - make-up, props, costumes, possibly tomatoes (yeah, we’re thinking about tomatoes), etc. We need to pay for the things you see off the stage - programs, marketing postcards, our website, etc. We need money to pay for the behind-the-scenes stuff - toner so we can print research materials and script drafts, insurance, various fees, etc. We hope to invest in documentation, because we have been told by a few granting organizations that we would have stronger applications if we had better footage of our work. Most importantly, we need to pay people for their time, crafts, work, and dedication.

 

Who is Kaleid?

Kaleid Theatre (as in kaleidoscope, as in collide) is a multiracial, physical theatre ensemble dedicated to exploring the questions that our communities are asking right now. We are interested in how language, movement, music, and sound can come together to explore questions that are not easy to talk about through one sense alone, to reflect the complexity of human experience, and to shift our lens so that we can learn new things about our world.

Kaleid Theatre is a program of CultureTrust Greater Philadelphia, a charitable 501(c)(3) organization supporting diverse cultural practices in the Philadelphia region. CultureTrust Greater Philadelphia provides a charitable home and affordable shared management resources for arts and heritage programs of diverse disciplines and cultural traditions.

 

Photos by Saul Zayas.

story:
As dancers and artists, we are driven to make this world better than we find it, more beautiful and more special. 
We have traveled with our show from our humble beginnings - with your support since 2016 - to stages across the world. And have enjoyed bringing smiles and moving our audiences wherever we go. 
But what about the communities that can not attend our shows due to personal limitations? Who will think of them? Who will think of populations that  experience difficult mobility, less independence and more financial burdens due to aging? We do not forget their existence!
We seek to bring this special, touching experience of "BARRY: Mamaloshen in Dance!" to them, and YOU can make this happen. Your much needed financial support, NO MATTER HOW SMALL, will give us, the DANCERS, the means by which to travel to these communities. The Rainbow groups in Rockville, Maryland will be our first such venture and pilot older folks experience. We hope to continue bringing warmth to the hearts of those who have lived through so much and deserve our highest honor and respect. 

Even if we do not meet our total goal, your contributions will allow us to perform for our special friends at no cost to them, it will support the bread on our table and it will pay for our transport to and from the performance. 

 

The saddest part of reality is that we cannot reach all such communities. But we can make a difference, even f for a short while, at two of them. This initial visit will allow us to dip into what a successful tour for this cause is, and will grow our experience into even more seasoned outreach performers. 

If you can't personally contribute....

Please, please with urgency share this with friends whom you think might be able to contribute. One dollar at a time, we reach our goals. 

Thank You!!

Asya Zlatina and Dancers!

Black and white photos by Augustina Iohan Performance Photography, colored image by Frank Bicking.

story:
The Project

 

The project is a solo experimental dance piece. The dancer begins in an all white space with lighting done so that there are little to no shadows. As the music starts, she begins to dance. Suddenly, powdered paint starts to get thrown at her but she pays no attention to it. As the music escalates, the backdrop drops to reveal a logo, colored by the paint that was thrown at the dancer all this time. This whole time, we were coloring in the logo while people were focusing on the dancer. By shifting a colorless world to a world full of colors through dance and music, we aim at promoting the creative side of the company and to thus reinforce its mission by inspiring creativity in others.

 

The Vision

 

Growing up, I was raised in the world of ballet. Through shows and taking classes for several years, I have experienced both being in the audience and being on the stage. Even though I no longer dance, I haven't forgotten about it and all my ideas seem to shape around it.

I came up with this idea randomly about 4 or 5 years ago and somehow it has never left my mind. I finally have a chance to bring it to life and I think it is a comforting way to close off my time at New York University. I think that ballet is incredible and unfortunately hasn't really been in the spotlight for those who don't partake in the dance world so I want to bring it back by - literally - clashing it with art.

Ultimately, I seek to inspire creativity in others through dance. I want to show how art brings color into one's world, just like ballet brought color into mine as a child. 

I think this is a bold idea and I have a great and talented crew to help me out with it so I am extremely excited to see how it all comes together!

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Although I have part of the budget locked already, I still need to spend money on key areas such as equipment rentals, production design, and post-production. For this reason, I am seeking to raise $4,000 in crowdfunding. With your help, I would be able to make this project as close as it can be to my vision. 

In exchange, you can get various perks, from having your name in the credits to receiving BTS footage from the shoot to being an Executive Producer on the project!

Below is a detailed breakdown of how our budget will be spent: 

 

The Team

 

  Director - Alisa Traskunov 

Alisa Traskunov is a senior at NYU Tisch studying Film and Television. Although she has just recently started directing dance videos but has already found a great passion for it. She spends most of her time script supervising on various sets and during her spare time, you can find her either fencing or watching a movie or two. Alisa has had this current dance idea for many years now even before she started NYU and she is very excited to see it come to life!

  Producer - Thomas Monsellato 

Currently a sophomore at NYU pursuing a B.S. at the Stern School of Business and a B.F.A. at the Tisch School of the Arts, Thomas Monsellato is a NYC based Writer and Producer from France. He began his filmmaking career working on major French TV-shows such as Les Témoins. He then moved into producing, with experience ranging from multiple NYU Thesis films to a music video, a spec commercial, and "Grounded: The Roots of Revolution", a feature documentary about the current agricultural crisis.

  Producer - Ethan Kobrin

Ethan Kobrin is a sophomore at New York University working toward a B.F.A in Film and Television production. He has worked as an editor on many short films, and is currently editing a web series “Erotica 101.” Ethan has also been developing his skill as a producer, production managing and producing multiple NYU thesis films and TV pilots.

  Cinematographer - George Du

George Du is an NYC based director of photography. He began his filmmaking career shooting in Hong Kong for various corporate, charity, and fashion events. Since then, George has worked on different narrative and documentary projects, including his work as the 2nd Unit Photography for Filmmaker Oscar Boyson’s documentary “The Future of Cities.” He also works as a Focus Puller on independent level short and feature films. He is currently an undergraduate student pursuing a B.F.A in Film & TV Production at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts.

  Assistant Director - Josh Sheehan 

Josh Sheehan has significant experience in the entertainment industry. He is a sophomore, born and bred down under in Auckland, New Zealand, and studies at the NYU Tisch School of the Arts, with a major in Film and Television, his focus being on Cinematography and Directing. His work in the industry in both America and New Zealand has seen him hired in commercials, television shows and major feature films. Standout examples include full time employment on James Cameron’s Avatar 2; the Warner Brothers’ Meg; MTV’s The Shannara Chronicles Season 2; and Starz’ Ash vs Evil Dead Season 3. With three semesters under his belt at NYU, Josh has already amassed over 800 hours of student set work, with 600+ hours working on Upperclassmen sets, finding constant work as a 1st AC, as a 2nd AC and in G&E. The previous semester has found Josh chosen as a Director of Photography and as a Gaffer for intermediate and advanced shoots.

  Production Designer - Kasee Wang

Kasee is currently a junior majoring in Film and Television in New York University and during her time there, has worked on multiple intermediate and advanced projects in several capacities, mainly in the art department or in the producing/ production management departments. In the professional world, she currently holds an on-campus job at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts, and has worked at INE Entertainment in Los Angeles as a development intern. Back in Singapore when her journey in ﬁlmmaking ﬁrst started, she spent three years before NYU studying ﬁlm and during those three years made multiple projects both in a class setting and in a professional setting. She worked on two feature ﬁlm sets in Singapore: “Distance”, which opened the 2015 Golden Horse Film Festival, as part of the Art Department, and “Utter 2016”, which was commissioned by the National Arts Council of Singapore, as a key set production assistant. She also spent three months doing an internship in a post-production house, Infinite Frameworks, which partners with Warner Brothers Studios, HBO Asia, and Mediacorp.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

The fact that you read to the end already means a lot to us! Thank you truly!

To help us even further, you can simply spread the word to family, friends, and other acquaintances. No support is insignificant and any help we can get makes a serious difference!

Many thanks again!

Warm regards, 

The Blank Canvas Team
story_txt:
The Project
 
The project is a solo experimental dance piece. The dancer begins in an all white space with lighting done so that there are little to no shadows. As the music starts, she begins to dance. Suddenly, powdered paint starts to get thrown at her but she pays no attention to it. As the music escalates, the backdrop drops to reveal a logo, colored by the paint that was thrown at the dancer all this time. This whole time, we were coloring in the logo while people were focusing on the dancer. By shifting a colorless world to a world full of colors through dance and music, we aim at promoting the creative side of the company and to thus reinforce its mission by inspiring creativity in others.
 

The Vision
 
Growing up, I was raised in the world of ballet. Through shows and taking classes for several years, I have experienced both being in the audience and being on the stage. Even though I no longer dance, I haven't forgotten about it and all my ideas seem to shape around it.
I came up with this idea randomly about 4 or 5 years ago and somehow it has never left my mind. I finally have a chance to bring it to life and I think it is a comforting way to close off my time at New York University. I think that ballet is incredible and unfortunately hasn't really been in the spotlight for those who don't partake in the dance world so I want to bring it back by - literally - clashing it with art.
Ultimately, I seek to inspire creativity in others through dance. I want to show how art brings color into one's world, just like ballet brought color into mine as a child. 
I think this is a bold idea and I have a great and talented crew to help me out with it so I am extremely excited to see how it all comes together!
 
What We Need & What You Get
 
Although I have part of the budget locked already, I still need to spend money on key areas such as equipment rentals, production design, and post-production. For this reason, I am seeking to raise $4,000 in crowdfunding. With your help, I would be able to make this project as close as it can be to my vision. 
In exchange, you can get various perks, from having your name in the credits to receiving BTS footage from the shoot to being an Executive Producer on the project!
Below is a detailed breakdown of how our budget will be spent: 


 
The Team
 
  Director - Alisa Traskunov 
Alisa Traskunov is a senior at NYU Tisch studying Film and Television. Although she has just recently started directing dance videos but has already found a great passion for it. She spends most of her time script supervising on various sets and during her spare time, you can find her either fencing or watching a movie or two. Alisa has had this current dance idea for many years now even before she started NYU and she is very excited to see it come to life!
  Producer - Thomas Monsellato 
Currently a sophomore at NYU pursuing a B.S. at the Stern School of Business and a B.F.A. at the Tisch School of the Arts, Thomas Monsellato is a NYC based Writer and Producer from France. He began his filmmaking career working on major French TV-shows such as Les Témoins. He then moved into producing, with experience ranging from multiple NYU Thesis films to a music video, a spec commercial, and "Grounded: The Roots of Revolution", a feature documentary about the current agricultural crisis.
  Producer - Ethan Kobrin
Ethan Kobrin is a sophomore at New York University working toward a B.F.A in Film and Television production. He has worked as an editor on many short films, and is currently editing a web series “Erotica 101.” Ethan has also been developing his skill as a producer, production managing and producing multiple NYU thesis films and TV pilots.
  Cinematographer - George Du
George Du is an NYC based director of photography. He began his filmmaking career shooting in Hong Kong for various corporate, charity, and fashion events. Since then, George has worked on different narrative and documentary projects, including his work as the 2nd Unit Photography for Filmmaker Oscar Boyson’s documentary “The Future of Cities.” He also works as a Focus Puller on independent level short and feature films. He is currently an undergraduate student pursuing a B.F.A in Film & TV Production at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts.
  Assistant Director - Josh Sheehan 
Josh Sheehan has significant experience in the entertainment industry. He is a sophomore, born and bred down under in Auckland, New Zealand, and studies at the NYU Tisch School of the Arts, with a major in Film and Television, his focus being on Cinematography and Directing. His work in the industry in both America and New Zealand has seen him hired in commercials, television shows and major feature films. Standout examples include full time employment on James Cameron’s Avatar 2; the Warner Brothers’ Meg; MTV’s The Shannara Chronicles Season 2; and Starz’ Ash vs Evil Dead Season 3. With three semesters under his belt at NYU, Josh has already amassed over 800 hours of student set work, with 600+ hours working on Upperclassmen sets, finding constant work as a 1st AC, as a 2nd AC and in G&E. The previous semester has found Josh chosen as a Director of Photography and as a Gaffer for intermediate and advanced shoots.
  Production Designer - Kasee Wang
Kasee is currently a junior majoring in Film and Television in New York University and during her time there, has worked on multiple intermediate and advanced projects in several capacities, mainly in the art department or in the producing/ production management departments. In the professional world, she currently holds an on-campus job at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts, and has worked at INE Entertainment in Los Angeles as a development intern. Back in Singapore when her journey in ﬁlmmaking ﬁrst started, she spent three years before NYU studying ﬁlm and during those three years made multiple projects both in a class setting and in a professional setting. She worked on two feature ﬁlm sets in Singapore: “Distance”, which opened the 2015 Golden Horse Film Festival, as part of the Art Department, and “Utter 2016”, which was commissioned by the National Arts Council of Singapore, as a key set production assistant. She also spent three months doing an internship in a post-production house, Infinite Frameworks, which partners with Warner Brothers Studios, HBO Asia, and Mediacorp.

To help us even further, you can simply spread the word to family, friends, and other acquaintances. No support is insignificant and any help we can get makes a serious difference!
Many thanks again!
Warm regards, 
The Blank Canvas Team

story:
Douglas Dunn's Cassations is a suite for a dozen dancers set to operatic arias by Donizetti, Bellini, Bizet, Handel and others. Seven women activate chaos and serenity, five men power and submissiveness. The necessities of the two genders play out separately and together, combusting and adjusting accordingly. The dance takes place in the round. Inside the circled audience, in keeping with one of the title's meanings, sovereign authority annulling a final judgment, the drama of fragmentation/unification, modesty/inflation, and other dichotomies unfolds. The piece offers design and lighting by longtime collaborators Mimi Gross and Carol Mullins. 

Your contribution will go directly to paying the dancers' and production team's salaries. Seeing this visual feast, you will be glad you became part of our endeavor!

 

 

We'd love to see you at the show, too:

To be presented at the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Center

Friday, October 5th, 8:00 PM

Saturday, October 6, 8 PM

Sunday, October 7, 3 PM

2012

Tickets:

http://www.92y.org/tickets/production.aspx?pid=...

212 415 5500

story:
GLITTERHOOPZ by Lori

Hello Everyone, My name is Lori and I'm a hooper! What's a hooper? A good definition would be: a professional hula hooper or a person with extraordinary and original hula hooping skills. (Thanks Urban dictionary!) Being a hooper is my passion and my dream is to spread hoop love, through dance and fitness to people of all ages.  I currently work in the food and beverage industry, like a lot of performers and artists, but I dream of being recognized for my talent and being able to have a career doing what I love.  I am a trained educator, as well as a coach and a holistic wellness advocate.  I have been hooping for close to 3 years and it has changed my life.  I want to be able to help others do the same.  I have lost 35+ pounds since picking up a hoop.  I have created a design for my own brand of hoops and have begun working in my community to help spread the love of hooping, fitness and dance, to people of all ages.
 

MY CAMPAIGN

In my campaign, I hope to raise funds so that I can produce my brand of hoops and make them available to as many people as possible. With the funds raised I can purchase supplies for production, promotions and education. This is my dream but without the support of others, starting my own business would be next to impossible.  Given the opportunity, I know I can really make a name for myself and be successful in this endeavor.  My passion is contagious and my idea well thought out.  I truly believe that if you do what you love you will be successful.
 
Your contribution to my campaign will allow me to:
  • Purchase all necessary supplies, including but not limited to tubing, tape, connectors, and other design materials. 
  • Obtain Business licenses and insurance.
  • Assist in the purchase of promotional materials for vending and teaching.
  • Education opportunities for myself and my students.  Fitness Certification, studio rental, and development of educational materials for students and myself.
Without assistance, it would take me years to do all these things on my own.  I have been supported in my dream thus far, so I know the support exists and through this fund I can make it a reality.
 

MY GOAL

My goal is to raise $3500. I came to this amount by building my business plan and breaking down my needs into manageable pieces.  I have an order, based on necessity, that would make my business legitmate and able to flourish.
  • Supplies to develop my brand of hoops ($500).  
  • Patent and/or trademark my specialty hoop.($300-500)
  • Business license and insurance.($1000)
  • Signs and cards to promote my hoops($300).
  • Fitness certification so that I may teach in gyms, schools, and fitness studios.($1000).

If I receive funds through this campaign I will begin making hoops immediately.  That would be the jump start to get the business up and running.  I would then make everything legitimate and get my licenses and insurance. Education and Promotion would be my last investments. If I'm able to go beyond the $3500, it would be directly invested in Glitterhoopz, for more supplies, equipment (power tools, sewing machine), studio space, and continuing education.  I have the ability and drive to make this a complete and fully operation business, with hoops for sale and all licenses and certifications by July 2013 with the proper funding. This is my first dream that I can honestly say I am seeing through to its fullest.  I have been successful in my career and the activities I've participated in over my years, but this is something that encompasses my dreams, aspirations, my personality and my desire to teach and perform all into one.  

THE PERKS

The Perks for funding Glitterhoopz by Lori are pretty special.  

  • Anyone who contributes $25 will receive an intro to hoop dance video, created especially for this campaign.
  • For contributions of $100 or more, I will be creating a custom hoop and tutorial based on your specifications (ie: weighted fitness hoop, dance hoop or youth hoop).
  • For my biggest supporters, contributing $1000 or more, I will be gifting my very special Glitter Spinner Hoopz, with a custom tutorial and a thank you performance piece.  Glitter Spinners will be my patent pending & trademarked item and you would be one of the first ANYWHERE to have one!

HOOPING

Hoop dance and hoop fitness are becoming very popular (again).  One half an hour of hooping can burn up to 250 Calories!  It's an activity that can be done by anyone at any age.  It brings joy, health and strength to all who participate.  

I couldn't hoop AT ALL when I first picked up the hoop.  I have no memory of hula hooping as a child. I was drawn to it as an flow art, a form of dance and as an alternative fitness.  I began watching YouTube videos and have taught myself most everything on my own.  And now I want to share all that with the world.  It's totally possible to do something you thought you couldn't do and it can change your life.  I plan on contributing to the spread of this amazing tool, toy, and art form.  Anyone who contributes to Glitterhoopz by Lori will be spreading hoop love through your support.

Interested in seeing me in action?  I have videos on Youtube showing my hooping evolution. www.youtube.com/thislilpinky1 

 

If you are unable to contribute, please help get the word out.  Share my campaign with others or like and share my business page on facebook (http://www.facebook.com/GlitterhoopzbyLori).  All support is appreciated.  Thank you for taking time to learn about me, my goals and my passion: Glitterhoopz by Lori.

story:
Hello!

We’re Hartshorn – Hook Productions and we’re trying to raise £7000 to take Jon Brittain’s wonderful play Rotterdam to Brits Off Broadway this year in New York City.

‘No Alice, I don’t want to become a man, I just want to stop trying to be a woman.’

Rotterdam is the story of Alice and Fiona, a young couple who live in the Netherlands. It starts on the night when Alice has finally plucked up the courage to email her parents and tell them she's gay. But before she can hit send, Fiona reveals that he has always identified as male and wants to start living as one - named Adrian. Now, as Adrian begins his transition, Alice must ask a question she never thought she’d ask… Does this mean she’s straight?

Rotterdam is a modern story about gender, sexuality and being a long way from home. It shines a light on a kind of relationship that’s underrepresented on stage, and does so with honesty, humour and compassion.

We first read the play in 2015 when Donnacadh O’Briain approached us to produce it and we both immediately fell in love with it. We signed on to mount a production of the show at Theatre503, assembling an amazing production team and an absolutely stellar cast. They took the script we loved and created a beautiful production: we were delighted to have that rare experience when everyone involved in a show really loved it.

Since the very first performance, audiences and critics alike have embraced the show. Time Out said ‘Brittain’s play is another reminder – warm, witty and wise – of the stupidity of thinking that there are only two genders’ the Evening Standard called it ‘A hard hitting piece about love, gender and sexuality’ and The Stage said ‘Jon Brittain’s warm-hearted new play manages to speak eloquently about a complex issue while at the same time being properly laugh-out-loud funny’.

It sold out its run and transferred to the Trafalgar Studios in the West End, following which Jon was nominated for the Charles Wintour Award for Most Promising Playwright at the Evening Standard awards.

We applied for Brits Off Broadway, an annual theatre festival that showcases work from the United Kingdom, described by Charles Isherwood of the New York Times as 'a highlight of the theatrical year' in New York, and are delighted to have been accepted.

It’s a fantastic opportunity for everyone: for us, it’s a chance to take work we’re proud of to the theatre capital of the world, for our actors and creatives it’s an opportunity to make connections in the industry there. But most importantly, it’s a platform to share this story with more people.

However, mounting a production off-Broadway is expensive. Our budget is £50,000, we’re not eligible for public subsidy and due to the size of the venue we’re guaranteed to make a loss.

This is why we need your help to raise 14% of what we need to share Rotterdam with the people of New York.

This money will go towards:

  • £13,000 for the cast and creatives fees
  • £14000 for production and theatre fees
  • £6000 for accommodation for our cast
  • £5000 flights
  • £15000 we’ll need for general costs like visa’s, administration, marketing and extra travel. 

As you can see, we have a lot of money to raise, any help you are able to give is extremely valuable to us, and as a way of saying thank you we have some exciting perks to offer. Have a look to the right hand side!

For us, sharing this play with a New York audience is incredibly important. It speaks about relationships in a new and exciting way, it gets to the heart of what love is, what makes us love each other and what values we put on that love. Now, more than ever, we need stories like Rotterdam.
