story:
Help us get to NYC! 

The Shenandoah Dance Ensemble is going on tour! We have been invited to perform at The New York Jazz Choreography Project on Saturday, April 28 at 8:00pm and Sunday, April 29 4:00pm. 

jazzchoreography.com/project/april-2018/

The performance will take place at The Salvatore Capezio Theater at Peridance in NYC. 

 

Your contributions will go directly to:

  • Dancer travel costs 
  • Dancer per diem
  • Dancer lodging 
  • Dancer pay 

 

This event will give our students a real experience in what it's like to go on tour with a professional dance company. We need your help to make this possible! 

Any amount will be immensely helpful. 

 

We thank you in advance!

story:
About the Show

Follow struggling actor (VINNY) over the course of 3 weeks, as he tries to come to terms with his demons upon discovering he is about to become a father.

Highlighting the battle that rages inside one’s head at all times, but especially during moments of crisis in one’s life.

A Fear and Loathing Actor in Dublin is a dark, humorous and gritty play examining the great debate of art versus commerce, and the sacrifice artists face on a daily basis, in just trying to survive, and to live a ‘normal life’. Can we follow our creative urges and still have a life, or is it always to be a struggle? And is that struggle even worth it?

What We Need

In order to bring this wonderful piece of new writing to you at THEATRE@36, we are reaching out to our amazing community of artists and theatre lovers across the globe to help generate the necessary funds for A FEAR AND LOATHING ACTOR IN DUBLIN. 

Your donations will help pay for our Stage Design, Marketing, Actor and Crew Fees and necessary equipment to bring you a guaranteed exciting and moving production.

  Together with your support we will make this production a huge success!

Why support this Production of A FEAR AND LOATHING ACTOR IN DUBLIN.

By supporting this production, you are supporting new writing and local talent.

To find out more about Loft Productions Ireland and past productions, please click here.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

* Come see the shows. We have our first performance on 3rd September 2018.

* Tell your friends about the show and our campaign. You can help us spread the word! Use that share button and tweet, Instagram or Facebook share about the campaign and show. 

* If you would like to sponsor the production or find out more about getting involved, contact our producer Emma at loft.productionsireland@gmail.com
story_txt:
About the Show
Follow struggling actor (VINNY) over the course of 3 weeks, as he tries to come to terms with his demons upon discovering he is about to become a father.
Highlighting the battle that rages inside one’s head at all times, but especially during moments of crisis in one’s life.
A Fear and Loathing Actor in Dublin is a dark, humorous and gritty play examining the great debate of art versus commerce, and the sacrifice artists face on a daily basis, in just trying to survive, and to live a ‘normal life’. Can we follow our creative urges and still have a life, or is it always to be a struggle? And is that struggle even worth it?

What We Need
In order to bring this wonderful piece of new writing to you at THEATRE@36, we are reaching out to our amazing community of artists and theatre lovers across the globe to help generate the necessary funds for A FEAR AND LOATHING ACTOR IN DUBLIN. 
Your donations will help pay for our Stage Design, Marketing, Actor and Crew Fees and necessary equipment to bring you a guaranteed exciting and moving production.
  Together with your support we will make this production a huge success!
Why support this Production of A FEAR AND LOATHING ACTOR IN DUBLIN.
By supporting this production, you are supporting new writing and local talent.
To find out more about Loft Productions Ireland and past productions, please click here.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
* Come see the shows. We have our first performance on 3rd September 2018.
* Tell your friends about the show and our campaign. You can help us spread the word! Use that share button and tweet, Instagram or Facebook share about the campaign and show. 
* If you would like to sponsor the production or find out more about getting involved, contact our producer Emma at loft.productionsireland@gmail.com

story:
AVANTHARDCOLLECTIVE invite you to join them in the party at the end of the world. The rogue planet Nibiru, as predicted by internet conspiracy theorists, crashes into earth, and NIBIRU! presents society collapsing into the black-hole and having a wail of a time as it does so.

 

There are many ways to join the party. On August 6th you can join us in building a giant capitalism mother-monster. On August 7th you could be part of the cast if you like – drop us a line – and, of course, you can come and see it.

 

BUT, times are hard for sailors, and AVANTHARDCOLLECTIVE needs your help to make this show happen. We are looking to make £1000 to cover rehearsal space, marketing, set materials, art supplies, transport costs for our wonderful performers, and costumes. £1000 covers the bare minimum needed to get this show on in the way we want to, but we are more than happy to exceed the goal and for once stop being artists who always have to cut a million corners because they don't have a trust fund. That is to say, past productions like “The Third Policeman” and “Gargantua” were done on budgets of about £500 – wouldn't you be curious to see what we could do if we had £10,000? YES. Yes you would.

 

ABOUT THE ARTISTS

Ergo Phizmiz (PLC) has been making DIY music-multimedia-theatre for over 10 years across the UK and Europe, and experimental music, including nearly 1000 tracks of free, Creative Commons music, over the past 20 years. Despite sell-out tours and critical acclaim, they have never once successfully received UK arts funding to put on an independent production, and instead has relied on hustling and regular bouts of poverty to bring the magic to life.

 

Lottie (Depresstival) Bowater is the curator of London's longest running Avant-Hard night Depresstival Presents, which has provided a platform for experimental work from artists across film, performance-art, music and the left-field of comedy since 2011 and, again, runs at a perpetual loss.

 

ABOUT NIBIRU!

AVANTHARDCOLLECTIVE

presents

NIBIRU!

Reclaim (the end of) your world … make a difference

 

Everyone from flat-earthers to Slavoj Zizek is telling us that the end of the world is nigh, and one side of the spectrum or the other must be right. So why not celebrate the apocalypse with NIBIRU! the new techno-opera by “maverick composer” Ergo Phizmiz (PLC).

 

Hot on the heels of Mahogany Opera Group's sell-out tour of the electronic time-travel epic “Mozart vs Machine” and the controversial community-theatre apocalypse “The United Kingdom of Earth: A Brexit Opera”, Ergo Phizmiz (PLC) makes a return to Tête à Tête: The Opera Festival with this heavy slice of DIY agitprop collage theatre that continues in the quest to redefine opera completely in the 21st century.

 

The definition is this: 21st century opera is any kind of entertainment that uses performers, sound, image, and the cross-pollination of techniques and technologies to create analogue-digital / virtual-space-meat-space Gesamtkunstwerk. The future of opera has nothing to do with tiaras, bow-ties, and the operatic voice, and everything to do with the late 19th – early 20th century search by avant-gardists of “the total work of art” and the possibilities of this in the digital age. Fundamentally all you need to make an opera is a laptop and some willing friends.

 

And willing friends there are. In common with last year's presentations of “The United Kingdom of Earth” in London, Glasgow and Rotterdam, AVANTHARDCOLLECTIVE have gathered together a bevy of beautiful professional and non-professional performers to bring the end of the world to life. Watch as all your friends become estate agents, divinities, mythological figures, terrible children, social-network Gods, and secret-police. Society is collapsing and a giant, happy, tap-dancing celestial ball rapidly approaching earth has something to do with it. We really ought to have a party.

 

Ergo Phizmiz (PLC) / Dominic Robertson has been presenting music-theatre, opera and multimedia works, always somewhere under-the-radar, across the UK and Europe for a long time. Their productions have included “Gargantua”, “The Third Policeman”, “The Mourning Show”, “Gala”, “UOEIA: The Histories of Yodelling”, “The United Kingdom of Earth”, “Fulcanelli's Shoes”, and “Mozart vs Machine”. They are regarded by fools and wise men alike as a leading light and rabid experimentalist in the world of contemporary opera.

 

NIBIRU! premieres at Tête à Tête: The Opera Festival, RADA Studios, August 7th 2018.

 

Let the AVANT-HARD art through. Most of what we see and hear has been filtered through conversations between people with lots of money sitting in offices. Support the art made by artists who don't receive institutional or commercial support but carry on regardless, though the shit piles high and smells of estate agents. And no one wants to smell that.

story:
|||NEW CORPORATE PERKS ADDED|||


HADES and PERSEPHONE

Hades and Persephone is an original ballet film based on the Ancient Myth. 

The film will serve as the starting point for an original LIVE production mixing BALLET and FILM. The film will be used as a calling card for future production investment, but will also work as a standalone piece. Our previous Co-Production RAPUNZEL with Sisters Grimm and The Royal Ballet serves as an example of what can be accomplished on a low budget. 

Hades will be created using motion capture technology, to capture the movements of the Male Lead and CGI, the same process used for the creation of Gollum in lord of the rings. although he won't look like Gollum as that would be too weird.

**This will be the first ballet ever committed to film with a CGI dance partner!**

The Film will be shot in 3D using the brand new Red Epic rig.


Despite all of these impressive whizzbang effects, everyone is working on this movie for the love of it, without your donations we will not be able to shoot at all. 

This really is the chance to become involved in a first for dance and film. Donations start from as low as $5/ï¿½3 and can be made by credit card or paypal. If you can't donate please retweet, share, e-mail or Facebook this page as far and wide as possible. 

Thank you in Advance.


Hades and Persephone will be shot entirely on location 

(apart from the scenes in Hades of course).


THE CAST AND CREATIVES


Directed by 
Frazer Brown

Ballet Choreographed by 
TBC

Production Design 
Chrissic Design studio

HADES Concept Art by
 Fc Jab

Makeup by 
Amy Lacey
 at Bedazzling (TBC)

Costumes Supplied by
The National Theatre

We are hoping to secure the services of 
Costume Supervisor
Rosemary Burrows 
(Gladiator, V for Vendetta, Harry Potter)

Original music will be composed for the piece.

The rest of the production roles have yet to be filled, however, quality will be assured, on our last Ballet co-production our crew consisted of:

Peter Talbot- Director of Photography: Casino Royale, 28 Weeks Later

Gareth Tandy- Assistant Director: The Borrowers, Nanny McPhee

Chris Gill- Editor: 28 Days Later, Millions, Sunshine and 28 Weeks Later

Adrian Rhodes- Sound Engineer: The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas, Wallace and Gromit

Thomas Urbye-Colourist: Corpse Bride, Troy

Mike Figgis- Production Consultant: Leaving Las Vegas


THE STORY of HADES AND PERSEPHONE

The short will highlight key plot points in the persephone myth, but also serve as a standalone story.


A young Ballerina, practices alone in her studio, Lost in the music she dances into her imagination and through the changing seasons, Confronted by a stranger, she pursues him to find herself at the gateway of hell (hades), caught by the souls of the dead, she is slowly drawn below ground, she awakens to find herself back in the studio, , the glass starts to melt and hades appears aflame, they dance with passion as she transforms into the queen of the underworld, with a flash of flame Hades is gone as is any evidence of him being there. The Ballerina looks at her reflection and leaves, her reflection smiles knowingly and leaves one step behind her.


Where does the money go?

Every single penny will be spent on the final film, 

everybody involved is working for profit share. 

You will see the result of your donation in every frame of the film.


We appreciate these are difficult times, If you can't help us financially then please help us by spreading the word, the more 'Hits' we have the greater the chance of us reaching our goal or maybe even making the front page of Indiegogo in thier 'featured' films and projects.

IF YOU CAN'T HELP FINANCIALLY, 

PLEASE HELP US SPREAD THE WORD

Please Follow us on TWITTER, FACEBOOK, VIMEO and PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE take the link for this page and post it anywhere and everywhere you can:

Myspace, Linkedin, Vimeo, Twitter FACEBOOK,

e-mail old college roomates, long lost relatives, anyone.


We will love you forever.

story:
We want to make Unknown Artists known.

Play Club was started two years ago and we’ve already come so far! We have active clubs in Los Angeles and New York with over 350 people, collectively, on our email lists.  The club gives actors, directors and writers in New York and Los Angeles the opportunity to... play.

THE UNKNOWN ARTISTS -  The Unknown Artists mission is to provide opportunities for talented, unknown individuals to thrive on a stage enabling them to show off their gifts of music, acting, dance, comedy, film and all categories of art. Founded in 2007 by Pamela Eberhardt and Emily Clark, the Unknown Artists search far and wide for an explosive amount of talent that is of a specific, unheard of, untraveled artistry.

What We DO

Play Club of the Unknown Artists has been focused on:

  • Table Readings
  • STaged Readings
  • Scene Workshops
  • Full productions
  • Musical Sing Alongs
  • Original work workshops
  • sketch comedy and improv
  • And MUCH MUCH more…

But these things cost money. We have BIG plans to produce more STaged readings of original and published work along with full productions of new material. Spaces cost money. It can cost up to $2500 to rent a space for a week! Our money would go to help ease the cost of these spaces and other necessities of producing theatre. When we produce our Scene Nights (Which can cost up to $250 each time we do it) we video tape our actors in their scenes. This helps them with their REELS and gives them footage for their websites and certain audition submissions. With better camera equipment we can give them quality footage to use for these important tools in their career. 

If we don’t reach our goal of $4500, any money we DO make will still go into the club, but we will then trim down the GOAL list for the remainder of the year.

If we go OVER our goal of $4,500, any additional money we make will be split between us and Play Club West!

Why You Should Donate

Acting classes and several theatre clubs in New York cost money to be a part of and there are so many talented people out there who don’t get the opportunity to participate in artistic activities due to time or finances. Play Club gives so many creative people the chance to do what they love to do with out having to commit to a strenuous schedule and with out having to pay a membership due.

What People in Play Club are Saying:

"ACTOR FRIENDS! If you want to be in an acting class, but don't have the money. Or if you want to be in a play, but can't commit to a full rehearsal schedule, then you need to come join PLAY CLUB! Staged readings of new and established works every week! It's a lot of fun and it's an excuse to work on a piece for some time. If summer has been slow for you, then THIS IS WHAT'S UP! COME ON OUT AND JOIN!!!” - Carson Higgins (Play Club West member)

"I want to thank you for a good night. It was lovely to meet everybody, watch everyone work and to work on my cold reading technique in a casual atmosphere. I learned a lot and enjoyed myself doing so. I look forward to attending and reading at the Play Club readings in the future. Have a great night.” - Jessica Levesque (Play Club East member)

story:
Running Candles

A choreographed film by Michelle Ramos

Location: University of Pittsburgh’s Cathedral of learning – please view photographs for suggested shooting spaces. There is also the possibility of using two nationality rooms: Turkish and English.

Project description:

Can light be danced, can shadow?

Light is expansive and there are various approaches to investigating this phenomenon. For instance, light can be connected to temperature, and color may elicit emotion. For Running Candles I have used the image of candlelight as home base for specificity.

The illumination a candle creates reminds one of paintings by Rembrandt or Caravaggio, of the chiaroscuro effect. It illuminates only so much of an area, creating mystery and some shadow. I love that play of light. In addition, the flame is not static it flickers, sways, threatens to consume itself... and once the flame is blown off, smoke figures emerge, moving.

These were some of the shapes and actions explored in creating the movements for the dance.

Why film at the Cathedral of Learning?

The various ways light filters through the glass windows of the cathedral reveals the beauty of juxtaposing light with shadow. It reveals impressive details of architecture, design, and invites the senses to imagine stories. To imagine the lives of people of diverse nationalities and age groups coming together to share spaces.

Through the Cathedral pathways and arches, three encounters will take place and the stories of people will intertwine.

Examples:

Oliver and Rita: Age range: 60’s – 70’s

 Mar and Maia: Two little girls, age range: 8-12

 Luca and Michelle: Age range: 20’s – early 30’s

They will encounter one another through impromptu stone staircases that all of the sudden surprise one. They will meet via dance conversations while sitting in long wooden tables underneath incredibly high ceilings, where the echoes of their human voices can be carried throughout the space, inviting whisper.

What will the dancers-actors do at the cathedral?

Dancers will perform short choreographed dance sequences in site-specific locations inside/outside the cathedral. Examples:

Oliver and Rita – Older couple, will perform a hand dance sequence while sitting in a wooden table. Attention will be given to the ways in which they look at one another and how the light falls creating contrasts of light, thus having contrasts in meaning.

Mar and Maia – The girls will be filmed underneath a table playing, whispering in each other’s ears in semi-shadow.

Luca and Michelle – Neoclassical dance sequence in various spaces, an impromptu staircase, a nationality room and outside the cathedral.

Total of people present during the film:

Director and choreographer: Michelle Ramos Filmmaker

Filmmaker: Maira Duarte and two camera assistants

Performers:

Bob Vickrey, Lisa Wimer, Ewen David, Isabella Velasquez, Rachel Vilano, Evelyn Kitchen-Stevens, John Mattwews, Caitlin Grater, Luca Sbrizzi, Ella Mason, Yiz Hang, and Kim Clay - with possible additional extras.

Shooting Date: July 23rd 2014 

Fudget as follows:

Cathedral fee $300

Event liability insurance with rush fee $480

Film materials rental and filmmaker fee total $800

Director choreographer and performers compensation total: $ 1100 (varying depending on scenes and work time). This amount is much lower than desired - however would be nice to receive something if possible.

Total: $ 2,680

Director and choreographer: Michelle Ramos FilmmakerFilmmaker: Maira Duarte and two camera assistantsPerformers:Bob Vickrey, Lisa Wimer, Ewen David, Isabella Velasquez, Rachel Vilano, Evelyn Kitchen-Stevens, John Mattwews, Caitlin Grater, Luca Sbrizzi, Ella Mason, Yiz Hang, and Kim Clay - with possible additional extras.Shooting Date: July 23rd 2014 Fudget as follows:Cathedral fee $300Event liability insurance with rush fee $480Film materials rental and filmmaker fee total $800Director choreographer and performers compensation total: $ 1100 (varying depending on scenes and work time). This amount is much lower than desired - however would be nice to receive something if possible.Total: $ 2,680

story:
Hey Everybody. Well we are doing it thanks to your generous help. By Tuesday morning, November 18, we passed the $3000 target we had set over the previous weekend.  Then the afternoon of November 26 we hit $5000. YAY!!!  Please contribute ASAP so that we can reach our goal in this final day of our campaign. The clock is ticking! Thanks again to all of you - Jim

MORE NEWS:


"The First Light" project has launched a "Say NO to Endless War" campaign with silent peace processional events around the Bay Area.

We are committed to the interface between arts and activism through this project. We encourage you to join us in supporting this important work, as well as in participating directly. Our next event is today, Saturday, November 29, at 12:30 PM, at Castro and 18th streets in San Francisco.  Weather permitting, of course.


Hello, my name is Jim Berenholtz.

THE FIRST LIGHT is a theatrical work-in-progress that originally emerged out of "The First Light Pilgrimage for a Nuclear Free Planet”.
I spearheaded this pilgrimage with other San Francisco-based performing artists Nancy Wang and Robert Kikuchi-Yngojo, along with Hiroshima survivor Takashi Tanemori in the summer of 1999.

Between 1999 and 2000 I developed a basic storyline, and wrote and recorded three songs, which I share here as a perk.

The story of "The First Light" spans the entire Nuclear Age, from 1945 until now, and explores not only the nuclear issue, but the very roots of war and violence that are so embedded in the human experience.

Following the onset of the Fukushima nuclear disaster,  which is tragically still not over, I have felt the call to finish developing the characters, writing the script, and composing the rest of the music for the show.

The initial funding goal will provide the seed money I need to do a detailed outline of all the characters and scenes in the show, with complete text for at least a few scenes, plus composing and recording of three more new songs for the show. These new songs include the titles "Fukushima is Here", "The Violence Inside Us", and "Dracula's Drug".

Then, with seven complete songs plus a substantial amount of the script, I will shop THE FIRST LIGHT to theater companies or producers, and get the backing I need to fully finish the work.

In short, this funding will help cover my living costs so I can focus my energy on creating, as well as pay for a preliminary recording of the three new songs.

Please don't delay. The time is now.

With your support of THE FIRST LIGHT, I will explore and illuminate what is certainly one of the most critical issues of our time.

Even simply sharing this campaign with your friends and family will help!

Thank you for being an agent of positive change.

SPECIAL VIEWING TODAY!!!-Here's an example of one of my past theatrical productions. Excerpts from the 2003 Hollywood performance of "Temple of the Cosmic Serpent",   a ritual dance theatre extravaganza created by Jim Berenholtz along with a diverse team of dancers, musicians and live snakes.

story:
MarDelDance, a local non-profit dance company aimed at introducing audiences as a whole to dance-drama by incorporating dance with music, art, acting, and multi-media, made its way to the nation's capital last year. MarDelDance has been commissioned for the 2nd year to perform at Gallaudet University as part of the school's spring dance concert. Gallaudet University is a federally chartered university for the education of the deaf and hard of hearing located in Washington, D.C. It was the first school for the advanced education of the deaf and hard of hearing in the world, and is still the only higher education institution in which all programs and services are specifically designed to accommodate deaf and hard of hearing students. The Gallaudet Dance Company is a performing group of approximately 15 dancers. Each dancer's background is different-both in terms of hearing loss, preferred communication mode, secondary school education, and current major field of study as a University student. But all the dancers are excellent communicators. They rely on their vision as their primary mode of communication and communicate through their dancing in a range of styles, including dance that uses American Sign Language as its foundation.  

MarDelDance last year was asked to perform their renowned piece Patsy, an edgy, mysterious and unpredictable solo. Patsy represents the struggles of a girl who is still attached to her past while trying to live and move forward in the present. This theme also resonated greatly with the students of Gallaudet University who live their own struggles every day in their communities. Dancer Jen Gill and choreographer Marianne Delehanty also won Dance Magazine's Editor's Choice Award for Patsy in 2009. Since then, Patsy has evolved to include David Smith, fellow dancer, and has been performed in Philadelphia, New York City, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and now Washington D.C.. 

 MarDelDance's artistic director and choreographer had this to say about the experience at Gallaudet University, "I feel extremely humbled by these performances. It's truly astonishing how dance crosses all boundaries... emotional, cultural, and especially physical. The deaf dancers at Gallaudet are remarkable and have made me appreciate the power of dance and renewed the love I have for what I do." 

Dancer Jen Gill, whose parents are both deaf, also had this to say, "Growing up around deaf culture this was my first time at Gallaudet and surrounded by deaf dancers. The dancers and this experience was amazing!" 

MarDelDance will be performing a NEW work at this years showcase and needs your help to get there!

story:
ABOUT US

The xodus dance collective is a magnet of dancers drawn together to fuse several voices into one body. An eclectic blend of ideas and concepts, the xodus dance collective seeks to merge extreme forms of movement into one integrated language.

Established in New York in 2006, the collective merges dancers of diverse experiences and backgrounds into one shared experience. Artistic director, Karen Gayle’s ‘slice of life’ choreographic approach explores both unique and common perspectives of life.

Offering a glimpse from a wide shot or close up angle on scenarios that affect the human journey and day to day living, Gayle continues to create different methods that touch audiences through their senses. Sculptural, pedestrian, athletic, fluid, spoken dance theatre, the collective fuses all styles and techniques into one unified movement. 

The ensemble has had the opportunity to perform on many stages and venues across the nation including; Jacobs Pillow - Inside/Out Festival, The Riverside Theater, The Ailey Citigroup Theater, Manhattan Movement Arts Center,  Steps Studio Theater, Movement Research at the Judson Church, The Downtown Dance Festival, The John Ryan Theater, Govenor’s Island and The Queen Elizabeth Theatre in Toronto, Canada. 

This summer the collective will have the privilege of performing it’s first full length evening work at HERE in New York City. The performance runs Thursday August 15th - Sunday August 18th in the Dorothy B. Williams Theatre. The company will premiere TRIGGER, a dance theatre production that journeys into the inferno of street riots.  It plunges through time, dissecting the boiling point of individual and collective frustration. From Detroit 1967, to New Delhi 1984 to Los Angeles 1992, TRIGGER takes a glimpse at the powerful yet destructive side of the human condition and the anatomy of a riot.

Performed by a magnificently talented and innovative group of artists including: Elizabeth Douglas, Marielis Garcia, Adelita Hinojosa-Martin, Carlos Kerr Jr., Samuel Turner and Lisa Nicole Wilkerson. 

These extraordinary individuals selflessly dedicate their time and talent towards creating new, dynamic work. The result is a family of dancers that continue to grow and nurture each other and the process.

 

HOW TO GET INVOLVED...BECOME A PRODUCER!

We are extremely excited, anxious and nervous to present this new work. Every time an artist creates a new piece it is both personal and sacred and is kept close to the heart, until you the audience is invited to share in the experience, making it whole.

A production is a process. It requires several components and elements in order for it to occur. For this we need your support. Help us produce this 4 night run and give birth to our new work.

Whether you have seen our work before, or are new to the xodus dance collective’s ‘slice of life’ experience, there is something for everyone. As a supporter, you get the opportunity to contribute to the production, receive an autographed poster, attend a rehearsal  (live or via skype), meet the ensemble and speak with the choreographer. You can help breathe life into the arts.

Your funds will go DIRECTLY to production resources, including payment for the artists, lighting design, set design, costumes and rehearsal space. Absolutely every penny counts and will be accountable.

 

THE IMPACT

Why this production?

There are endless dance, theatre, performance productions currently trying to emerge. And that is good news for the arts. But, how do you select which one to support? Why this campaign?

xodus dance collective has a history of producing work that is for everyone. Whether you are a dancer, teacher, doctor or waiter, there is something for you. We touch on every day scenarios and frame our narratives in a slice of life window, giving you a glimpse into a moment of time.

TRIGGER takes a look at three historical events and compares individual frustration to collective outrage. Ride the roller coaster of emotions as we move through time experiencing the full circle of life.

We understand that times are tough. We are just recovering from one of the toughest financial disasters this century and as always the arts takes a hit stronger and longer than other areas. 

There are other ways you can help. Spread the word. Share our link. Tell people about our show and tell them to tell people. It takes a village...

story:
Short Summary

Seminar by Theresa Rebeck is the FIRST production by Vancouver's brand-new 'Stages Theatre Co.'

Who is Stages Theatre Co.? Stages Theatre Co. consists of three emerging artists, colleagues, and friends, each with a vision: Stages Theatre Co. is committed to creating rare opportunities for artists with passion and integrity, working towards establishment in the theatre community. The company does so by presenting thought-provoking, ballsy, and often humorous works that we consider to be relevant, engaging, and, quite simply, a good f***ing time. 

What are we doing with this project? 

Vancouver has a vast arts community and theatre is at the forefront of it. Unfortunately, like many other artists, we are constantly searching for material that we can sink our teeth into. Even with the wealth of productions in Vancouver, there is a lack of opportunities for artists to nurture their process and to allow their work to thrive. This project is here to change that. We seek to establish a passion driven company, to feature some of the finest talent in Vancouver, and to create a learning experience that culminates in a great production.

What is Seminar?

In Seminar, a provocative comedy from Pulitzer Prize nominee, Theresa Rebeck, four aspiring young novelists sign up for private writing classes with Leonard, an international literary figure. Under his recklessly brilliant and unorthodox instruction, some thrive and others flounder, alliances are made and broken, sex is used as a weapon and hearts are unmoored. The wordplay is not the only thing that turns vicious as innocence collides with experience in this biting Broadway comedy.

Who are we?

Devon Busswood

Devon's background spans many disciplines, having explored film-making, singing, acting, dance, directing, and writing. At the age of 14, she wrote and produced her first short film, The Tenants, for the North Shore Film Festival, ultimately winning several awards, including 'Best Picture'. She went on to write, produce, and direct two subsequent films, both of which were also honored at the Festival. Though she has a deep passion for film, Devon’s true love is musical theatre. Recent credits include: Kate in Legally Blonde (TUTS); Dora in Fiorello! (APPLAUSE!); Daisy Hilton in Side Show: In Concert (FCP); Ashley in Changing Minds and Kate in Zanna, Don’t! (Awkward Stage); and Rosalind in Moon Over Buffalo (Metro Theatre). Additionally, Devon was recently honored with the 'Outstanding Newcomer Award' at the OVATION Awards, an award which recognizes talent, ambition, focus, and ability to continue to contribute to the musical theatre community of the lower mainland. Watch for Devon this March as Betsy Bear (and others) in Carousel Theatre for Young People’s Busytown! She couldn't be more elated to be involved in the creation of Stages Theatre Co. and is thrilled to have the opportunity to bring Seminar to the Vancouver theatre community. Alex and Cory: you are such inspirations to me. Thank you for your endless support and fervent friendship.

Cory Haas

Cory is an actor, director and a little bit of everything else in between. He is a recent graduate of Capilano University from where he hold an ASAS diploma and a Bachelor of Performing Arts degree. Acting credits include: Simon in Statu Quo (La Seizième), a role that he originated;  Lord Farquaad in Shrek The Musical (Align Entertainment); Cary in a staged reading of Proud by Michael Healey (CapU/School Of Communication); J.H Rogers in Titanic: A New Musical, Jenkins in How to $ (TUTS); Man in 7 Stories, Frederick Fellows in Noises Off, Reverend Hale in The Crucible (Exit 22), and many more! Directing credits: Legally Blonde (TUTS/Assistant), The Boyfriend, Hello Dolly! (Exit 22/Assistant). Cory co-created and performed in Naked Love, at the Vancouver Fringe Festival along with Tiffany Anderson. He has conceived pieces for FUSE and the PuSh Festival. He is thrilled, proud and honoured to be debuting Stages Theatre Co. with Seminar in Vancouver. Thanks to Devon Busswood and Alex Strong for being anchors in this busy adventure.

Alex Strong 

Alex left New Brunswick 4 years ago to study acting at Vancouver’s Studio 58. Select credits for Studio 58 include Spring Awakening, Attempts on Her Life, Balm in Gilead. Other theatre credits include Hair, Songs for a New World, Company, The Threepenny Opera, Tommy, Godspell, Hamlet, Bunked, and How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. Alex has also spent time directing and choreographing for the stage and in 2012 he was assistant director for The Gateway’s Fidddler on the Roof. Other achievements include Canada’s National Voice Intensive (2011), Bachelor of Arts Degree (English, Theatre, Psychology), and the recipient of the David Pritchard Theatre Arts Award. Alex has experience leading a theatre company back in New Brunswick and looks forward to this new opportunity to independently produce theatre in Vancouver with the inspiring artistic talents of Cory Haas and Devon Busswood.


What We Need & What You Get

• We need a minimum of $3000 to cover the costs of: 

                 Rights 

                 Venue 

                 Production Costs and Contracts

• We have some exciting and unique perks to offer you, from tickets to backstage tours. Check out our perks page for more information!

The Impact

The impact is simple: we're creating valuable opportunities for actors, directors and designers in this city. With your donation, you can be apart of this challenge and know that you have had a hand it making quality theatre come to life. 

We are aware that producing theatre in Vancouver is difficult. This is the simplest, yet largest, challenge that any theatre company has to go up against. There are a few reasons why: saturation, funding, and public appeal. We are more than aware of these factors but are determined to be a solution seeking company and one that works and fights hard.

How will we overcome these risks and potential setbacks?

* Going up against other companies

This is healthy competition to have in any art form. The fact that we are new and don't have a following yet, just lights a fire under our ass. We strongly believe that the material we are choosing to produce separates us from much of the theatre in town. We also believe that the public that is funding this project is ready for something new and exciting, something that includes seeing new actors, directors, designers, stage managers, and technical crews. With the emerging talent assembled, we are full of inventive and innovative ways to make this production a reality and we are ready to overcome anything that comes our way.

* Not having enough money

Theatre is expensive. That is the reality. We have worked hard to make this production cost effective, while keeping our artistic integrity and the director's has vision in tact. Even with the generosity of our Indiegogo backers, we are constantly looking for alternative sources of funding to accommodate our tight budget. Unfortunately, there is always the possibility that we will be short, financially speaking. For this, we have already come up with ways to edit and evolve Seminar without losing the production value and integrity of this stellar text. Whether it be altering designs, playing with new ideas, or working overtime, we are ready to change and progress. Theatre is a living art form and it is absolutely necessary to know how to work with these challenges.

* Being unique, yet appealing to the general public

The biggest artistic challenge of this production. Reviews and criticism aside, we want to get as many people as we can to take a chance on a new company and come enjoy this wonderful play. We're confident in our production and our artistic values. We will be up night and day to prove to our patrons that we are worthy of a spot in the Vancouver theatre scene. Our company is seeking the patronage of a new generation of theatre-goers, while accommodating the current audience demographic present in Vancouver.


We are a group of extreme professionals and the three of us share very different histories that complement our method of work. We all have had a few years of experience in this industry and we love it. We wouldn't be here if we didn't. We are committed to our craft and just beginning a long journey in the theatre. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for help of all kinds, monetary and otherwise. If you would like to volunteer to work as an usher, box office attendant, or just to help us get the word out, please email: stagestheatreco@gmail.com

• Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. All of your help can and will make a HUGE difference for us!

• Please share this page with your friends and family. (Use the social media share tools to do so!)

• We need A LOT of books to fill out our book shelf set pieces. If you have any books that you would like to donate, please let us know!

The Impact
The impact is simple: we're creating valuable opportunities for actors, directors and designers in this city. With your donation, you can be apart of this challenge and know that you have had a hand it making quality theatre come to life. We are aware that producing theatre in Vancouver is difficult. This is the simplest, yet largest, challenge that any theatre company has to go up against. There are a few reasons why: saturation, funding, and public appeal. We are more than aware of these factors but are determined to be a solution seeking company and one that works and fights hard.

How will we overcome these risks and potential setbacks?

* Going up against other companies

This is healthy competition to have in any art form. The fact that we are new and don't have a following yet, just lights a fire under our ass. We strongly believe that the material we are choosing to produce separates us from much of the theatre in town. We also believe that the public that is funding this project is ready for something new and exciting, something that includes seeing new actors, directors, designers, stage managers, and technical crews. With the emerging talent assembled, we are full of inventive and innovative ways to make this production a reality and we are ready to overcome anything that comes our way.

* Not having enough money

Theatre is expensive. That is the reality. We have worked hard to make this production cost effective, while keeping our artistic integrity and the director's has vision in tact. Even with the generosity of our Indiegogo backers, we are constantly looking for alternative sources of funding to accommodate our tight budget. Unfortunately, there is always the possibility that we will be short, financially speaking. For this, we have already come up with ways to edit and evolve Seminar without losing the production value and integrity of this stellar text. Whether it be altering designs, playing with new ideas, or working overtime, we are ready to change and progress. Theatre is a living art form and it is absolutely necessary to know how to work with these challenges.

* Being unique, yet appealing to the general public

The biggest artistic challenge of this production. Reviews and criticism aside, we want to get as many people as we can to take a chance on a new company and come enjoy this wonderful play. We're confident in our production and our artistic values. We will be up night and day to prove to our patrons that we are worthy of a spot in the Vancouver theatre scene. Our company is seeking the patronage of a new generation of theatre-goers, while accommodating the current audience demographic present in Vancouver.We are a group of extreme professionals and the three of us share very different histories that complement our method of work. We all have had a few years of experience in this industry and we love it. We wouldn't be here if we didn't. We are committed to our craft and just beginning a long journey in the theatre. 
Other Ways You Can Help
We are always looking for help of all kinds, monetary and otherwise. If you would like to volunteer to work as an usher, box office attendant, or just to help us get the word out, please email: stagestheatreco@gmail.com

• Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. All of your help can and will make a HUGE difference for us!
• Please share this page with your friends and family. (Use the social media share tools to do so!)• We need A LOT of books to fill out our book shelf set pieces. If you have any books that you would like to donate, please let us know!

story:
After years of marriage, David and Anna are splitting up. Everything is going smoothly until they must decide who keeps the couch. In the biggest fight of their relationship, this couple must decide whether the couch - and their marriage are worth saving.

OUR STORY

ABOUT THE LOVESEAT 

Scantily Glad Theatre premieres the full-length version of The Loveseat, written and directed by S.E. Grummett at the PotashCorp Fringe Theatre Festival in Saskatoon from July 30th-August 8th. 

Written at the Saskatchewan Playwrights Centre's 24-Hour Playwriting Competition, The Loveseat placed 2nd in the student category. In December 2014, the play was shown at the Drama Students Association One Act Play Festival in the Department of Drama at the University of Saskatchewan. Since its creation, the play has undergone a series of developmental workshops to evolve it into a full length production. 

The Loveseat is created entirely by U of S Department of Drama students, S.E. Grummett (writer/director), Kelly McTaggart (actor), Kyle Kurchirka (actor) & Yvonne Addai (stage manager). 

ABOUT SCANTILY GLAD THEATRE

Founded in 2014, Scantily Glad Theatre is a Saskatoon-based theatre company. Our goal is to create original work that provokes laughter, emotion and thought. The Loveseat is the first Fringe show for the company. 

WHY TELL THIS STORY?

As a child of divorce, The Loveseat is a very personal work. Much of the play’s thematic content come from my personal experiences which I would describe as an amalgamation of my parent’s divorce (quoted directly in the play as the “Best Divorce Ever”) and my own failed relationships. When I first wrote the play, I had just gone through a messy break-up. My own feelings of inadequacy, heartache and frustration are mirrored in the characters. And for those reasons, The Loveseat was an amazing form of catharsis (get dumped, write a play!). Staging The Loveseat equally terrifies and excites me as an artist and I both love and cringe at bringing it to an audience. Despite what I’m sure is a challenging road ahead, I am thrilled to be bringing this show to audiences this summer at the Saskatoon Fringe. 

-S.E. Grummett (Writer & Director)  

OUR TEAM

Yvonne Addai (Stage Manager) is a third year drama student at the University of Saskatchewan, working towards a BFA in acting to pursue a career in film. Addai has assisted in stage construction for Eurydice and Better Living (Greystone Theatre)and costumes for Our Country's Good (Greystone Theatre) . Most recently, she has worked as the assistant stage manager for Vernon God Little (Greystone Theatre) directed by Dwayne Brenna, and stage managed the first production of The Loveseat at the DSA's One Acts Festival. Addai has also played the role of Toby Gaddarn in Coram Boy (Greystone Theatre) directed by Natasha Martina. 

S.E. Grummett (Writer & Director) is a director, filmmaker and actor from Saskatoon. Last summer, she made her directorial debut for the stage with The Legend of Bone Creek (FLoYD Youth Theatre Festival), and her short play Junk Mail was shown at both the U of S We the Artists collaborative showcase and LadyBits Improv comedy night. Both shows were co-directed with her partner-in-everything, Caitlin Zacharias. Grummett has also worked as an actor in Coram Boy (Greystone Theatre). This spring, she won the Department of Drama's Best Student Director for her work on The Loveseat. Grummett also directs for the screen. Her first feature, Paper Airplanes, premiered at the Yonkers International Film Festival in New York and she has made a number of short films including Dust, Paper or Plastic?, & Broken Image. Grummett is currently in her final year of BFA Acting at the University of Saskatchewan with a minor in Digital Culture & New Media. 

Kyle Kuchirka (Actor) is super psyched to be a part of Scantily Glad's newest version of The Loveseat. He is currently on the tail end of obtaining his BFA Acting degree at the U of S and has had a total blast getting to riot for the past four years in the Department of Drama. Being a part of Greystone Theatre was a party for sure! Kyle's acting credits during his time at Greystone include Junior (Better Living), John Arscott (Our Country's Good), Brad Pritchard (Vernon God Little) and most recently Meshak Gardiner (Coram Boy). All good times!

Kelly McTaggart (Actor) is a recent graduate from the University of Saskatchewan BFA Acting Program. She most recently worked with the Saskatoon Opera on Madama Butterfly moving props, waving fans, etc. McTaggart is currently auditioning for literally everything that she is allowed to. This will be her third Fringe season in Saskatoon, but her first (in two shows this year) with this little clothing. So please donate to our project so that she can be tastefully underdressed instead of being undressed because we're too poor for costumes. In her free time (which is rare), she enjoys nope-ing people on others' Tinder accounts, fighting in catsuits and making money for Fringe shows.  

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS

Theatre ain't cheap. And as students, it can be difficult to feed yourself anything more than ramen noodles, let alone fund a show! But by supporting us through this campaign, you will be helping us bring this show from script to stage.
Our budget is as follows: 
Fringe Application & Venue Costs: $1000.00
Printing & Advertising Costs: $250.00
Equipment Rental: $150.00
Set & Props: $100.00
TOTAL: $1500.00
By raising these funds prior to the Fringe, we are able to use our ticket sales to pay our team and support future creative projects.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please, share this campaign with your friends, family, loved ones, exes, allies and nemeses. If you are in Saskatoon, please come out and see our show! You can support us by being a member in the audience and sharing in a laugh. 
PotashCorp Fringe Theatre Festival (Saskatoon) is in its 26th year of operation. The festival runs from July 30 to August 8, 2015 in various venues in around the Broadway area.
Venue: Oskayak 
Saturday, August 1st        7:15
Sunday, August 2nd         8:45
Monday, August 3rd         2:40
Wednesday, August 5th  5:35
Thursday, August 6th      8:40
Friday, August 7th             7:15
Saturday, August 8th      2:45
Tickets: $14, on sale in July
*MATURE AUDIENCES ONLY: Sexual Content, Language* 
Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/scantilygladtheatre

Thank you for your support!

story:
Los Angeles-based ensemble theatre company Say Yes! Collective proudly presents its inaugural production, Land of the Ice Bears, a world premiere dark comedy co-produced with the acclaimed Hollywood Fringe Festival.


Written by Jacob Cribbs and directed by Rob Adler, Land of the Ice Bears is set in a surreal world where art and language collide, where words are weapons. On a scorching summer afternoon in Virginia, high society siblings Mason and Madeline break away from their brother’s engagement party. To escape the mundane, they dive into the magical realm of their innermost dreams. But when a sensitive debate goes too far, the party takes a drastic turn as secrets are challenged, and the pair is forced to examine lingering questions about their relationship and the future.

We hope this play will spark a conversation. What does it mean to sacrifice everything for your art? How far are you willing to go? It's a difficult conversation, and one that each of our characters struggle with--the audience will be in for a roller coaster ride.

Initially we budgeted for a fully self-financed production, but as we face theatre rentals, registration fees, marketing and publicity costs, and paying our stage manager and director, our goal is simply to break even. Each contribution will ensure this beautiful play is fully realized, allowing us to share it with as many people as possible. Thank you so much for your support.


About Say Yes! Collective: 

Formed in 2015 with the mission of advancing new and fresh ideas, Say Yes! Collective represents a coalition of actors, playwrights, directors and theatre artists committed to creating art in a mutually respectful and safe space. When artists are willing to say yes to the unknown, an unlimited and boundless experience of creation can occur. We say yes to cross-pollinating different talents from different walks of life to create even more expansive and vibrant stories. We say yes to encouraging women to have a strong voice and to be seen. We say yes to enriching and giving back to our communities. In an artistic landscape where it is much easier to say no, we choose to Say Yes!

story:
Friends, Thebans, Countrymen

In ANTIGONE, a brisk, new translation lead by Sarah Sharp is paired with a production steeped in ancient theatrical practice, featuring fully sung-and-danced choruses and three actors performing all of the major roles.

PROGENY brings the central themes and core story of Antigone to the present day, recentering the eternal conflict between divine and secular law on today's struggles over women’s reproductive rights. Set in the present moment, Progeny asks "What would Antigone look like if it happened now?"

EXTANT ARTS has developed this pairing of an original work and a new translation into a theatrical conversation on the cost of certainty and the consciences behind our hubris.

The Gang's All Here (Except You)

Director Greg Taubman
Producers Chie Morita and Courtney Harge
Set Designer Anshuman Bhatia
Costume Designer Lux Haac
Lighting Designer Elizabeth A. Coco
Composer/Sound Designer Shane Parks
Choreographer Allison Brzezinski
Stage Manager Jenny Ainsworth
Company Manager Allie Lalonde
Marketing Manager Glenn De Kler
Assistant Director Marlee Faye Koenigsberg
Production Assistant Katey Howitt

Featuring Virginia Baeta, Jack Berenholtz, Rick Busser, Pëtra Denison, Nicole Greenbaum, Brandon Tyler Harris, Zane Johnston, Russell Jordan*, Teresa Lotz (Violin), Tony Neil*, Maureen O’Boyle, Aden Ramsey (Guitar), Quinn Warren

*These Actor's Appear Courtesy of Actor's Equity Association

What We Need & What You Get

"ANTIGONE is one of those plays that you read in high school and think you know," says Director Greg Taubman, "but I've been challenged again and again through this process just how complicated Antigone and Creon are as characters."

Your support will allow EXTANT ARTS to tell these powerful and important stories in a profound way in December 2012 at the Connelly Theater in Downtown Manhattan. Recently presented in partnership with Columbia Stages, ANTIGONE/PROGENY is exploring a transfer that will only be possible with your help.

BONUS: Every person who gives $50 or more will receive a pair of FREE TICKETS to the show in DECEMBER!

EXTANT ARTS is offering one-of-a-kind gifts and experiences in recognition of your donations to ANTIGONE/PROGENY.

Έχουν αντίκτυπο! (Have Impact!)

ANITGONE/PROGENY proves that certainty can be costly; only slightly more costly than presenting two shows in repertory. Your gifts will not only catalyze a dynamic reexamination of the original story of nonviolent protest, but also support the remarkable team of actors, musicians, technicians, and designers that make this work possible.

Every dollar you give goes directly to support the production's costs.

The Oracle Has Spoken: Here's How You Can Help

There are many ways to support ANTIGONE/PROGENY:

  • Donate!
  • Tell your friends to donate!
  • Like Extant Arts on Facebook and Follow Extant Arts on Twitter!
  • Come see the show December 1-9, 2012 at the Connelly Theater!
  • If you saw the workshop production at The Riverside Church, October 17th - 20th, DONATE OVER $50 TO SEE IT AGAIN FOR FREE!

Boilerplate (Or The Stuff That's So Awesome We Say It All The Time)

Extant Arts Company is dedicated to engaging audiences in a welcoming, challenging, rigorous and free-wheeling conversation about our shared stories. By combining excellent productions of enduring works from diverse traditions with the development of innovative projects that speak directly to the way we live now, our goal is to dream a more creative, dynamic, and resilient community into being. 

Since its founding in 2006, Extant Arts Company has produced high-quality productions from the classical canon coupled with exciting and profound new work in venues throughout the New York metropolitan area. Committed to continued engagement with enduring stories, Extant Arts' dedicated artists and staff have explored the works of such luminaries as Euripides, Shakespeare, Chekhov, Ibsen, Feydeau, and Schnitzler, as well as contemporary voices like Rebecca Gilman, and Ellen McLaughlin, all while working with schools to foster a passion for theatre in the next generation.

story:
In Short

Chicago theatre has a strong and beautiful history of New Plays and New Work. But many new play development centers in Chicago cater toward established writers, leaving emerging artists at a loss for opportunity. This May, Carina Abbaticchio is directing Juli Del Prete's The Art of Losing, a fresh new play brought to life by the newest generation of Chicago theatremakers. This project will be the first in a cycle of readings and world premiere productions showcasing up-and-coming talent in Chicago’s new work community.

What We're Asking For

We are asking for your help and partnership. It is vitally important to us that our actors and designers are both paid for their work and provided with the funds and supplies they need to fully utilize their artistic abilities. For The Art of Losing, we are need to raise $6,250 for renting a performance space at The Den Theatre, production budgets for our design team, marketing for the show, and most importantly, giving our artists payment for their hard work on this project.

To date, we have already raised over $3,800 in funding, volunteer work, and in-kind donations and have secured our performance space at The Den. With the help of the internet magic of crowdfunding, we hope to push ourselves up to an operational budget to get through production.  

$10 will give us one of the many buddha statues we need on stage! $15 will give us a pair of intimidating surgical scrubs!  $100 will help compensate a designer or actor for their hard work and commitment to this production. 

Here's where are money is going and has gone!

$1,300 - marketing, insurance, auditions

$2,700 - cast/designer payments and budgets

$2,250 - Venue rental and Tech fees.

The Play

“For the 86th consecutive autumn, the Red Sox are not going to win the World Series.”


So proclaims the Boston Globe at the height of the 2004 American League Championship Series. Boston’s beloved Red Sox are down three games to none against their rival Yankees, and the curse keeping them from a championship is as strong as ever. To break that curse? It would take a miracle.


The Red Sox have devoted fans in Brett, Holly, and Dominic - three siblings who are less than lucky themselves. When their father disappears, leaving them in the care of their estranged Aunt Peg, their family might be in more dire need of a miracle than their team. Hoping for a victory on or off the field, Brett prays to every possible deity.Dominic seeks answers in statistics. And as losses pile up, Holly uncovers a clue to their father’s whereabouts. Against impossible odds, is there still a way to win?

Big Picture

This is going to be more than just a singular excellent production. This is going to be a model for our contemporaries. The success of this production will enable the success and development of more productions for years to come. Our producing team is committed to finding new artists and voices and after we've done it successfully once, we'll be able to program more and more opportunities for artists we haven't worked with before, or haven't even met yet.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're looking for other ways to help and support - first things first, come see the play and bring your friends! The production is Pay What You Can, so anyone and everyone can enjoy it. You can also volunteer to tear tickets at our box office if that is fun for you, or you can simply send this link around in case someone you know might be interested - word of mouth is the best advertising theatre can get! 

Please email matthewbmoynihan@gmail.com with any questions, requests, or to get involved!

But many new play development centers in Chicago cater toward established writers, leaving emerging artists at a loss for opportunity. This May, Carina Abbaticchio is directing Juli Del Prete's The Art of Losing, a fresh new play brought to life by the newest generation of Chicago theatremakers. This project will be the first in a cycle of readings and world premiere productions showcasing up-and-coming talent in Chicago’s new work community.What We're Asking ForWe are asking for your help and partnership. It is vitally important to us that our actors and designers are both paid for their work and provided with the funds and supplies they need to fully utilize their artistic abilities. For The Art of Losing, we are need to raise $6,250 for renting a performance space at The Den Theatre, production budgets for our design team, marketing for the show, and most importantly, giving our artists payment for their hard work on this project.
To date, we have already raised over $3,800 in funding, volunteer work, and in-kind donations and have secured our performance space at The Den. With the help of the internet magic of crowdfunding, we hope to push ourselves up to an operational budget to get through production.  
$10 will give us one of the many buddha statues we need on stage! $15 will give us a pair of intimidating surgical scrubs!  $100 will help compensate a designer or actor for their hard work and commitment to this production. 
Here's where are money is going and has gone!
$1,300 - marketing, insurance, auditions
$2,700 - cast/designer payments and budgets
$2,250 - Venue rental and Tech fees.

The Play
“For the 86th consecutive autumn, the Red Sox are not going to win the World Series.”
So proclaims the Boston Globe at the height of the 2004 American League Championship Series. Boston’s beloved Red Sox are down three games to none against their rival Yankees, and the curse keeping them from a championship is as strong as ever. To break that curse? It would take a miracle.
The Red Sox have devoted fans in Brett, Holly, and Dominic - three siblings who are less than lucky themselves. When their father disappears, leaving them in the care of their estranged Aunt Peg, their family might be in more dire need of a miracle than their team. Hoping for a victory on or off the field, Brett prays to every possible deity.Dominic seeks answers in statistics. And as losses pile up, Holly uncovers a clue to their father’s whereabouts. Against impossible odds, is there still a way to win?

Big Picture
This is going to be more than just a singular excellent production. This is going to be a model for our contemporaries. The success of this production will enable the success and development of more productions for years to come. Our producing team is committed to finding new artists and voices and after we've done it successfully once, we'll be able to program more and more opportunities for artists we haven't worked with before, or haven't even met yet.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you're looking for other ways to help and support - first things first, come see the play and bring your friends! The production is Pay What You Can, so anyone and everyone can enjoy it. You can also volunteer to tear tickets at our box office if that is fun for you, or you can simply send this link around in case someone you know might be interested - word of mouth is the best advertising theatre can get! 
Please email matthewbmoynihan@gmail.com with any questions, requests, or to get involved!

story:
The Basics

We are the Demented Dolls of Sideshow, an international all-female freakshow troupe bringing our bizarre brand of ridiculosity to the universe. We bring together performers from Germany, Norway, France, Israel and the USA, and although we're over the moon about our stellar cast, it's costlier to put together a tour when we bring in ladies from around the world.

The Dolls did a highly successful European tour in the spring of 2015: not only did the audience adore the show, but it was the most (legal) fun we'd had in awhile! We immediately decided to continue pushing the show. As we progress, we are building the name and bringing more people into our weird world: if this American tour does well, we hope to tour Australia and Europe in 2017. Today, the east coast of the USA; tomorrow: THE WORLD! We're here to ask your help to get this show on the road! All contributions go directly to the cost of travel, printing merchandise, and hard-to-find props that have to come from Europe.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's our approximation of what it will cost to get us into and around the States. We're not including the daily costs of food/accommodation, as we hope to stay with friends along the way and eat cheaply on the road (as a general rule, we feed and shelter ourselves with any profits from merchandise).

  • 3 European-USA round trip flights: $2000
  • Van rental: $1700
  • Gasoline: $800 (estimated, ocourse)
  • Needles for the Princesses: $350
  • Merchandise printing: $550

Curious why these numbers don't add up to the exact amount we're trying to reach? We've already received sponsorship donations from the immensely awesome companies of Gorilla Glass Jewelry, Kraken Jewelry, Sacred Symbols Jewelry, and The Squidling Brothers Circus Sideshow. If you're interested in sponsoring the tour directly, email dementeddolls <at> gmail <dot> com.

The Impact

  • Get involved with our show, even if you can't see one of these American events. Your support brings us that much closer to performing in your city. Message us and tell us where you'd like to see us in the future!
  • Although this is our first time doing an electronic crowd-funding project, we've always been supported through direct sponsorships by companies, donations from individuals that want to see more of us on the road, and by putting our own money into the show that we love.

Risks & Challenges

  • This is a relatively new show that hasn't established itself in the US (hence us doing this tour!). There's every chance that we'll arrive in a city and the show tanks, with very few tickets sold. What then? Between the 6 Dolls on this tour, we have nearly 100 years of performance experience. However, that doesn't guarantee us an audience. If we don't have an audience, we don't sell any merchandise, and we don't eat that day. (That can light a serious fire under your ass to promote the show!)
  • Thankfully, we have friends. We have an immense backing of people around the world that want to see us succeed, and our network of industry professionals will help us spread the word. Yes, touring is HARD work. Yes, we're INSANE for locking 6 girls in a van for a month with lots of sharp objects. But we love what we do, so we are working to heavily promote every new show that confirms on the tour. We'll be pushing for media interviews and appearances in every city, and with the booking wisdom of the amazing Squidling Bros. Circus Sideshow, we are approaching every market with years of experience. And, yes, we're crossing ours fingers, toes, eyes, and tongues, because a lil' extra can't hurt! 
THE PERKS!
Here's a few images of our available perks, containing show collectibles and handmade curiosities, among other goodies!

Custom Paintings!

Looking at that VIP meet and greet perk? Here's our tour list:

May 4 The Slipper Room, NYC - SOLD!!!

May 6 The CEC, Philadelphia, PA

May 8 Roxy & Dukes Roadhouse, Dunellen  NJ

May 11 Shriners, Greensboro NC

May 12 Odditorium, Asheville NC

May 13 Flying Monkey Arts, Huntsville AL

May 15 Mag’s 940, New Orleans LA

May 18 Cosmic Charlie's, Lexington KY

May 19 Cobra Lounge, Chicago, IL

May 20 Smith's Downtown Tap & Grill,  South Bend IN

May 21 Hastings/Tangent Gallery, Detroit MI

May 22 Smarty Catz, Ypsilanti MI

May 25 The Foundry, Cleveland OH

May 26 Smiling Moose, Pittsburgh PA

May 27 Connie's Ric Rac, Philadelphia PA

May 28 Coney Island, NYC - SOLD!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • No money to donate? That's A-OK! Help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! You can share this campaign easily using the IndieGoGo SHARE buttons.

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Short Summary

Hey, Mahoney family and friends!  Lots of folks have asked us when and how they can help support Gwynn's first step into the Irish dance big leagues, so we set up this Indiegogo page to make it convenient and easy! 
 
She's come a long way from the little 4 year old we enrolled in Irish dance classes.  Gwynn is now working on her Preliminary Champion dances (the second highest level of competition).  This November she'll take her first trip to Oireachtas - the regional competition where dancers can qualify for the National and World Championships!   She's not old enough for Worlds yet (a couple more years), but her teachers think she has a shot at being in the top 10 at Oireachtas and qualifying for the North American National Championships in Montreal, Quebec next summer. 
 
To compete at Orieachtas (and beyond) Gwynn needs her first solo dress.  We're getting a DEAL at $1200 (yep, they really cost that and more!) because one of her teachers is a dress maker.  Please don't feel in any way obligated to contribute!  But lots of family and friends have asked to help out, so we thought this would be an easy way to let you know it's time.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need

  • A beautiful solo dress for Gwynn's first competition with the Scariff Hardiman School in September (Oireachtas in November!). (We'll post the mock up here soon, but rumor has it, the dress might have the Mahoney family crest on the cape.  We think that's pretty awesome.)

You get

  • Our undying gratitude!
  • A handwritten thank you letter from Gwynn for your sponsorship
  • A photo of Gwynn in her new solo dress
  • Bragging rights!

story:
"Oscar Wilde's most delightful, timeless comedy of them all"

 

Theatre Mill

Theatre Mill is an establishing professional theatre company based in Yorkshire. Inspired by our nation’s love of classic literature, we are focused on bringing people together for a shared, theatrical experience to be remembered. Quite simply - we tell amazing stories within stunning, carefully crafted surroundings.

Our shows are designed to be special, by optimising our regional heritage roots we like to go that extra mile. Theatre Mill audiences are invited to spectate, we are not an immersive company. Audiences feel safe, secure and above all enthralled within the world we create.

 

Theatre Mill cordially invites you to be the guest of Mr Algernon Moncrieff…

Witness first-hand the social follies and misdemeanours that take place this summer at York Mansion House in this sparking, witty and light-hearted play of aristocratic manners and high society. 

Enjoy a sumptuous afternoon tea* during your visit to the country, courtesy of Mr John Worthing. Discover the truth behind the deceit in Oscar Wilde’s most delightful, timeless comedy of them all. 

Directed by Samuel Wood

 

Family Mill Scheme

Now on to the matter in hand. This is an initiative for all of our current and future Theatre Mill productions. Put simply, for every scheduled performance we set aside one of our Family Mill Tickets (2 adults & 2 children). These are free tickets for charities and organisations based in and around the wonderful City of York. 

Now we turn to our community and industry supporters and make a simple request - please consider becoming a Family Mill Sponsor. Making a donation will truly help towards achieving our targets. Your donation will directly enable a disadvantaged family to come and watch one of our shows too. 

 

How do I become a Family Mill Sponsor?

This is the truly easy part, read our exciting options and sponsor away. Please be aware that the campaign is not in place to cover production costs.

Its sole purpose is to raise the sponsorship needed to fund the Family Mill Scheme and nothing else. The show is booked, tickets go on sale Friday 7th June, pulling together as a community will enable us to make the arts more accessible to all, for Earnest and beyond…

For further information: www.theatre-mill.co.uk

story:
PRODUCERS DOMINIC PAOLILLO AND LAWRENCE LERITZ CONTINUE THE JOURNEY TO NEVERLAND FOR RON PAOLILLO

RECENT PUBLICITY:

EDGE ON THE NET - APRIL 1st, 2014

BROADWAY WORLD ARTICLE - March 31, 2014

BROADWAY WORLD - March 11, 2014

THE ADVOCATE - March 7, 2014

"A devoted cousin is crowdsourcing in an attempt to produce The Lost Boy by Ron Palillo, best known as Welcome Back Kotter's Horshack." 

BY BRANDON VOSS - The Advocate


HORSHACK WAS MY COUSIN -

AND WAS THE BEST FRIEND OF MY PRODUCING PARTNER LAWRENCE LERITZ.  (Producer of the Off-Broadway hit, Boobs! The Musical)


BROADWAYWORLD ARTICLE WRITTEN BY LAWRENCE ON RON'S PASSING & LEGACY


THE LOST BOY - BY RON PAOLILLO

NEW YORK CITY DEBUT - SUMMER/FALL 2014  - Initially an Off-Broadway workshop, with the intent to continue to Broadway. The show is currently in pre-production with auditions slated for June 2014. 

                              The brilliance of the writing is amazing.

After Ron's untimely death in 2012 his dream of personally bringing this brilliant show to Broadway ended. We are committed to changing that beginning with your help!!!! 

This campaign will help pay for an Equity Showcase or Festival Production with plans to do a larger scale after that. A Broadway run is planned. We have already met with a number of producers. Having an outlet for them to see and hear this play will enable them to commit. Even if you are unable to contribute PLEASE FORWARD the campaign! When you forward to your friends the word is spread which will in turn help this project.

"The Lost Boy" tells the story of writer James M. Barrie and his creation of "PETER PAN." Despite finding success and fame as a writer, James M. Barrie is dissatisfied with his work and his life. He returns to his hometown in Scotland to visit his mother, who still blames him for the long-ago death of his older brother in a skating pond. Haunted by the tragic accident and his mother's harsh words, James slowly begins to confront his family's tragic past with the help of an unexpected friendship and his own gift for storytelling. This fictionalized account of the birth of Peter Pan warms the hearts of audiences everywhere who remember the magic and mystery of The Boy Wouldn't Grow Up" - BROADWAY.COM

In The LOST BOY - J. M. Barries brother Davey is the inspiration for Peter Pan. 

He drowned in an ice skating  accident at the age of 12 and truly was the boy who never grew up. The writing of Peter Pan in many ways helped James deal with the loss.

SCENE SNIPET BEFORE THE DROWNING:

DAVEY’S VOICE- JAMIE!

JAMIE-He’s alive! He’s alive! 

(He summons up the strength of mind to inch his way out onto the ice to save his brother. He carries one ice skate with him. He looks down and helplessly screams in fright.) 

DAVEY! I CAN SEE YE!

(He takes skate and beats on the ice with the point of the blade.) 

But, I’m too small and my arms too weak and the ice too thick and my body’s tired to aching; but I won’t stop! I have to save him! I scream and chip the ice. I cry and chip the ice. I pray and chip the ice.

Davey is trying to find the hole he fell through, but he’s lost all sense of direction and the hole isn’t where he thought it was. I look again and see his face grow dimmer and smaller as the pond’s inky depths engulf him. DAVEY!!! 


A SNIPET AS THE NEVERLAND STORY STARTS TO DEVELOP:
JM BARRIE- No. This little boy has just been kidnapped.

MAUREEN- (With no little concern.) Kidnapped??

JM BARRIE- By Fairies. (She gasps.) Even now they are flying him in his perambulator to- (Goes to window.) Come here. Please. ( She obeys.) See that star? (MAUREEN points.) No, not that one. That one. The second star. To the right.

MAUREEN- Yes I see it, I think. Why?

JM BARRIE- That’s where the Fairies are taking him. To a tropical island called Neverland.

MAUREEN- Neverland?

JM BARRIE- A land where no one grows up.

MAUREEN- (Quite concerned.) But he’s a baby! How will he take care of himself? How will he survive?

JM BARRIE- (At a complete loss.) Well, quite frankly, I hadn’t thought of that. (Has she sparked his imagination?) Uh- there is an island, not very big, just East of Neverland. It’s an ‘islet,’ actually, and very drab in comparison to the sun-drenched multi-colored wonders of the bigger island. In fact, this islet is so remote, that the sun has almost forgotten to shine on it. As if it wasn’t aware of its very existence.

This will be the first NYC production since publication in October 2013.

PLEASE FORWARD!! 

SCRIPTS ARE AVAILABLE THROUGH PLAYSCRIPTS.COM or at The Drama Book Shop here in NYC. This play is destined to be a classic.

*Note: previous productions before the official publishing of the script were performed at at The Helen Hayes in Nyack, NY and The Queens Theatre in Flushing, NY and the G STAR Performing Arts School in Palm Beach Gardens, FLA
