story:
Summary

This Side of the Blue is a classical baroque music concert, infused with contemporary folk tunes, electronic sounds, and shadow images, that tell the story of the coming of age of a young water-nymph.  Led by love, magic, and mischievous creatures, our water-nymph travels through a fantastic world of light and darkness to find her place among the forces of nature. Her quest is paralleled by the piece’s objective to find it’s place in the world of music and image.


This show is a collaboration between Elizabeth Windnagel and Alex Hathaway and many other talented artists! Elizabeth has made music for shows at Open Eye Figure Theater and In the Heart of the Beast Puppet Theater. She has also been involved with Mixed Precipitation's Picnic Operetta. She is a classical singer and super collaborator!  Alex has been drawing and telling stories since his schoolboy days.  This is what he loves to do.  Both his visual and stage work are in frequent collaboration with Open Eye Figure Theatre and Theatre Forever.


TSOTB is an originally written fairytale told completely through music - like a ballet or a silent movie! It also showcases classical music in a fun and accessible setting. It's so many things! Baroque music! Shadow puppetry! Electronic music! Animation! Folk music!


An experience for all ages and walks of life. We want to share this story with everyone. And we want to bring people together so we can experience it as a community. We are dedicated to keeping ticket prices low so all may attend!

What We Need & What You Get 

Where the money is going:

- lazer cutting puppets / puppet materials / projectors 

-screen for the shadow puppets

-paying musicians and puppeteers! Original art and music for you! See below!

-keeping ticket prices low

-venues

Perks

Original art and music for you! See below!

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell people about it!  Share this page with your friends and family!  Who knew copy+paste could do so much?  Her you go:  http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/this-side-of-the-blue/x/6665331
story_txt:
Summary
This Side of the Blue is a classical baroque music concert, infused with contemporary folk tunes, electronic sounds, and shadow images, that tell the story of the coming of age of a young water-nymph.  Led by love, magic, and mischievous creatures, our water-nymph travels through a fantastic world of light and darkness to find her place among the forces of nature. Her quest is paralleled by the piece’s objective to find it’s place in the world of music and image.This show is a collaboration between Elizabeth Windnagel and Alex Hathaway and many other talented artists! Elizabeth has made music for shows at Open Eye Figure Theater and In the Heart of the Beast Puppet Theater. She has also been involved with Mixed Precipitation's Picnic Operetta. She is a classical singer and super collaborator!  Alex has been drawing and telling stories since his schoolboy days.  This is what he loves to do.  Both his visual and stage work are in frequent collaboration with Open Eye Figure Theatre and Theatre Forever.TSOTB is an originally written fairytale told completely through music - like a ballet or a silent movie! It also showcases classical music in a fun and accessible setting. It's so many things! Baroque music! Shadow puppetry! Electronic music! Animation! Folk music!An experience for all ages and walks of life.  We want to share this story with everyone.  And we want to bring people together so we can experience it as a community.  We are dedicated to keeping ticket prices low so all may attend!What We Need & What You Get Where the money is going:- lazer cutting puppets / puppet materials / projectors -screen for the shadow puppets-paying musicians and puppeteers! Original art and music for you! See below!-keeping ticket prices low-venuesPerksOriginal art and music for you! See below!Other Ways You Can Help Tell people about it!  Share this page with your friends and family!  Who knew copy+paste could do so much?  Her you go:  http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/this-side-of-the-blue/x/6665331

story:
In response to so many of my wonderful friends who have lovingly asked me...

"HOW CAN I HELP YOU?"

YOU CAN GIVE EVERYONE A CHANCE...

"Give EVERYONE a chance"...I BELIEVE in giving the underdog a voice, artistic expression, cultural diversity, opening hearts and minds, finding clarity in complexity, unleashing curiosity, imagining new vistas, honoring nature, honoring humanity.

"HOW CAN YOU HELP???

YOU can help US promote LIVE THEATRE and Performing Arts Education,

Award winning Actors, Producers, Directors, and Teachers, husband and wife team, JIMMY FERRARO and DEE ETTA ROWE, will open Jimmy Ferraro's STUDIO THEATRE this June, in the Tampa Bay area, at 5732 Main Street, in Historic Downtown, New Port Richey, FL.  The STUDIO THEATRE is perfectly nestled among Restaurants, quaint  Antique Shoppes and Art Galleries.

The intimate "STUDIO THEATRE", is located in the historic SIMS Building. The Ferraro's will lead a company of theatrical professionals, devoted to preserving the American Art form of LIVE Theatre, by developing and presenting new works and seldom seen plays and musicals, as well as classic favorites.

The FERRARO STUDIO THEATRE is a professional theatre company, working together with Actors' Equity Association, the professional union of theatrical actors and stage managers in the United States, under a Special Appearance Agreement.

Our commitment to connecting actors and audience is built into the very architecture of our STUDIO, seating 68 patrons. No theatre in the Tri-County operates in such an exclusively intimate space.

The FERRARO STUDIO THEATRE offers an intimate viewing experience, where every seat is "a good seat", and the minimalist "black box studio" setting allows the art of LIVE theatre to be uniquely explored, pure and unadorned, focusing on the story and the actors, without distraction.

In addition, the STUDIO will be offering instruction in Voice, Acting, and Musical Theatre, preparing the current and next generation of LIVE Theatre performers and audiences. An annual scholarship fund will be established to benefit a student(s) with financial need.

A BIT OF the HISTORY of NEW PORT RICHEY

On Jan. 1, 1926, the New Port Richey Press reported:

FAMOUS MILLIONAIRES OF BROADWAY BUY IN

NEW PORT RICHEY
Thomas Meighan and Paul Whiteman, Irving Berlin, Sam H. Harris
Among Celebrities Who Have Purchased Here

Celebrities famous the world over, owners of names as familiar to Paris theatre-goers and Australian music-lovers as they are to the inhabitants of old Manhattan Isle, have bought land in New Port Richey, and plan to build winter homes in this famous resort-town, the New Port Richey Press has learned. Recent purchases of building lots in this city, when generally known, will thrust New Port Richey in the public eye as no other community of like size in the limits of Florida can possibly be subjected to the calcium glare of publicity.

During the 1920s, New Port Richey was a gathering place tor film stars and other celebrities. The guest list at the then new fashionable Hacienda Hotel included Mary Pickford, Gloria Swanson, Oscar Shaw, Jack Hazzard, Ernie Truax, Raymond Hitchcock and Thomas and Frances Meighan.

(Ferraro opened Pasco County’s first dinner theatre, at the Hacienda Hotel in 1977,)

The name of George R. Sims, prominent businessman (and the history of New Port Richey are intertwined). One of the first settlers here, Sims was a founder and developer of the community and it was largely through his vision and efforts that the sparsely settled area emerged as a planned thriving municipality. The Sims family gave the property for Sims Park to the city for recreation use.

(The FERRARO Studio Theatre is located IN the1922, historic SIMS building)

In 1926 it seemed possible that New Port Richey, Florida, might become another Hollywood, or at least a winter residence for Hollywood stars. Thomas Meighan, one of the top stars of the silent screen, had purchased property and was about to build a mansion on the Pithlachascotee River.

Our Artistic Vision …

To produce challenging and diverse artistic work that speaks to the intelligence, the soul, and the imagination of the community...

Works that empower, challenge, provoke, motivate, educate and inspire....

To foster a nurturing artistic home for artists, technicians, staff and all who have a passion for the development of the arts. A place to develop and practice the craft, share talents, enrich lives and fulfill dreams. A place for everyone in the community...children, adults and senior citizens regardless of life circumstances.

To strengthen the community and the economy by attracting tourists, visitors and area residents to our venue to enjoy educational, entertaining, artful and developmental programming.

To provide a venue for familiar, new, and developmental productions by artists who may otherwise have their works unnoticed.

To achieve through the performing arts, productions and educational outreach programs which involve the entire spectrum of craft, talent and skill.

Our Goal

to educate, to broaden and intensify the theatrical experience with consistently excellent acting, directing and plays. Through this, the company nurtures the artistic growth of area actors, directors, designers, playwrights and musicians.

HOW YOU CAN HELP...

Please note: I BELIEVE IN MIRACLES AND THE POWER OF PRAYER...              WE WOULD NOT HAVE GOTTEN THIS FAR, WITHOUT THE GENEROUSITY OF OUR LOVING FRIENDS, WHO HAVE DONATED THEIR TIME AND MONEY AND SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT;  BECAUSE THEY BELIEVE IN US AND WHAT WE HAVE DONE IN THE PAST AND WHAT WE PLAN TO DO NOW AND IN THE FUTURE FOR OUR COMMUNITY...THANK YOU, OUR ANGELS ON EARTH...

We signed our lease. We are building the stage, lighting grid, dressing room, sets, costumes, and properties.

Your generous gift will help our scholarship fund, pay rent, purchase lights, chairs, a sign, sound equipment, royalties, educational materials, advertising, electricity, insurances,paint,  property taxes, and the hundreds of other necessities we need to produce quality instruction and performances.

You, our theatre patrons and aficionados’, are the heart of the vibrant  FERRARO STUDIO THEATRE community.  Your generosity of spirit breathes life into our shows.  Without you, we simply would not exist.

PLEASE join with us, in Redefining Intimate Theatre and Performing Arts Education in Pasco County, with your gift.

KEEP THE ARTS ALIVE...

Everyone can help...we understand that not everyone can afford a monetary donation. We would greatly appreciate just getting the word out about our project, volunteering on stage or off stage, and above all, keeping us in your prayers...

With Our Heartfelt Thanks, Gratitude, Appreciation, and Love,

Jimmy & Dee Etta

story:
The story of Waiting for AAA...

If you think you recognize our project, names, and faces, it's because we were here earlier this year, indiegogo. Yes, Waiting for AAA was produced at Pace University's entirely student-run Studio 501 in April of this year. Now, we are very proud to say that we are moving to 42nd street as part of Manhattan Repertory Theater's Stagecraft Play Festival.

Our cast and crew is made up entirely of females and college graduates. Because we are ladies trying to get into entertainment and because we are recent graduates, we are all very broke. So, indiegogo theater patrons, we need a little help...

Why Should You Help?

This show is really good. It's hilarious, brand-spanking-new, relevant, inspiring, a little heartbreaking, and, again, pretty damn funny. We highly doubt you'll come across a play like this anywhere else. 
So, again, why does that mean you should help it out? Well, it's hard out there for a pimp. And by pimp, we mean a female playwright and director. And for actors! And lighting designers! And stage managers! And assistant directors! Pursuing one's passion of theater right out of college is rarely, if ever, a lucrative path. Therefore, the cast & crew of Waiting for AAA needs all the help we can get. We have props to buy (including but not limited to an entire car), seats to fill, and mouths to feed. 
By supporting our project you're supporting young, talented, women in theater. You're supporting our futures, our presents, and our past, which was spent working our asses off on this thing.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you live in New York City or the tri-state area, come see the show! Check out our Facebook event for details.

story:
FallOut is a brand new play, produced by Off The Leash, that will tour to Junior High Schools in the Spring of 2014.

The tour will feature three actors and a stage manager, hitting as many schools in 3 weeks as possible (that's thirty shows to up to 400 students a show.)

FallOut is written by Cara MacPhail and we just completed the workshop of the second draft of the play.

We believe that this important piece of theatre and the accompanying workshop/Q&A/ discussion session is important and needs to be seen by as many students as possible.

Aside from applying for Provincial funding and funding from other sources, we are holding some grassroots fundraising events and starting THIS campaign.

The play will be offered to schools via Theatre Nova Scotia's PERFORM program.

FallOut received a Provincial creation grant to get it through the writing phase.

Off The Leash recognizes the support of the Province of Nova Scotia through the Department of Communities, Culture & Heritage. We are pleased to work in partnership with the Culture Division to develop and promote our cultural resources for all Nova Scotians. 

Help us get FallOut into schools and help us get the conversation started.

www.offtheleash.ca



SYNOPSIS

When Jamie, Alyssa and Becky attend a hometown wedding, their shared history of relentless bullying is right there waiting for them.

The three women relive their past and explore the three sides of the drama that plagued their junior high school years: the victim, the bully and the girl who stood by.

Years earlier, when Alyssa met Becky, at junior high, her existing friendship with Jamie was put to the test.

Things escalate for all three girls when a viral video of Jamie rips through their lives. Jamie knows it must be Becky’s handiwork, but Alyssa doesn’t believe her new friend could be capable of such cruelty.

Things spiral out of control when the bullying takes the form of anonymous, threatening texts and cruel chat-room comments.  Alyssa finally sees how bad things have become, tries to step in, exposing the situation. Is it too little, too late?

All three women are still dealing with their own fallout; no-one walked away unscathed. Alyssa is carrying the guilt from being a passive bystander for so long.

In a play where no one person is entirely innocent, nor completely unsympathetic, FallOut asks the question ‘if it were you, what would you do?’

FallOut is a play for three actors and will tour to junior high schools in Spring 2014.


Cara MacPhail - writer

Cara holds a BA (Hons) in English from the University of Strathclyde and an MLitt in Dramaturgy and Playwriting from the University of Glasgow, both in her native Scotland.

While in Scotland she worked variously as a dramaturg, director and youth facilitator. Previous work includes a Scottish Government project for a group of young carers, facilitating the creation and performance of a new play based on their experiences caring for family members. She was also an assistant director with Gateways Productions’ performance of a new musical by writer Rachel Jury. She has worked as a director and dramaturg for various productions with Strathclyde Theatre.

Since moving to Canada she has been fortunate to work with organisations such as Vancouver Youth Theatre, Halifax Theatre for Young People and Neptune Theatre’s Theatre School. She currently runs a playwriting class for teens.

In addition to working in Canada she also has a production of her new play, The Silkie, slated for performance early 2014 in Scotland.

The Director – Susan Stackhouse

SUSAN STACKHOUSE  is an actor as well as a specialist voice, speech and dialect coach. She received her training at Dalhousie University, the National Theatre School of Canada and the Central School of Speech and Drama in London, England (as a recipient of the Chevening Scholarship).

Susan has spent sixteen seasons with the Shaw Festival in Niagara-on-the-Lake both as a member of the acting ensemble and as a voice coach.  She has also performed at many other theatres over the years, including Neptune Theatre, The Royal Alexandra Theatre, Theatre New Brunswick, the Blyth Festival, Persephone Theatre, Festival Antigonish Summer Theatre and Ship’s Company.  Susan began her career as an educator at George Brown College in the Performing Arts Department, and then moved to her home province of Nova Scotia to take a position in the Department of Theatre at Dalhousie University where she teaches in the Acting Program and has directed and voice coached many DalTheatre productions.

In the past few years she has acted in Romeo and Juliet (Nurse) and Rabbit Hole (Nat) at the Neptune Theatre, recorded the role of Anna Dobchuk in the CBC radio series Backbencher, collaborated with mezzo-soprano Marcia Swanston in The Belle of Amherst (words and music of Emily Dickinson) and How Do I Love Thee?  Let Me Count The Ways . . . (words and music of Elizabeth Barrett Browning).  In that same time Susan has also voice/dialect coached the feature films Copperhead and The Memory Keeper’s Daughter as well as the stage plays Romeo and Juliet, The Seafarer and Strong Poison – all for the Royal Manitoba Theatre Centre.  Susan sits as Vice-Chair on the Board of the Nova Scotia Talent Trust <www.nstalenttrust.ns.ca>.


Jeremy Webb - Producer founded Off The Leash in 2009. He moved to Canada, from his native UK, in 1998. He grew up in Cambridge and trained at The Bristol Old Vic Theatre School.

Most recent Canadian stage appearances include First Voice/male roles in Under Milk Wood, ‘Paul Fisher’ in Fishing (OTL, also writer/producer),  ‘Beowulf’ in Beowulf (Two Planks & A passion), 'Duke Solinus' in The Comedy of Errors, ‘The Wizard’ in The Wizard of Oz and ‘Friar Laurence’ in Romeo & Juliet (Neptune Theatre, Halifax),  ‘Milo Tindle’ in Sleuth (Festival Antigonish, 2010), ‘Duncan’ and ‘The Porter’ in MacBeth (Shakespeare By The Sea, 2009) ‘Iago’ in Othello (2008), ‘Peter Quince’ in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, ‘Maurice’ in Beauty & The Beast (Silvermist Productions, Niagara Falls) and ‘Cogsworth’ in Neptune Theatre’s long-running Beauty and The Beast.

His one-man version of A Christmas Carol was a great success in 2003, 2005, 2008-12 playing at Neptune Theatre’s Studio Theatre and touring Nova Scotia schools and venues.

Shakespeare On Trial returns to North Carolina and Georgia in October/November 2013 for a five-week tour, after a successful 5-week, 30-show  tour in 2011.

His new comedy about the perils of internet dating, Fishing, opened in May 2012 (with a 3 week tour) and, last Summer, played Festival Antigonish, Live Bait Theatre  for the month of August. It then played Neptune Theatre in November 2012. In Summer 2013, Fishing plays the Chester Playhouse as part of their Summer Season. It is already taking bookings for 2014.

Under Milk Wood performed in March 2013 and played the Al Whittle Theatre in Wolfville for 2 weeks in August 2013. Webb produced the play, featuring Susan Stackhouse and himself, directed by Rhys Bevan-John.

In 2011, Off The Leash released a 2-disc CD of A Christmas Carol, featuring Symphony Nova Scotia and over thirty characters all voiced by Webb.

In March 2009, Jeremy won a Best Actor Merritt Award for his portrayal of Iago in Othello, for Shakespeare By The Sea. He won the 2010 Mayor’s Award for Achievement in Theatre and The Coast (Halifax’s weekly newspaper) Best Theatre Actor Award in 2007, 2009 and 2010 (2008 wasn’t such a great year!)  

In October 2013, he receives the Creative Nova Scotia Established Artist award, the night before departing on another 5 week tour in the USA with Shakespeare On Trial.

In the past few years she has acted in Romeo and Juliet (Nurse) and Rabbit Hole (Nat) at the Neptune Theatre, recorded the role of Anna Dobchuk in the CBC radio series Backbencher, collaborated with mezzo-soprano Marcia Swanston in The Belle of Amherst (words and music of Emily Dickinson) and How Do I Love Thee?  Let Me Count The Ways . . . (words and music of Elizabeth Barrett Browning).  In that same time Susan has also voice/dialect coached the feature films Copperhead and The Memory Keeper’s Daughter as well as the stage plays Romeo and Juliet, The Seafarer and Strong Poison – all for the Royal Manitoba Theatre Centre.  Susan sits as Vice-Chair on the Board of the Nova Scotia Talent Trust <www.nstalenttrust.ns.ca>.

Jeremy Webb - Producer founded Off The Leash in 2009. He moved to Canada,
from his native UK, in 1998. He grew up in Cambridge and trained at The Bristol
Old Vic Theatre School.
Most recent Canadian stage appearances include First
Voice/male roles in Under Milk Wood, ‘Paul Fisher’ in Fishing (OTL, also
writer/producer),  ‘Beowulf’ in Beowulf
(Two Planks & A passion), 'Duke Solinus' in The Comedy of Errors, ‘The Wizard’ in The Wizard of Oz and ‘Friar Laurence’
in Romeo & Juliet (Neptune Theatre, Halifax),  ‘Milo Tindle’ in
Sleuth (Festival Antigonish, 2010), ‘Duncan’ and ‘The Porter’ in MacBeth
(Shakespeare By The Sea, 2009) ‘Iago’ in Othello (2008), ‘Peter Quince’ in A
Midsummer Night’s Dream, ‘Maurice’ in Beauty & The Beast (Silvermist
Productions, Niagara Falls) and ‘Cogsworth’ in Neptune Theatre’s long-running
Beauty and The Beast. 
His one-man version of A Christmas Carol was a great success in 2003, 2005, 2008-12 playing at
Neptune Theatre’s Studio Theatre and touring Nova Scotia schools and venues.
Shakespeare On Trial returns to North Carolina and Georgia in October/November
2013 for a five-week tour, after a successful 5-week, 30-show  tour in 2011.
His new comedy about the perils of internet
dating, Fishing, opened in May 2012 (with a 3 week tour) and, last
Summer, played Festival Antigonish, Live Bait Theatre  for the month of August. It then played Neptune Theatre in November 2012. In Summer 2013, Fishing plays the Chester Playhouse as part of their Summer Season.
It is already taking bookings for 2014.
Under Milk Wood performed in March 2013 and played the Al Whittle
Theatre in Wolfville for 2 weeks in August 2013. Webb produced the play,
featuring Susan Stackhouse and himself, directed by Rhys Bevan-John.
In 2011, Off The Leash released a 2-disc CD of A Christmas Carol, featuring Symphony
Nova Scotia and over thirty characters all voiced by Webb.
In March 2009, Jeremy won a Best Actor Merritt
Award for his portrayal of Iago in Othello, for Shakespeare By The Sea. He won
the 2010 Mayor’s Award for Achievement in Theatre and The Coast (Halifax’s
weekly newspaper) Best Theatre Actor Award in 2007, 2009 and 2010 (2008 wasn’t
such a great year!)  
In October 2013, he receives the Creative Nova Scotia Established Artist award, the night before departing on another 5 week tour in the USA with Shakespeare On Trial.

story:
Different Choices Productions

Hi. My name is Bob Linebarger and I am one of the founders of Different Choices Productions. Danny and the Deep Blue Sea by John Patrick Shanley (Doubt being one of his most popular works) is the second show produced by Different Choices, the first being an original work called The Bottom of Everything presented on the Unicorn main stage as a part of the 2011 KC Fringe Festival. Different Choices alludes to works being cultivated with a comedian's touch, or finesse. At the center of the lessons Bruce Woodruff shared with us at Baker University (Bruce was the head of the department when I went there and is now retired) was one word: Choices. Life and theatre, in their simplest form, are just a collection of choices. The choices brought forth by true comedians (I believe true comedians are those who can go through the thought process to find the humor in anything and everything) might not always hold as the best choices, but they can sure be counted on to be different. These different choices made by these true comedians will hope to build on the open-mindset that there is never only one way of doing things.

Danny and the Deep Blue Sea 

This play, written by young John Patrick Shanley who has one hell of a career after writing this one, is a dark play. Danny is an angry man who gets into multiple bar fights. Roberta... well you will have to come see the show to find out what makes her dark. As dark as it is, though, I would find myself laughing out loud when reading it. I hear two kindergartners talking. They just happen to be 29 and 31. Hence, my concept: this is a love story between two adult-children. Oh, adult-children exist. They absolutely, positively exist. The question was then, "What cultural world do I put them in to really bring out this concept?" Then timing gave me a present. I was walking to Crown Center one day when I see a man, maybe early 30s, heading to the "oh-so-notorious" annual concert in KC called Rockfest. I watched him notice a pigeon while walking, tell his friends to "Watch this!" and then proceed to intimidatingly step to this pigeon. Pigeon flew off, went about his day. But this man and his friends thought it was hilarious. I find it hilarious, however, because I had truly observed adult-children in action. So, Roberta and Danny... yeah they are going to be Rockfest people. Oh, and there will be Nickelback songs in the sound design. You can count on that! With this concept, hopefully this comedian's touch to a now 30-year-old play will bring the rich, dark undertones people have come to love and also make it a fun, hilarious experience for those watching.

Artist Funding for Danny and the Deep Blue Sea 

Funding, of course, is crucial towards the production of a show. It can come from multiple resources or it can come from one big donor. Different Choices is still at the very beginning of its business life, so funding is coming from anywhere we can get it. I'm paying for the rehearsal space in painting labor. I'm paying for the performance space in putting on a variety show (The Bob and Matt Show... details below... but this is gonna be great so, like, come to it). But I do need to raise funds to pay my more-than-worthy artists helping put this show on. That is where this Indiegogo campaign and you come in. By raising the goals of $2000, I can pay my actors, stage manager and designers the bare minimum of what they are worth. So, please, help this production by donating any amount you can. Community is a big part of why the old art of theatre is still around, and I am a firm believer that we have one of the best art-supported communities right here in KC.

    Future of Different Choices

    Not only are you helping fund Danny and the Deep Blue Sea with a contribution to this campaign, you are helping the success of future projects for Different Choices Productions. Denver Little (another founder and the writer of The Bottom of Everything) and I are already talking about the next Fringe Festival project all revolving around the life of Nate Ruess, lead singer of the bands The Format and fun. Hailey Jones, founder of MoJo productions, and I are talking about co-producing a project. The wonderful, wonderful ladies at The Westport Center for the Arts and I have talked about producing an original work in the future. Many projects on the table, and if we meet our goal this time around, it will give us great confidence to move forward. Moving forward... what life is all about. The long-term goal for Different Choices is to open a theater run by an education program for the ages and donated ticket price. I recently became a co-educational director of The Living Room theater so... moving forward. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      • Word of Mouth
      • Come see the Show! Performance Dates: October 10, 11, 17, 18 @ 7:30 and Industry Nights October 13 and 20 @ 8:00
      • Come to The Bob and Matt Show on September 14th @ 8:00
      • Word. Of. Mouth.

story:
About the Project

There are over 314 million people living in America today, and 265 million of them are Christians.  

And yet, despite holding a massive majority of the American population, Christians still find themselves embroiled in a major culture war.  Conservative media outlets discuss the "war on Chrisitanity" as progressive ideals about marriage, contraception, education and immigration continuously class with traditional Christian beliefs.

At the center of the culture war is Tim Tebow.  Tim doesn't say very much; he prefers to let his actions speak for him.  He donates his money to charity.  He spends his free time volunteering to help children with special needs.  And he prays after every touchdown he scores.

Some people love Tim Tebow.  They think he's an inspiration.

Other people hate Tim Tebow.  They think he's a phony.

God Damn Tim Tebow! is a play that wonders, "What does God think about Tim Tebow?  And what does God think about Christians in America today?"  

Expenses

In order to produce this play, we need to cover the following costs:  

  • Theater rental ... This covers the rental fee as well as insurance for the venue.
  • Rehearsal space ... We're rehearsing this play 3 times a week!
  • Fringe Fest entry fee ... This covers the administrative and promotional work that the lovely folks at the Hollywood Fringe do to make this awesome festival happen.
  • Salary for cast & crew ... The amazingly talented cast & crew are all putting dozens of hours of effort into this show, and we will be paying them a modest fee for their fantastic work.
  • Props & costumes ... The actors can't exactly go on stage naked, can they?  (Well, not all of them.)
  • Art & advertising ... We will be using some money to pay for art, programs and postcard advertisements to help get the word out.

The Impact

Perhaps you're friends with one of the cast members.  Perhaps you're family with one of the crew.  Or perhaps you're just a good Samaritan who stumbled on this page.  

But whoever you are, we need your help to produce this play.  

And if you're in the Hollywood, California area, we welcome you to come check out our show on June 27th, 28th, 29th and 30th!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help out financially, that's okay ... we'd still LOVE your help spreading the news!  Connect with us online, and tell your friends about us:

  • Website: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/1352
  • Twitter: @GodDamnTimTebow 
  • Facebook: God Damn Tim Tebow - The Play https://www.facebook.com/GodDamnTimTebowThePlay?ref=hl

story:
Summary

Now in its 4th year, BAILANDO POR UNA CAUSA has become one of New York's pre-eminent celebrations of love, life and dance. 

Join us as Baila Society brings together a diverse mix of New York's most esteemed dance companies for a night of breathtaking performances at El Museo del Barrio to benefit the Latino Commission on AIDS, a non-profit organization dedicated to fighting the spread of HIV/AIDS. 

Each genre of dance represents the cultures and traditions of the diverse communities supported by the Commission and equally engage in addressing the impact and stigma of HIV/AIDS in our country. 

100% OF EVENT PROCEEDS BENEFIT THE LATINO COMMISION ON AIDS 

The Latino Commission on AIDS was founded in 1990 by concerned community leaders to address an unmet need in the Latino community for HIV & AIDS prevention and care services.

We serve the community by providing HIV testing, support groups and counseling for those living with and affected by HIV, bi-lingual health and treatment education, and ensure culturally and linguistically appropriate services are provided nation wide by providing capacity building assistance to other organizations and advocating for the rights of our community at the city, state and federal levels.


What We Need & The Impact

In conjunction with Bailando Por Una Causa (www.bailandoporunacausa.org) we hope to raise $5,000 additional funds from concerned community members like yourself to support our HIV testing program and national community mobilization and awareness campaigns.

As the fastest growing group in New York City and the United States, increased efforts are crucial in order to improve the health and wellness of Latinos and all of our communities. In New York City alone, over 36,000 Latinos live with HIV/AIDS. 

Getting tested and knowing your status is the first step in preventing the spread of this disease. Your contributions will help us raise the funds needed to ensure free HIV tests are available in our communities. 

In 2012 we tested over 2,000 individuals in the New York City area and each year we aim to reach even more people. Every person who knows their status is one more person who if they are negative can learn how to stay HIV-free and if positive one more person who can get into treatement and stay healthy.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're in New York in October, don't miss the the show:
http://www.bailandoporunacausa.org

Spread the word and get tested! We encourage everyone to learn the facts, get tested and encourage those you love to get tested as well. It's about keeping yourself, your loved ones and your entire community healthy.

Tweet, Facebook, email the link to this campaign to your friends, family and colleagues.

story:
What is The Contemporary Theater Company?

The Contemporary Theater Company is a non-profit theater in Wakefield, RI that is dedicated to bringing a comprehensive arts experience to South County. We believe that art is essential to our well-being as individuals and to the betterment of our community.

Founded in 2005, it started as a collaborative project among young local artists interested in restoring the once vibrant live theater scene of southern Rhode Island. In 2012, we opened a 90-seat theater at 327 Main Street, bringing theater to the heart of our community.

New Frontiers

The CTC is preparing to produce Stephen Sondheim’s Assassins, our first full-scale musical. The complexity of a rich Sondheim score coupled with an honest and surprising look at some fascinating historical figures led us toward this show.

Assassins asks big questions – how did the country of Abraham Lincoln also produce John Wilkes Booth?  How did the American Dream fail these assassins?  How is history and the nation shaped by tragic events?  These honest questions are important, but rarely asked.

Our company is known for producing shows that ask big questions and blend the comedic with the serious, such as Waiting for Godot (2010), Eurydice (2011), God’s Ear (2013), and our latest show Bob (2013), and Assassins follows this tradition.

What We Need

Producing a musical like Assassins has a lot of extra costs associated with it compared to a traditional CTC production.

We need to pay for :

-  Production rights

-  14 cast members

-  Director

-  Musical director

-  Stage manager

-  Choreographer

-  Costume designer

-  Production manager

-  Show musicians

-  Set construction

-  Costume construction

In order to live up to our mission of providing opportunities for everyone to experience live performance and keep our ticket prices at a reasonable rate while paying these extra expenses, we need to raise $3500 over the next 3 weeks!

What You Get

The CTC is dedicated to providing entertaining, thought-provoking shows year-round.  The funds raised by this Indie-Go-Go will help us ensure that we can provide the best quality production of Assassins that we can, while keeping tickets prices at a reasonable rate.  Plus, check out our awesome donor rewards (and, their cumulative)!

Even if you can’t donate, you can still help! Spread the word, tell your friends, and share, share, share!

story:
Love, Money, God, Drink, Christmas is an ensemble play that challenges the myth of  being "home for the holidays." The play unfolds over the course of four Christmas Eve parties (1997, 2001, 2005, and 2009) in which the world screws with the Sullivans, and the Sullivans screw with each other. Spanning the last two decades of the American experience (the Clinton years, 9/11, and the Great Recession), Love, Money, God, Drink, Christmas asks to consider if our families really are our closest loved ones, or just the ones we can never really get away from.


Your contributions will allow this play to see the stage the very first time, premiering at the downtown New York space that the sparked the careers of Craig Lucas, Lisa Kron, the Blue Man Group!

Because of your generosity we will be able to compensate the creative team for their time, talent, and terrific dedication...and dress them in a few appropriately awful Christmas sweaters.


$10 - Buys two roundtrip subway rides to rehearsal for us and a signed Christmas card from the Sullivans thanking you!

$25 - Buys an hour of rehearsal time for us and Christmas playlist of the team's favorite Holiday tunes for you!

$50 - Buys the hand props for us and a box of Grandma Jule's own secret recipe Christmas Cookies for you!

$100 - Buys an evening of rehearsal space for us an hour of present wrapping with the Director, Playwright, and select Cast Members for you!

$500 - Buys the set and costumes for us and a complete Christmas tree-trimming by the Director, Playwright, and select Cast Members for you!

$1000 - Buys half the cast's stipends for us, and a live caroling by the Director, Playwright, and select Cast Members for you!


A little about us:
Siobhan Gilbert (Playwright) is a New York-based playwright and screenwriter. Her work has been featured at Primary Stages' Detention Series, Columbia University, NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, the Old Globe Theater in San Diego's PlayGround series, the Last Frontier Theater Conference in Valdez, Alaska, and the Davenport Theater. She has been commissioned by MKA in Montclair, NJ to write a children's play for their upcoming season. She is a member of the Dramatists Guild. She holds a BA in Comparative Literature from Columbia University, and is an MFA candidate in Playwriting and Screenwriting at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, where she is the recipient of the Department of Dramatic Writing fellowship.

Greg Taubman (Director) is a New York-based director and dramaturg with a lifelong passion for enduring stories. He is the Associate Artistic Director for Outside the Wire, a social impact company that uses theater and other media to address pressing public health issues. As a freelance theater artist, Greg has worked with many local and national arts organizations including The Public Theater, Classic Stage Company, The Oregon Shakespeare Festival, The Shakespeare Society, and Extant Arts Company, where he served as Artistic Director from 2006-2013. He holds a BA in Classical Studies from Princeton and a Directing MFA from Columbia University. 


The Ensemble:

J. Clint Allen*
Kirsten Benjamin*
Miles Duffield
Tom Giordano*
Gabriella Grier
Katharine Lorraine
David Shaw
Maria Silverman*
Jocelyn Vammer

*appearing courtesy Actors Equity Association

...and don't forget to book your tickets to the show at: http://dixonplace.org/performances/love-money-g...!

Love, Money, God, Drink, Christmas is an ensemble play that challenges the myth of  being "home for the holidays." The play unfolds over the course of four Christmas Eve parties (1997, 2001, 2005, and 2009) in which the world screws with the Sullivans, and the Sullivans screw with each other. Spanning the last two decades of the American experience (the Clinton years, 9/11, and the Great Recession), Love, Money, God, Drink, Christmas asks to consider if our families really are our closest loved ones, or just the ones we can never really get away from.

Your contributions will allow this play to see the stage the very first time, premiering at the downtown New York space that the sparked the careers of Craig Lucas, Lisa Kron, the Blue Man Group!
Because of your generosity we will be able to compensate the creative team for their time, talent, and terrific dedication...and dress them in a few appropriately awful Christmas sweaters.


$10 - Buys two roundtrip subway rides to rehearsal for us and a signed Christmas card from the Sullivans thanking you!
$25 - Buys an hour of rehearsal time for us and Christmas playlist of the team's favorite Holiday tunes for you!
$50 - Buys the hand props for us and a box of Grandma Jule's own secret recipe Christmas Cookies for you!
$100 - Buys an evening of rehearsal space for us an hour of present wrapping with the Director, Playwright, and select Cast Members for you!
$500 - Buys the set and costumes for us and a complete Christmas tree-trimming by the Director, Playwright, and select Cast Members for you!
$1000 - Buys half the cast's stipends for us, and a live caroling by the Director, Playwright, and select Cast Members for you!
A little about us:



Siobhan Gilbert (Playwright) is a New York-based playwright and screenwriter. Her work has been featured at Primary Stages' Detention Series, Columbia University, NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, the Old Globe Theater in San Diego's PlayGround series, the Last Frontier Theater Conference in Valdez, Alaska, and the Davenport Theater. She has been commissioned by MKA in Montclair, NJ to write a children's play for their upcoming season. She is a member of the Dramatists Guild. She holds a BA in Comparative Literature from Columbia University, and is an MFA candidate in Playwriting and Screenwriting at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, where she is the recipient of the Department of Dramatic Writing fellowship.



Greg Taubman (Director) is a New
York-based director and dramaturg with a lifelong passion for enduring
stories. He is the Associate Artistic Director for Outside the
Wire, a social impact company that uses theater and other media to address
pressing public health issues. As a freelance theater artist, Greg
has worked with many local and national arts organizations including
The Public Theater, Classic Stage Company, The Oregon
Shakespeare Festival, The Shakespeare Society, and Extant Arts Company,
where he served as Artistic Director from 2006-2013. He holds a BA in
Classical Studies from Princeton and a Directing MFA from Columbia
University. 


The Ensemble:

J. Clint Allen*
Kirsten Benjamin*
Miles Duffield
Tom Giordano*
Gabriella Grier
Katharine Lorraine
David Shaw
Maria Silverman*
Jocelyn Vammer

*appearing courtesy Actors Equity Association...and don't forget to book your tickets to the show at: http://dixonplace.org/performances/love-money-g...!

story:
Help us be part of dance history in the making!

Canadian Contemporary Dance Theatre is an award-winning repertory company of dancers under 19 years of age. Acclaimed “a national treasure” and numbered "among Toronto’s top dance companies” by Canada’s Globe & Mail, CCDT members experience the life of a professional dancer, including intensive ballet and modern training, touring up to forty performances a year, and creation work with celebrated international choreographers and designers.

This October, CCDT has been honoured with an invitation to perform alongside a stellar cast of international companies celebrating the José Limón Dance Company’s 70th Anniversary.  Canada’s only representative at the two-week Festival, CCDT will be taking fourteen dancers to perform one of Limón’s iconic works, The Winged (1966), on the stage of the storied Joyce Theater in New York City.

This momentous opportunity grew from our long history with the Limón Company and its Artistic Director Carla Maxwell, who has nurtured two former CCDT members, Kristen Foote and Belinda McGuire. Best of all, Kristen, now among the Limón Company’s most senior artists, will return to mount The Winged on CCDT’s company dancers.

In order to make this exciting tour a reality, we need your help!

Kristen Foote in José Limón's Dances for Isadora.


What Your Help Means

An international tour has significant expenses. Your contributions to this campaign will go toward:

- Two Years’ Performance rights for The Winged ($4,800 CAD) …YES, we will perform José’s masterwork FOR YOU here in Canada, too!

- Remount /rehearsal and costume expenses ($3,200 CAD)

- A life-changing, dream experience for fourteen exquisite young artists!

Our goal is to raise at least 50% of our total expenses, or $8,000. Please help us reach our target!


A New Chance for Global Recognition

Making Our Mark in the World’s Dance Capital

This Festival, hosted by the world’s oldest Modern Dance Company, is the dream platform for winning recognition in a new part of the globe, helping CCDT and its dancers to establish important international relationships for the future.  It also will mark CCDT's first time performing in New York City, and only the second American tour in the company's history.  

Following our July 2014 tour to Scotland, this invitation to The Joyce Theater is just the beginning of what we hope will be a trend of consistent international touring opportunities for many years to come. 

In addition to the José Limón Dance Company, we will be sharing the stage with sjDANCEco (California), Royal Danish Ballet (Denmark), CoreoArte (Venezuela), and Bavarian State Ballet (Germany), among many others!

Your generous donation will help CCDT continue to establish its international presence, proudly representing Canada beyond our borders!

Kristen coaching CCDT dancers through movement intention.

It doesn't stop there... there are other ways to help!

Whether or not you can contribute, please help spread the word!

We all love our Internet -- Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and other social media, and tell your friends and family!  Your donations are going towards a great cause, and we will be forever thankful!

story:
Short Summary

"The way to read a fairy tale is to throw yourself in," said W.H. Auden. Les Enfants Terribles took this quote to heart and morphed Oliver Lansley, the Artistic Director of Les Enfants Terribles, and Sam Wyer's stories into a fantastical production for the world to view. They ripped them out of the traditional medias of books, movies or musicals. Instead, they created "The Terrible Infants"  which uses music that has no score to both speak and sing the dialogue. They allow for each production company to pick up the fairy tale play and use their imagination to create images that will enhance the already vivid tales. These ideas will be utilized to their fullest during the production by a new theater company Renegade Productions with one of the founders, Megan Holder, as the director. This production will serve as her Honor's Thesis and Theater Directing Capstone and will benefit Room to Read, a non-for-profit organization that brings books to underprivileged children in America and builds libraries stacked with books for children in underdeveloped countries around the world.

What We Need 

What we are in need of:

  • Royalties for Three Performances (about $180)
  • Performance and Rehearsal Space for a Week Minimum
  • Lighting (alternative to traditional lighting instruments)
  • Props (the props in this show create some of the storybook characters)
  • Set pieces (we are hoping to build a toy chest to emphasize the idea that these are children's tales)
  • Costumes (visual representation to change from character to character)
  • Posters
  • Playbills

First we will look at item donations, then we will begin buying used or making items. If we are still struggling to obtain certain items such as lamps for lighting, we will have to buy new. Most of the costs are for Royalties and Performance and tech Rehearsal Spaces, as they will cost the most. Props is the next big line item because it is a prop heavy show; the more there are for the actors to use to create the characters during the show, the more fun it will be. There are some props needed that cannot be substituted. We do have to create a doll and either create her fancier version or create her so her fancy version attaches over her main body.

Any additional funds will be donated to Room to Read along with the cost of admission to the performances. If we do not reach our goal, the production will still go on somehow, someway but with an even tighter budget. 

What You Get

  • For $10 your Name will be in the Playbill.
  • For $20 you will receive a Handwritten Thank You Note and your Name in the Playbill.
  • For $40 you will receive a Poster Signed by the Cast, a Handwritten Thank You Note, and your Name in the Playbill.
  • For $60 you will receive a Hand Crocheted Dinosaur hat (because why not), a Poster Signed by the Cast, a Handwritten Thank You Note, and your Name in the Playbill.
  • For $85 you will receive a Hand Crocheted Egg Monster stuffed with a surprise (again, because why not)Hand Crocheted Dinosaur hat (because why not), , a Poster Signed by the Cast, a Handwritten Thank You Note, and your Name in the Playbill.
  • For $100 you will receive a Hand Crocheted Dinosaur Hat, a Hand Crocheted Egg Monster stuffed with a surprise, a Poster Signed by the Cast, a Handwritten Thank You Note, and your Name in the Playbill.
  • For $150 you will receive a Hand Crocheted Infinity Scarf, Hand Crocheted Dinosaur Hat, a Hand Crocheted Egg Monster stuffed with a surprise, a Printed Poster Signed by the Cast, a Handwritten Thank You Note, and your Name in the Playbill.

The Impact

If you are not excited already, the show has five actors. One narrator, two storytellers and two musicians ("There's live music?" Yes. Yes there is). These actors then create the character from each of the tales using props on costumes as they tell each story. There are a lot of wacky things like children growing tails, bees creating hives in hair, and a cloth girl stealing fabric to recreate herself. Oliver Lansley is quick to point out "'The Terrible Infants' was about exploring that most basic form of storytelling. Though it is important to note that we never set out to create a 'children's show', rather a show that made grown-ups feel like children. A small but fundamental distinction." Trust me, this show is the show for you.

Renegade Productions is a ragtag theater group that came into existence when a new work needed support to be produced. The new work "if by yes" by Ru Weller-Passman was successfully launched a year ago and is in discussion for production with other companies. Renegade Productions operates completely on a shoestring budget in different spaces that can be had for cheap. Only quality, thoughtful work is produced. "The Terrible Infants" by Oliver Lansley will be the second show produced by Renegade Productions, though hopefully there are many in their future. "if by yes" was an adaptation of e.e. cumming's poem, "anyone lived in a pretty howtown" and sold out all the seats, including the 25 chairs added last minute to accommodate. "The Terrible Infants" will continue the tradition of producing plays that have ties to the literary world. Why? Because cross-curriculum teaching is important.

This production will act as Honors Thesis and Theater-Directing Capstone for Megan Holder, one of the Founders of Renegade Productions. She will be submitting it as the final two requirements for her Bachelors of Science in Theater Production at Ball State University. Another Founder, Ru-Lee Weller-Passman, will be acting as Dramaturge for this production.

Risks & Challenges

We do not yet have a space for the tech rehearsals or performances so the exact cost is unknown, though based on research of the area and previous experience, the performance space will cost about $450 total. 

All funds from the cost of admission will go to benefit Room to Read, a non-for-profit organization that donates book for children in underprivileged homes in the USA and sets up fully stocked libraries in underdeveloped countries.

These unknown costs have been budgeted at their highest cost. Should there be any money left over, it will go directly to Room to Read. As there are an abundance of spaces, finding a performance space will be no problem if we receive full funding.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you do not have the funds to donate, you can help us out by sharing our Indiegogo page and encouraging your friends and family to donate in your stead. 

Also, if you are in Muncie, Indiana or the surrounding area, feel free to donate metal objects or instruments to help us create the music. Also, working umbrellas of all sorts, bed sheets, abnormally-styled clothing will be useful .Send us a message on here if you have any questions or need a drop-off location. If you have oddball objects and want to know if we could use them, feel free to message on here because we probably can use it.

story:
THE PROJECT

Greetings from the Theater and Performance class of 2016 at Bard College! We are a group of 20 seniors who are creating an epic event of theater and weirdness at the Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College this spring! 

The "Senior Project" is the final, cumulative piece of work Bard students create during their 4th year here. We theater majors have decided to make our senior project a huge, collaborative, community event. Over the course of the past year, we brainstormed how we could create a project of which all of us could be a part. We finally landed on the incredible book, Dante's Inferno.

We decided to break up into small, collaborative groups that would each get 25 mins to create an original piece inspired by one of the circles of Dante's hell. Each group/circle now has an incredible cast and we have been writing/devising theater pieces that center on whatever sin we are exploring. This February, all our hard work will culminate in an uproarious, fun, absurd, gorgeous, ridiculous day of marathon theater; you will be able to come for 25 minutes or 7 hours to explore with us the circles of hell we have created. 

February 26th - 29th, 2016 in Luma Theater in the Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College


THE PLAYERS

PROGRAM A
The Neutrals
Dana Shimkoski/Audrey Rosenblith

Circle 1: Limbo
Ayla Miller/Lauren D’Ottavio

Circle 2/3/4: Lust, Gluttony, and Greed
Abby Adler/Leah Rabinowitz/Eleanor Robb/Salome Dewell

Circle 5: Anger
Cullan Powers/Mikey Gray/Aleah Black

PROGRAM B
Circle 6: Heresy
Daniel Krakovski/Eileen Goodrich

Circle 7: Violence 
Antonio Irizarry/Ethan Rogers/Daisy Rosato

Circle 8: Fraud
Kedian Keohan/Reeves Morris-Stan

Circle 9: Treachery 
Imani Jones/Soraya Cain

THE IMPACT

Theater is challenging to make. It is just as hard to get funding for. Yet like anything worthwhile in life, we've decided to do it anyway. In a world where we are facing global tragedies where sin, religion, violence, hatred, and apathy play a huge role, it's essential to make art that looks at these issues head on. By creating a community of artists dealing with the ancient yet still relevant themes, we are opening up a space to talk about issues that are too easy to ignore. Theater is activism; it is a way to look at something as complicated and charged as the idea of "hell" and ask what we can do now. Theater is community; it is a way for people of all kinds to gather in a space together and decide what we think is worth fighting for. Theater is art in a world where artists are so frequently not allowed to create anything. The "impact" of this show is something we can't quantify, so please come and join us and experience it for yourself.

THE NEEDS

Each circle is made up of thrifty college students, so we are doing as much as we can to create inexpensive shows. That said, we need help! In order to clothe our actors, create effects, build sets, buy props, and promote our show, we need a budget. Every penny that goes toward this campaign will go directly to the senior projects. All our actors and musicians and stage managers are working for free, so everything we are requesting is just to create the physical worlds of our plays. Anything you can donate is so appreciated! $5 helps more than you think! Please share our campaign with friends, family, enemies, strangers; help us create some wild, beautiful art. 


CONTACT US:

Email: infernoseniorproject@gmail.com

Tickets: FREE (reservations suggested), (845)758-7900, 
http://fishercenter.bard.edu/calendar/event.php?eid=130151

One million thanks!

-The INFERNO team

story:
SPUN

Spun has been given the honor of performing at Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, on August 19th, 2016, as the first show ever brought to the Pillow to incorporate Cyr wheel. Jacob's Pillow Inside/Out stage is an amazing platform for emerging artists to show their work on a beautiful outdoor stage (see image below). We couldn't be more excited about this amazing opportunity, but first, we need your help! (You can visit us also on Double the Donation: 

https://doublethedonation.com/LorenRoyseandCompany


Spun first came into existence in March of 2015 in support of Bee's Fund annual charity event.  The fund benefits lesbian, bisexual women, and  transgender women, ages 18-25, whose own families have withdrawn emotional and/or financial support because of their sexual and/or gender identity.  

This show was a beautiful collaboration concentrating on the intersection of comedy, dance and Cyr wheel vocabulary.  The audience was blown away!  

The past year has provided us with the time to improve the integration of the apparatus and its movement vocabulary with the dancers. We look forward to presenting at Jacob's Pillow, our vision; a choreographic work integrating the disciplines of Cyr wheel with the vocabulary of modern dance.  We are also planning to present our work in New York City after the Pillow so that those who are unable to come see us at the Inside/Out Festival can be entertained locally!


What We Need & What You Get

SPUN is fiscally sponsored!!! Your donations are tax deductible! 

$20,500!!! 

https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/
Spun is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Spun must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


The Impact

This project is the first time that Cyr wheel will be shown at Jacobs Pillow and the first time that Jonathan and Courtney's work will be shown at the Pillow. This festival is an amazing platform for emerging artists and it is truly an honor to show our work there.  Collectively we are working toward advancing collaboration in the integration of circus, theater, dance and other forms of performing arts. We are incredibly excited to be emerging artists given the platform to show our work on such a beautiful stage with an amazing organization. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, we still need assistance in other areas.  Do you have access to discounted car rentals, a house in the Berkshires, or friends who might be about to make a donation?  Or, just come see the show!  If you can't do either of those things we gladly accept love notes, bad jokes, and cookies.
story_txt:
SPUN

Spun has been given the honor of performing at Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, on August 19th, 2016, as the first show ever brought to the Pillow to incorporate Cyr wheel. Jacob's Pillow Inside/Out stage is an amazing platform for emerging artists to show their work on a beautiful outdoor stage (see image below). We couldn't be more excited about this amazing opportunity, but first, we need your help! (You can visit us also on Double the Donation: 

https://doublethedonation.com/LorenRoyseandCompany



 Spun first came into existence in March of 2015 in support of Bee's Fund annual charity event.  The fund benefits lesbian, bisexual women, and  transgender women, ages 18-25, whose own families have withdrawn emotional and/or financial support because
of their sexual and/or gender identity.  
This show was a beautiful collaboration concentrating on the intersection of comedy, dance and Cyr wheel vocabulary.  The audience was blown away!  
The past year has provided us with the time to improve the integration of the apparatus and its movement vocabulary with the dancers. We look forward to presenting at Jacob's Pillow, our vision; a choreographic work integrating the disciplines of Cyr wheel with the vocabulary of modern dance.  We are also planning to present our work in New York City after the Pillow so that those who are unable to come see us at the Inside/Out Festival can be entertained locally!
   What We Need & What You Get

SPUN is fiscally sponsored!!! Your donations are tax deductible! 


$20,500!!! 


https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/
Spun is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Spun must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The Show. . .

Immersive productions have been thrilling audiences in New York, London, and LA in recent years; now it is time for Rochester theatre-goers to experience this exciting medium for storytelling. Since its inception in 2014, WallByrd has been adding its unique vision to the theatrical landscape with productions including last fall’s THE DUCHESS OF MALFI and a fresh take on Shakespeare’s classic ROMEO AND JULIET this summer at the Highland Bowl. With DRACULA, we hope to shift perceptions of what live theatre can be and invite those who may not consider themselves theatre fans to experience the art form at its most engaging.

The Team. . .

With a cast and production team that blends local artists with additional professionals imported from New York City and across the state, this production promises to be an experience that is exotic while remaining rooted in the community and uniquely Rochestarian. It will be a new and exciting experience for a city already deeply committed to the performing arts.

The Journey. . .

Phase 1 in our development of this production is a readers’ theatre performance as part of the First Niagara Rochester Fringe Festival.  This special two-night event at the historic Lyric Theatre will give Rochester audiences a taste of this exciting new adaption and our unique immersive style. It promises to be an evening of gothic horror, classic literature, and perhaps a few surprises.

It will also be a chance for patrons to connect with the creators as we move forward towards a full production slated for Fall of 2017. 

You. . .

So where do you come in? Venue rental, travel costs, compensation for the dedicated professionals we employ in Rochester and beyond— these are just a few of the costs associated with making a production like this happen. We can only do it with the support of donors like you. No amount is too small. Now is the time to get involved and help bring a new kind of performance experience to Rochester.

WallBryd Theatre Co. is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of WallByrd Theatre Co. must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Using elements of Calypso and other various styles of music, choreography and Stickfighting, "Flambeaux" tells the story of a Community in Trinidad in the late 1880's. Set in fictional Homer Yard during Carnival, they are striving for relevance and Home.

With your support, we'll be able to produce Nandi Keyi's provocative, new Carnival Musical. We'll also launch our 2015 Touring and development cycle, where we hope to expand our audiences by touring Atlanta, GA and Houston, Texas.

Caribbean-American Theatre is vital to diaspora work and Cultural Ambassadorship, but for many years it has not been able to contribute within the grand Vision of Theatre Culture. With this project, "Flambeaux" we are seeking to rectify that.

Through this "Indiegogo" campaign, we will be able to produce 15 full shows of "Flambeaux" this Summer/Fall. This is one of our most exciting projects to date, with new surprises and the Obsidian Media Group commitment to making every performance an accessible theatrical event.

Where the Money is Going

The Actual Budget needed is $65,000.00. Indiegogo is just one of the Fundraisers we will be having.

story:
Last year I decided to take the  plunge and make my first solo show. Most of my ideas centred on my little brother Sean who has severe learning disabilities and autism. What started this was being asked by an audition application to write a short story, so I wrote about 'The Christmas I nearly killed my brother' (by accident). This is part of my collection of stories centring on usual experiences based around Sean, which I am now aware are not entirely normal.

'He Ain't Heavy' will use physical theatre, aerial circus and puppetry to look at my relationship with Sean and the future responsibility I will have for him. 

With this project I hope to reach out to other siblings of people with special needs and autism, to raise awareness about the established groups and support networks out there and to give an insight into some of my experiences for those who don't know someone with special needs.

So far we've nearly raised the money needed to start this project, but it would be great to have your help with the final push to meet the target!

Breakdown

This first stage of the project is to Research and Develop the ideas, and the budget accounts for:

Space hire

Creation of a bespoke puppet (named Seamus)

Direction from theatre and circus professionals

Commissioning a composed piece of music

Working with a producer

Marketing

Building a website

Delivering a workshop exploring the themes (17th October at 10am)


We have received support from Ausform and the Arts Council of England. This final £500 will account for the final 7% and will make a massive difference, enabling us to fulfil all of the project aims. Without it we will be unable to fully document and publicise the piece, which means that whilst the rehearsals will happen the piece won't have the same impact, with less resources to raise awareness or build a profile on which to develop the project into the future.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the campaign to help us reach our total!

If you know anyone with a family member with autism who would be interested in being involved in the project please ask them to get in touch @GraniaPickard or graniapickard@gmail.com.

Also if you would like to watch the piece and give you feedback then please come to the showing: Volt: Women in Circus.

story:
Fight for Love

Rubans Rouges Dance Company, Artistically Directed by Noelle Andressen, loves to perform modern dance pieces that not only have artistic value and entertainment, but a message. A message of HOPE, LOVE, and PEACE.

We cordially invite you to join the emotional journey.

  • "FIGHT FOR LOVE" is a Dance Drama close to Ms. Andressen's heart. She believes we are in a day and age where we have to fight for love or fight for the right to love whom we choose without fear of being out-cast and forced into conformity, labeled, or harmed for our choices. WE are all flesh and blood and deserve to be cherished and not stripped of our emotional being. This piece explores the brainwashing and peer pressure that results from conformity.

A Little About Us

  • Ms. Andressen and her beautiful dancers, have been creating dance pieces for the Los Angeles area since 2009; going in to their 7th year. They've presented and performed these dance pieces in various, notorious festivals such as: LA Dance Festival, Mix Match Dance Festival, So Cal Dance Invitational Concert in Huntington Beach, TriArts Fest in San Pedro, ADaPT Festival in NYC, St. Barbara, Pasadena and their very own festival: Awakenings & Beginnings Dance Festival to name just a few. 
  • Ms. Andressen's background: Earned AA & BFA degrees in dance & film and merged those two loves together to form this multi-media dance company that excels presenting dance drama on stage and screen. She also earned Emmy nominations regionally for "Baby Doe's Heartbeat" 2004 for her production skills, writing, and music composition. 
  • Her husband, Kristopher, is the company's composer and Co-Director. His dramatic scores create the sound tapestry in which the dancers move to. He also earned an Emmy nomination for his music composition.
  • Through our Community Outreach Programs, we also fund raise for other charities such as: Lupus and American Cancer Society. Ms. Andressen sits on the committee for Relay for Life South Valley, CA.
  • More about us: http://www.RubansRougesDance.com

Don't Give Up

  • This project also serves as an awareness campaign to "Stand Up - Speak Up - and Don't Give Up" and don't give in to conformity. Ms. Andressen was a victim of abuse on many levels: sexually as a child, bullied even in her adult years, emotionally and physically harmed. Because of this, she does a lot of non-profit/charity work to raise awareness and help those who also suffered. The numbers of victims are on the rise as our world loses sight of Love. She and her dancers want to stop the suffering by using their artistry to get the message out. "We need to help prevent suicides due to out-casting and succumbing to peer pressure just to "fit in". Love is the answer. We must "Fight for Love."

  • There is value in giving others their value. They need to know: "They are not their failures, confusions, labels, mistakes. They are humans that love, feel and are wonderfully made." You can help us ennoble another human being through art.

What We Need to Succeed & What You Get

Breaking it all down: We've been able to fund raise some of what we need on our own. We are asking you to participate to help us reach our dreams & goals.

  • $3,800.00 is still needed for: dancer honorariums; studio rehearsal fees; venue & event insurance; music licensing + composition fees; costumes; set design; lighting designer; stage manager; crew chief; house manager; marketing materials; video recording; photography; ads and promotion; post production administration.
  • We promise not to forget to thank you for your contribution. Every amount donated helps and we want you to have pride in helping. To show our gratitude our awesome perks range from a huge shout out on our social media via personal thanks on video from our dancers to free tickets to the show to an iPod Shuffle. YES!!! We love to say thank you in a big way!
  • Should we not reach our entire funding goal, please know that your donations will still go towards all of the budgetary items. If needed, Ms. Andressen will not accept compensation for her dancing or work. It is more important for the funds to go to others for their hard work first.
  • We're also subject to a 9% fee on donations should we not meet our goal. I'm sure you understand why we truly need the full $3,800.
  • Anything in excess will go towards our 2016 season.

Your Voice Matters

You can help us raise awareness through art about the harm labeling causes.

Did you know that according to the Jason Foundation (jasonfoundation.com): 

  • Suicide is the SECOND leading cause of death for ages 10-24. (2010 CDC WISQARS)
  • Suicide is the THIRD leading cause of death for college-age youth and ages 12-18. (2010 CDC WISQARS)

What if people knew that they had other options and didn't have to succumb to harmful labels or results from conformity or bullying? What if they knew they were loved?

  • You can help us raise awareness about peer pressure, conformity and bullying.
  • You may be able to help us reach someone. Even one person saved is valuable.

Our Past Track Record

  • We've also successfully produced our own dance festival: "Awakenings & Beginnings" 3 years running and several repertoire shows and showcases. 
  • To date: each show has sold out and has been great successes. 
  • To re-state: this project is in the hands of Emmy nominated producer wife & husband team. We came in on budget and on time with each production.
  • We've touched many hearts with "Red Ribbons & Memories Dance Concert". A dance concert that raised awareness about sexual child abuse.

Overcoming the Odds

We believe it takes a larger community to help a smaller one. In this case a dance company. No one is an island, and sometimes we all need a little help from friends.

  • Should we fall short of our funding goal, we are committed to see this project through no matter what. If needed, we will have additional creative campaigns to complete the funds needed. Granted, we don't want to resort to a bake sale with $50 cookies, but please understand our dedication will not waiver.
  • Should we need to find another venue, we do have a "cover set" which is an alternate location. It is not ideal, but this project means that much to us.

Other Ways You Can Help - Remember the 4 "S"s

If you want to help but aren't able to donate, here's what you can do:

  • SHOUT: word of mouth is the best - tell a friend
  • SHARE: via Indiegogo share tools - there's an app for that
  • SEND: eMails or texts - to your friends
  • SOCIAL: post this campaign to facebook, twitter, instagram our pix, blog on blogger (we love editorials and will give awesome interviews--just ask us).

Thank you so much for your time and consideration.


Notice: *Contributors can contribute from anywhere in the world to campaigns. Indiegogo does not charge any fees, but depending on the currency of the campaign they contribute to, they will bear the exchange rate and any additional exchange charges as determined by their credit card.

story:
What these sly dogs are up to:

Orrin Whalen and Connor Hayes have been at this for years--- building an annual haunted maze for their friends, family and neighbors to enjoy on one special, spooky night in the fall. With the countless help of friends and loved ones, they have pulled off each year through the charity and good-will of their community. 

This year they want to give something back to the place that started it all--- Malibu High School. The Arts Angels program inspired the two from the very beginning in acting, set design, construction and prop-making. Looking back on their roots, they want to give as much as they can back to keep that program going for the future artists of Malibu. 


What they need & why:

Building a home-haunt of this magnitude is costly. An enormous amount of time and money is put into making the annual haunt a reality, with preparation starting in the middle of summer. Funds will be distributed towards material costs, costumes, props, etc and the rest will go directly to Arts Angels. 

During the year, Orrin juggles his time doing freelance set design and art direction with leading a free fitness movement called November Project, while Connor works as the operator of a woodworking company called Hayescraft that makes artisanal crafts for local businesses and friends, so naturally their monetary dedication to this project can get them in some pretty tight spots.

"What we're asking is to help raise the funds we need to make the haunt as amazing as we dreamed it could be. Our hope is that we raise enough to make up the difference for what we spend, and the rest will go directly to Arts Angels."

The Haunt will be open on October 29th & 30th to the public, and the 31st by invitation into the neighborhood, with an optional donation box towards Arts Angels.


The Impact:

Last year the Haunt was dedicated as a fundraiser for a local firefighter, Mike Downing, who had suffered a stroke earlier that year and needed a boost to keep up with the hospital expenses. In total over $5,000 was raised by the Haunt, all of which went directly to Mike and his family. This was in just two nights.

This year, over a course of three nights, they are hoping to meet a similar goal. The Arts Angels program is what keeps the arts at Malibu High School afloat, and each year the funding becomes more and more difficult to muster.

Both Orrin and Connor were a part of the arts program and can truly say that it has shaped them into the human beings they are today. They could only hope that the students at MHS are presented with the same opportunities, if not better.

"We plan to make this year's haunt bigger and better than last year, with more tricks, more scares, and more fun for your friends and family. We thoroughly enjoy giving back to this community and we hope that you can help us reach our goal."


How you can help:

Talk about us and share our story and fundraiser with your friends!
