Both Orrin and Connor were a part of the arts program and can truly say that it has shaped them into the human beings they are today. They could only hope that the students at MHS are presented with the same opportunities, if not better.

"We plan to make this year's haunt bigger and better than last year, with more tricks, more scares, and more fun for your friends and family. We thoroughly enjoy giving back to this community and we hope that you can help us reach our goal."
    
How you can help:
Talk about us and share our story and fundraiser with your friends!

story:
WE NEED YOU!!! To help us take our original musical to the Hollywood Fringe Festival this summer! We need your love and support, but we could also use some Franklin's, Jackson's, Lincoln's or even Washington's to help make that happen. We have a full list of incentives for your donation listed to the right! Check us out in June at Three Clubs in Hollywood!

Hollywood Fringe Info

Need More of an Explanation?!

WHO: The Sassy Classy Flashy girls of The Cherry Poppins Caburlesque Company. Madame Britannia, Lilly St. Byr, Dalia Demure, Slutty Jew Who, Oopsy Daisy, Magique Monique and all the rest of the gang are busting at the seams with triple threat talent, and are ready to shimmy it for you!

WHAT: "The Knock Shop"  is a modern twist on traditional cabaret and burlesque shows, with dancing, singing, and strong comedic overtones. The Knock Shop is more than a show, it's an experience! Think burlesque with sass AND brains! Guests are immersed into the Cherry Poppins world by our host, who will showcase the many different women and services available, despite struggling to maintain control of his feisty girls. Life at the Knock Shop is a constant party, and will encourage audience members to laugh, drink, dance and enjoy the beauty of scantily clad women.  At least one girl will get naked…ish.

THE FUNDS we need will go to the Fringe Festival itself for registration, the venue, advertising, the live band, lights, sound, mics, costumes, props, set pieces, and YOU! And for a very reasonable donation you will get a ticket!!

WHEN: This June we have 5 solid dates picked out to present our Original Musical in in the Hollywood Fringe Festival!

Friday, June 5th @ 5:20pm
Thursday, June 18th @ 11:50pm
Saturday, June 20th @ 5:20pm
Tuesday, June 23rd @ 8:50 pm
Saturday, June 27th @ 3:50 pm

Come to one, or EVERY show! But first....help us make them happen!

WHERE: We were lucky enough to snag prime space in the prohibition style back room of Three Clubs Cocktail Lounge. This well known hangout that we will be taking by storm is located at 1123 Vine St, Los Angeles, CA 90038.

WHY: Well, because you believe in Women's rights, glitter, comedy, theatre,  burlesque,  cabarets, and Sandy Chao Wang and whatever band she is with at the moment, and drinking, and debauchery, and boas, and feather fans, and magic acts, and tear away clothing, and tap dancing, and TLC, and Uber or Lyft....well not so much Uber or Lyft but you can use them to get to and from the show! You probably should in fact, for we promise you will have WAY too good a time to drive home. Don't believe us? Well.....believe these fine folks:

"They sing! they dance! They're hilarious! They're gorgeous! They MAY grope you! What more do you need to see Cherry Poppins?!"- Prof. Matt Ryan

"Cherry Poppins is like the holy trinity of Cabaret/Burlesque shows because it molds together provocative sensuality, exquisite performance, talent (song, dance, and otherwise), and a dash of tongue in cheek humor. Their group isn't one dimensional since they include a vast array of talents from singing sirens, dancing vixens, and quick witted comediennes who know exactly how to please an audience member in all sorts of entertainment ways (and they definitely allude to more pleasure in their act). Simply put the Poppins girls are a hurricane of talent and nothing is ever expected, pedestrian, or off limits, as their hurricane of personalities and skill entertain you from the moment the show begins to the titillating ending that always makes you want to experience more." - Reviewer/Writer Kyle Bruehl 
"I love going to Cherry Poppins shows because they're always different. You know you're getting very talented singer/dancer/comedienne/burlesque artists, but sometimes they sexily remove clothing, sometimes they climb on audience's shoulders, sometimes they do bad-ass power ballads, sometimes they do full-on musical chorus numbers, they tap, they soft-shoe, etc. And somehow every single girl is a TRIPLE threat, is RIDICULOUSLY good looking, and it's HILARIOUS. Prepare to have a blast and not ever know what's coming next at a Cherry Poppins show...." - Actress/Director/Teacher Kate Bowman

story:
We have made our money to produce the show and I will let you know in the next month where and when!
But feel free to continue to contribute - Monies over our goal amount go to purchasing tickets for young women who wouldn't otherwise be able to afford to attend in every market we go to. 
We also changed the name!



My name is Karen Irwin and I was inspired by Janis Joplin

For the last two years I have performed my one woman show, A Piece Of Her Heart: a tribute to Janis (now 'Janis, Me & Bobby McGee') at The Cabaret At The Columbia Club in Indianapolis to sold out houses.  This year it sold out a month in advance which has prompted us to add another show on Thursday, July 30 at Theatre On The Square in downtown Indy (TOTS.org). Recently, I took the show to Bangor, ME to the Penobscot Theatre Company, once again selling out 4 shows.  Audience and media responses are consistently phenomenal.  And I love doing it.  We are now working towards bookings all over the country.

IBJ Review
Examiner.com
Broadwayworld.com

The next step is taking it to New York to do a show. For better or worse, in the big world, a review from anyone in NYC makes national venues more inclined to book a show.  However, it will cost.  We can't expect a venue to pay us, so we will have to pay to do it on our own.  

Making the show accessible to young women who would otherwise not be able to see it is part of my master plan (the show speaks with particular strength to women). In each market we travel to, I will find an organization to connect me with the local teenage female population who could be inspired by Janis but who don't have funds or the support network to attend live theater.  And, any money raised beyond what it takes to do the New York show will go into a fund to help buy tickets for these women.

What We Need & What You Get

We need  $6,000 to produce the show in New York.  This includes:

  • Hiring musicians
  • Hiring a local producer/marketer to help get the word out
  • Venue Rental
  • Marketing costs
  • Travel Expenses (including airfare)

As you can probably tell, I am estimating on the low end.  I prefer to stay in hostels and I do not require much food.  I will be taking Alex Vanbergeijk, my drummer and musical director, and he is also pretty low maintenance. 

For various contributions you could become the proud owner of:

  • the warm fuzzy feeling that comes from  supporting an artist
  • an autographed picture

  • a specialized "Happy Birthday" video to your email or on FB on your birthday

  • my voice recording your voicemail (people have paid me for that!)

  • tickets to the future show of your choice
  • A private concert in your home this summer or fall with me and a guitar                 player
  • your name or the name of your business in the program in New York or the           venue of your choice.
      
      The Impact

I'm her legacy, man.

Become part of her legacy.  So many young people today have no idea about the contribution she made.  She was a woman in a male-dominated industry who poured her soul out on the stage and paved the way for generations of women to follow.

You can also view this project as "little girl from Indiana finally finds her project and shares it with the world!" Okay, not so little girl.  But you get what I’m saying. This project has legs. And I’m a proud Hoosier who will stop at nothing to let everyone on the planet  know that amazing things come out of Indiana.

I truly believe this show is important.  And I've seen its impact.

It inspires and empowers women.  It helps give us license to discover our own voices and unapologetically use them in the face of a society that continues to tell us that we are not good enough, not smart enough, not pretty enough, too big or too loud. And, once again, any overage from this fundraising will go to buy tickets for young women who could not afford to attend, in cities all over the country.

Risks & Challenges

  • I don't see a lot of long term risk - Janis is an easy sell.  I thank God every day that I don't sound like Anne Murray or Britney Spears.

  • Of course, I am going to be on the road, so any perks that have to happen in your town will have to be strategically scheduled.
  • The biggest challenge is that I’m doing this all myself.  Booking, producing, acting, singing and marketing are all part of my job description.  And now - fundraising.  But I already have a lot of people who are supportive and excited about what I am doing and that number is continuing to grow.  I am also learning a lot about how to do this, which makes me feel powerful.  When the time comes for me to be able to turn parts of this project over to other people, I will feel secure in the knowledge that I understand the inner workings of this business and be less likely to be taken advantage of.


    • Can't Financially Contribute?

I have been a "starving artist" my entire adult life.  I get it.  So - If you share this on your FB page, I will enter your name in a drawing for 2 free tickets to the newly added show on Thursday, July 30th at Theatre On the Square in downtown Indy. Just send me a message that you did it.  And tell all your friends.

And thank you so much for all your continued support.

I don't see a lot of long term risk - Janis is an easy sell.  I thank God every day that I don't sound like Anne Murray or Britney Spears.


Of course, I am going to be on the road, so any perks that have to happen in your town will have to be strategically scheduled.





The biggest challenge is that I’m doing this all myself.  Booking, producing, acting, singing and marketing are all part of my job description.  And now - fundraising.  But I already have a lot of people who are supportive and excited about what I am doing and that number is continuing to grow.  I am also learning a lot about how to do this, which makes me feel powerful.  When the time comes for me to be able to turn parts of this project over to other people, I will feel secure in the knowledge that I understand the inner workings of this business and be less likely to be taken advantage of.

I have been a "starving artist" my entire adult life.  I get it.  So - If you share this on your FB page, I will enter your name in a drawing for 2 free tickets to the newly added show on Thursday, July 30th at Theatre On the Square in downtown Indy. Just send me a message that you did it.  And tell all your friends.And thank you so much for all your continued support.

story:
My sister and I wrote this show after our first year of college, when High School Musical and Bieber ruled the airwaves and the Jersey Shore was not just a geographical location, but a place of worship. We, like many 90's born kids have an inherit love for Nintendo and all the beloved characters that come along with it. 

We thought it would be fun to write a musical around Mario and Luigi's experience in high school, where they were training to participate in the games. 

It's senior year for the two best friends and both are determined to make this the "Best Year Ever." Luigi desperately wants to fit in with the cool kid Miis, while Mario has fallen in love for the first time with a princess from his first period class. 

Emotions run high as Peach, who is dating Link, the douche master himself, must decide whether to follow her heart or her hairbrush as she discovers what true love really is. Meanwhile Bowser cuts Toad a deal, that he won't bully him anymore so long as he teaches Bowser to read Shakespeare and help him fulfill his ambition of becoming a classical actor. All of this leads up to the big event, Battle of the Bands, where the winner gets to play at prom and is therefore, by default, popular. 

You can expect appearances from all your favourite secondary Nintendo characters including Koopa Troopa, Daisy, Zelda, and Wario.

Our plan for this show is to organize a 3-4 day run at a local theatre in Toronto. We also are intending on filming it and putting this up on youtube, so if you're not in Toronto you will still be able to see it! 

The unique thing about this production is that we have 8 young writers, composers and lyricists all working on this show as opposed to just a couple, so it's been and will continue to be a very dynamic, collaborative process!

Your donations will cover the rental of the theatre, set, costumes, props, keyboard rental, printing, videographer, and technician costs. 

The production costs depend solely on donations, we are starting this as a barebones reading and seeing how much more we can add to make it a truly amazing show that will be on youtube forever! 

The music, script and lyrics are already written all we need is funding!

Show dates: July 31 - Aug 2 @ The Box Theatre in Toronto 

Admission: "Pay What You Can."

All updates will be announced on Facebook! 

FB event: https://www.facebook.com/events/246651798792118/

Questions? Email us at jazzsquared@hotmail.com. Thank you so much!

story:
Where: Portland Stage Company, Portland, Maine

When: In repertory with two other local works, performances will take place on January 11, 17, 19, 22, 25 and 30, closing on February 1.

  

“I never had any intention of moving to a retirement community. And I certainly had not intended to do so at the age of 27.”

In support of her terminally ill mother, young journalist Ollie moves to a small town in Maine housing a cancer research facility, and takes the first job she could snatch up in the area.

As an obituary writer.

Temporary Living Arrangements, is a comedic exploration of death and mourning. It is the first full-length dramatic work by Elizabeth Lardie – Lanyard Co-Artistic Director (and former student of the company’s educational arm, The Trigorin Project). The work has been germinating in Lardie’s head for six years, and comes very directly from her own experience with grief while working as, you guessed it, a twenty-something obituaries editor for a local newspaper.

Funding Goal

Lanyard greatly value artists' time, skills and efforts. The company has always operated on a modest budget, but it also has always paid its casts and creative consultants.For this campaign, a fundraising goal of $8,000 has been set. The funds will help ensure we can offer due compensation for our incredible actors (stay tuned for an official casting announcement!) and talented creative team, as well as offset other greater production costs.

About the Play

This is a show about confronting the inevitable. And culturally, we are not particularly adept at being able to discuss death and loss frankly, be it our own fears of how we’ll be remembered or how we celebrate a loved one’s life. One of the best (and cathartic) ways to deal with any painful subject is through humor. In Temporary Living Arrangements, this ranges from bad jokes training editors make to the horrifying absurdity of a fire at a funeral home, and the resulting “complementary cremations.” These anecdotes are mostly drawn from my own real life experience as an obituary editor, as well as my own experience with caring for a parent.

This show is also an analysis of how we navigate different versions of our life story. Prior to curtain, audience members will be invited to write down on a card one thing they would like to be remembered for. These will be anonymous and read aloud at the end. We can’t wait to read both honest and ridiculously flippant answers alike.  

About Lanyard

Lanyard Theatre Company is a professional theatre troupe operating primarily in the state of Maine and focusing purely on developing and showcasing new work, founded by area actor and playwright Kevin O’Leary. Now under the helm of founding member Joseph Barbarino and Maine native Elizabeth Lardie, the company has presented a staged reading of O'Leary's latest work, the full-length play Lascaux, and two lauded entries in Portland’s annual PortFringe fringe theater festival: Whale Watch and Heart on Crackers.

Founded in September 2005, the outfit blossomed out of a playwriting intensive called the Trigorin Project, which placed high school writers and actors with professional mentors from Maine and New York. After it became evident that community was hungry not just for students to have an opportunity to grow creatively but to see the produced work of the Trigorin mentors, Lanyard productions became semi-annual editions to the local arts and culture line-up.

We are working to make the Trigorin half of our operation a steady fixture in the area school system once again. Additionally, we are happy to return the company's annual programming to a minimum of two produced world premieres a season, and have opened up submissions beyond the original writers collective and encourage local playwrights to submit work for consideration, as either a workshop or full production.

About Studio Rep

“Three Bold, new productions from three different artists/companies, performed in repertory in Portland Stage Company’s intimate Studio Theater. Studio Rep: 4 weeks, 3 productions, 1 stage.”

Studio Rep is a new, collaborative project launched by Portland Stage to build bridges between the theater, local theater artists, and our audience. The aims of Studio Rep are to learn about what excites the next generation of theater artists; introduce our audiences to their work and their audiences to ours; and above all, to contribute to the ongoing vibrancy of Portland’s theater ecology.

Your Support

Lanyard is proud to help fill a void in coastal Maine - where glimpses at new work are rare to date and opportunities for stage artists to workshop new ideas can be similarly elusive.

We are very excited return to full productions once more, and are incredibly grateful for the support we will receive to move forward with this production and beyond!

Lanyard can be found on Facebook at www.facebook.com/LanyardTheatreCompany

Questions? Send us a message or drop us a note via e-mail via lanyardtheatreco@gmail.com

Also, check out Portland Stage Company at http://www.portlandstage.org/

Lardie, the company has presented a staged reading of O'Leary's latest 
work, the full-length play Lascaux, and two lauded entries in Portland’s annual PortFringe fringe theater festival: Whale Watch and Heart on Crackers. 
Founded
 in September 2005, the outfit blossomed out of a playwriting intensive 
called the Trigorin Project, which placed high school writers and actors
 with professional mentors from Maine and New York. After it became 
evident that community was hungry not just for students to have an 
opportunity to grow creatively but to see the produced work of the 
Trigorin mentors, Lanyard productions became semi-annual editions to the
 local arts and culture line-up.
We
 are working to make the Trigorin half of our operation a steady fixture
 in the area school system once again. Additionally, we are happy to 
return the company's annual programming to a minimum of two produced 
world premieres a season, and have opened up submissions beyond the 
original writers collective and encourage local playwrights to submit 
work for consideration, as either a workshop or full production.
About Studio Rep
“Three
 Bold, new productions from three different artists/companies, performed
 in repertory in Portland Stage Company’s intimate Studio Theater. 
Studio Rep: 4 weeks, 3 productions, 1 stage.”
Studio
 Rep is a new, collaborative project launched by Portland Stage to build
 bridges between the theater, local theater artists, and our audience. 
The aims of Studio Rep are to learn about what excites the next 
generation of theater artists; introduce our audiences to their work and
 their audiences to ours; and above all, to contribute to the ongoing 
vibrancy of Portland’s theater ecology.
Your Support
Lanyard
 is proud to help fill a void in coastal Maine - where glimpses at new 
work are rare to date and opportunities for stage artists to workshop 
new ideas can be similarly elusive. 
We
 are very excited return to full productions once more, and are 
incredibly grateful for the support we will receive to move forward with
 this production and beyond!
Lanyard can be found on Facebook at www.facebook.com/LanyardTheatreCompany

Questions? Send us a message or drop us a note via e-mail via lanyardtheatreco@gmail.com

Also, check out Portland Stage Company at http://www.portlandstage.org/

story:
Bare Bait Dance makes dance in Montana, for Montanans, with Montanans

Howdy!  We are Bare Bait Dance based in Missoula, Montana, and we are so proud to be a professional contemporary modern dance company in the Rocky Mountain West, performing for under-served dance populations specifically in Western Montana.  Founded in the fall of 2011, we are now in our 3rd season of producing high-quality, original dance works.  Under the artistic direction of Joy French, BBD focuses on choreographing new, accessible, collaborative dance works and strengthening the arts community by creating jobs for professional dancers. 

In a nut-shell: BBD wants to create a Montanan dance home for professional dancers and nurture the growth of dance-appreciation in the rural American West.

We need YOU to be on our BBD-team!  Please help us bring the magic of dance to Montanan audiences!


The Nuts and Bolts

BBD is fortunate in so many ways!  Season 3 highlights include:

  • Ten multifaceted, sophisticated and dedicated company members (Jenna Buska, Kirsten Cherubini, Claire Christensen, Jordan Dehline, Britt Gaudette, Allison Herther, Kaitlin Kinsley, Katie McEwen, Liz Pertis, and Jessica Shontz)

  • Two, multi-weekend original productions: the company began rehearsing in August for this season's productions.  First up: Springboard 2014, opening in late January, is our annual choreographic showcase.  This production hands the creative controls to company members who draw on diverse choreographic visions.  This year, inspirations come from Loons to awkward social dances to the comical aspects of pregnancy!  Then, our second production in late April, Wall City News, is a new work by BBD Artistic Director, Joy French.  This evening-length piece focuses on prison newspapers at the turn of the 20th century and includes both BBD and community performers.

  • Collaborations with local artists (Jes Mullette, Jack Metcalf, Hana MT) and musicians (John Sporman, Travis Yost)

  • A new performance venue!: for our two Missoula premieres, BBD is partnering with Stage 112 to expand our production design, diversify the venue's current concert offerings, and enhance the audience experience

  • Multi-city region tour of Wall City News (choreographed by Joy French)

  • We've been invited to be part of an installation performance in San Francisco at the SGC International Printmaking Conference
  • Continued partnership with Missoula's Downtown Dance Collective as their Company in Residence for the third year running

Why we need YOU!

Although ticket sales, program ads, and touring support the lion's share of our budget, it only gets us so far.  Your support will help to pay the BBD dance professionals for their time and talent and our collaborators for sharing their unique, one-of-a-kind skill-sets.  In addition your donation will go towards costumes, sets, venue rental for both production runs, tour transportation costs this coming summer, and general as well as production-specific marketing materials.  We hope you see the value of our budding artistic venture and appreciate that we can't do it alone.  And as we launch our third season, celebrate with us our many past successes and help us envision a very bright future!

BBD needs you.

You: the believer of creating stronger arts communities in rural America.  You: our audiences who have see our previous shows and want to see more!  You: our friends and family who have watched us dream, sweat, cry, and bask in the beauty of this remarkably challenging yet inspiring art form. You: the dance-lover! 

Thank you for becoming part of the BBD-team.


Want to know more?

Here are ways to learn more about us and keep updated on what BBD is up to:

  • Company website: www.barebaitdance.org
  • Email us at barebaitdance@gmail.com
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Get in touch via mail: PO Box 7372, Missoula, MT 59807
  • Or better yet, come to a show!:  Springboard 2014 (Jan 24, 25, 31, Feb 1 - 7pm all dates + 2pm on Feb 1); Wall City News (April 18, 19, 25, 26 - 7pm all dates + 2pm on April 26) - all performances at Stage 112 in Missoula

And please, if you like what we're doing, share our campaign with a friend.

story:
In 2005, my one-act play MILLER'S COURT, about Jack the Ripper and his last victim, Mary Kelly, premiere in Charlotte, North Carolina.  It was produced by Actors Scene Unseen, who also produced an audio version of the play that is still available as a CD and as an audio download from such vendors as Audible, iTunes, and Amazon.  


Since the play is set in London, I have long dreamed of staging it in that venue.  Now, at last, my dream has come true!  If all goes well, it will be staged at the Theatre  Collection, a pub theatre in Islington in Inner London on 10-11 November.  Please help me make my dream come true and donate what you can today!

story:
yT's Story

youTurn Arts produces an annual exhibition which gives "Individual Artists" (performing and visual) the opportunity to premiere their art in the San Diego community.  The yT Exhibition aims to offer unique, interactive and multi-dimensional experiences. These yT experiences push the boundaries of expectations typically associated with Dance, Music, Theater, Visual Art, Film and Installations. Each year our exhibition strives to create new work which exceeds the perimeters of the previous year. 


This year we are including some amazing new artists.  All the way from New York City we have Tamara Saari Dance as one of our choreographers, who will be doing a special performance art piece on the rooftop.  Check them out at www.tamarasaaridance.com.  Claudia Gomez Vorce, the fabulous percussion tapper, will be working this year with the well-known gypsy jazz trio, Trio Gadjo.  Visit Claudia at www.oliotheshow.com or cherriesjubileesd.com and Trio Gadjo at www.facebook.com/triogadjo.  Our rooftop experience isn't complete without the unparalleled visual art of Keith Puryear and Ursula McDonald http://ursulastar.tumblr.com, Vincent De Guzman http://moodybreakerstudio.com, plus the beautiful jewelry of d.ann designs, which you can visit at www.d-anndesigns.com and Sarah Larson's eclectic creations "Often Wander" Collection.  Don't forget the amazing eats of Nut 'n Bean!  Find them at www.facebook.com/nutnbean to get your orders in and pick them up at yT 2012.


Impact

San Diego is full of talented "Individual Artists" whose work goes unseen due to the lack of funding that would otherwise be available if affiliated with a larger non-profit company.  

We are the artists who have chosen to produce ourselves.  As we strive to keep our yT Exhibitions current, edgy, informative and relevant to the San Diego Community, we hope to be a strong representation of the thriving San Diego arts scene. 

yT is one of the only productions in San Diego that incorporates the artwork from local choreographers, musicians and visual artists into one low-priced exhibition, including a rooftop reception that is worth the ticket price itself.  We would like to keep it this way, because we believe art should be accessible and affordable.  Your contribution helps our cause.  

Collectively the producers of yT have worked for over 10 professional dance companies; performed, choreographed and exhibited works both nationally and internationally.  Erica Buechner, Anne Gehman and Maria Juan have been active voices in the San Diego Community and recognized for the proliferation of merging artists into new and collaborative experiences. We also impact the community directly through the free workshops and classes made available throughout the year. 

What yT Needs...

Last year yT was a raving success, complete with sold out evening shows and a great review from critic Kris Eitland of SanDiego.com, "YOUTURN Contemporary Arts Exhibition... A head-turner that deserves a second look ".  A large part of yT's success was not only due to the support of the community and those who attended, but also the artists, performers and choreographers who graciously donated hundreds of hours of their time to participate in the exhibition. We believe that art is valuable. If we were accountants, we wouldn't give our services away for free, let alone pay to have people use our service. yT brings several wonderful artists together under one roof to create an extraordinary experience for the San Diego community. We believe there is value in that and would like to be able to give a little something back to the artists involved. In order to be able to do that, we need financial support.

The Breakdown

Production costs for yT...

Basic costs include, 10th Ave.Theater ($1500), Lighting designer ($500), Insurance ($250), Permits ($50), Food and Drink ($500). Other expenses are costumes (roughly $100 per dance), rehearsal space ($25 per hour x 75 hours per dance), flyers, programs and marketing supplies, other art supplies etc... and we haven't even thought about paying the artists yet! 

Last year we covered the basic costs of producing the event through ticket sales, but the other expenses listed above were completely out of pocket. The yT artists involved were not compensated. Due to our desire to create an even better experience for the San Diego community, this year youTurn is expanding.  This fundraising campaign is only for the cost of the 10th Ave. Theater ($1500). Our hope is that by covering the cost of the theater, we MAY be able to give the artists involved a small honorarium.

Other ways to Support yT 

One of the biggest ways you can support yT 2012 is by attending it, May 3rd-5th at the 10th Avenue Theatre at 7:30 p.m.  Tickets can be bought a youturnarts.com.  You can also share this campaign with your art-supporting friends.

story:
Vacanti Ballets, created by choreographer Thomas Vacanti in 2012, produces elaborate dance works that are inspired by the creative intersection of ballet and contemporary culture. The company supports choreographers and performers of all stylistic backgrounds to explore the endlessly diverse concepts of dance. In the past year, he has assembled a group of dancers that are at once athletic, supple, and passionate in their dancing. The programming ranges from technically demanding to spare, intense dancing. There is a full on commitment to the dance vocabulary and dramatic intent in each of the works presented.

 


“The main thing is to be moved, to love, to hope, to tremble, to live.” ~Auguste Rodin

 

“Art is not what you see, but what you make others see.” ~ Edgar Degas

 

One year after its premiere performances  at the Boston University Dance Theater in Boston, Vacanti Ballets has been invited to present it’s signature repertory piece “Now Sleeps The Crimson Petal” at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Beckett Massachusetts on July 25, 2013. This is a major opportunity for the company to present work at a nationally/ internationally recognized dance festival.

 

 

 

This unique opportunity comes with increased costs. Our total budget in preparation for the festival is over $7,500. Vacanti Ballets is currently fundraising to aid in covering our rehearsal and production costs in preparation for the festival. Money raised will go towards studio rental fees, dancers’ stipends, travel and housing.

 

 

 

This project would not be possible without our friends and patrons who recognize the driving force of art and it’s impact on the community. Help Vacanti Ballets by making a donation and spreading the word about our company, our upcoming show and our fundraising campaign! Any amount you can contribute is welcome -- we appreciate support in all sizes. And whether you can donate or not, we hope you'll consider coming to see us on the Inside/Out stage on July 25 at 6:30pm!

 

Thank you!

Tom

 

For more information about Thomas Vacanti and Vacanti ballets visit:

thomasvacanti.com

story:
Theater Class's Long-Awaited Finale

Theater Class has been one of the internet's most offensive, adrenaline-packed, and cleverly hilarious web series with a lot of heart and yet no heart at all. It's a satirical gem for anybody who's had to endure academic theatre of any kind, and a tribute to the diverse range of characters we're required to put up with on and offstage. The show has plagued the nation for over 3 years with sold-out screenings, live performances, and an odd niche in the Youtube community where we can see Glee had it done heroine. The show was left open-ended on episode 210, and has been on hiatus for over a year. To this day, there is one email that I get more often than any other: "When is Theater Class getting closure?!" This is where we need your help!

What We Need 

  • Donations to help fund travel expenses, as the cast no longer lives in the same region. Let's face it, it wouldn't be Theater Class unless the whole gang shows up, right?
  • Funding for locations, props, set pieces, and talent! 
  • Any and all funds WILL be used, whether or NOT we make our goal. The smallest donation counts!

What You Get

Sitting on my desk is a script that has been waiting to be shot for over a year. It's an epic finale of epic proportions that we just haven't had the funds to produce. People ask, why not simplify the script for a cheaper production? The answer is simple: this show has been something that the cast and myself have poured our hearts into for years. We've had some of the best times of our lives shooting and writing this series for an audience who's given us the gratification and views to keep working. Cutting corners and watering down the script to fit an empty budget is just something I'm not willing to do. If we're going out, we're going out right! 

This finale script is something very dear and personal to me - it's an extended episode bringing back every character who's appeared on the show, and sends them off in a heart-felt, hilarious, and clever way, just like the rest of the series has always been - and I hope one day soon, you'll be able to enjoy it for yourself.

story:
Play on Words Productions is a theater producing company that supports the development of new works while creating a community of talented and spirited artists.

We support the developmental process of the new playwright by producing a writers group, public readings, industry showcases, and script workshops. Our mission is to aid emerging voices by giving them a safe place to create and an outlet to introduce their work to a wider community.

In opening up this developmental process and importance of that process to the general public, we hope to create a new breed of theater-goers. Theater-goers with an understanding and connection to the work, making each production a more satisfying experience.

People Behind the Magic:

Megan Kosmoski (Co-Founder, Producing Artistic Director) Theaters and festivals she has worked with include: Williamstown Theater Festival, Red Fern Theatre Company, UglyRhino Productions, The Glass Eye Theatre Company, HOT Festival, Ensemble Studio Theater/YoungBlood, The Bad Theater Festival, Smoke and Mirrors Collaborative, Dixon Place, Washington Shakespeare Company, Capitol Fringe Festival, OperaAlterna, and Active Cultures Theatre. Director Lab West Alumnus and guest writer for the LA Stage Times. She received her BA from Catholic University of America and studied at the Shakespeare Institute in Stratford-Upon-Avon. www.MeganKosmoski.com

Kate Pressman (Co-Founder, Literary Manager) A Brooklyn based playwright. Co-founder of [subject to change] playwright group. Her full length play Piano For Four Hands was read as Red Fern Theatre Company’s Dark Night series and workshopped in December 2012 at the Kraine Theater. In the past year various plays and shorter works have been read at Big Words ETC, The Access Theatre and Play on Words. Kate has worked as a stage-manager, dramaturg, script reader and designer all over the city and she is recently assistant directed the World Premiere of Isaac’s Eye by Lucas Hnath at Ensemble Studio Theatre.

Gina Femia (Director of the Playwright Group) work has been presented as a part of the Williamstown Theatre Festival, The New Ideas Festival in Toronto, New York Madness at HERE Arts Center and the Estrogenius Festival.  She was recently a featured playwright for Independent Actor’s Theatre’s Short Plays by Women Festival.  Her work has been developed at the Samuel French Institute, Dixon Place, Play on Words Productions, Sarah Lawrence College and Looking Glass Theatre.  MFA Sarah Lawrence College, Lipkin Award in playwriting.

Amanda Lea Mason (Casting Director) graduated from the Boston University School of Theatre in 2011 and has been living in Brooklyn ever since. In 2010, she completed the Classical Acting Semester at the London Academy of Dramatic Art  (LAMDA). Some favorite roles include Cari in Where It Feels, Bad dates/Jill/Nurse Ortega in Jewtopia, and Hertha in Spring Storm.

Thomas Wood (Director of Artistic Audience Engagement) Recent New York Credits include Demetrius in Midsummer Night’s Dream, an interactive night of Shakespeare and Improv with Annie’s Shakespeare Shakedown, and George in War of the Roses with Take Wing and Soar. He also recently wrapped his first feature film, Shankman’s, which will be out later this year. You can often find him making way too much noise on his twitter account (@thomaswood) or his website (www.thoamsdwood.com).

Cassie Foote (Producer)

What your money goes toward:

Our Reading Series
Readings of short plays October, November, March, and April.

Our Workshops
A 10-day Push to Production-Ready workshop
A Complete Waste of Time by Leon Pease, December 7-17th
Pranks by Suzanne Dottino, May 2014

We are also hoping to host networking events and seminars for emerging artists.

More Specifically, Why We Need the Money:

$8: domain name (so artists can find us)
$10: one script printed ($60, scripts for the cast and director for only one show)
$15: one hour in the rehearsal room ($45 for a night, $405 for a 9 day workshop)
$20: promote an event on social media (to get audiences to see our artists' work)
$30: business cards (to connect with other artists and the community)
$50: rent space for a play reading
$90: one month session for our playwright group (to develop and inspire work)
$100: season postcards
$150: rent for a one night presentation of our season workshop
$200: insurance for our artists (and equity participation)

That is not even counting artist fees, playwright commissions, administration payroll (we don't really have payroll yet... but a company can dream) and miscellaneous fees.

Thank you!!
story_txt:
Play on Words Productions is a theater producing company that supports the development of new works while creating a community of talented and spirited artists. We support the developmental process of the new playwright by producing a writers group, public readings, industry showcases, and script workshops.

Our mission is to aid emerging voices by giving them a safe place to create and an outlet to introduce their work to a wider community. In opening up this developmental process and importance of that process to the general public, we hope to create a new breed of theater-goers. Theater-goers with an understanding and connection to the work, making each production a more satisfying experience.
People Behind the Magic:

Megan Kosmoski (Co-Founder, Producing Artistic Director) Theaters and festivals she has worked with include: Williamstown Theater
 Festival, 
Red Fern Theatre Company, UglyRhino Productions, The Glass Eye Theatre 
Company, HOT Festival, Ensemble Studio Theater/YoungBlood, The Bad 
Theater Festival, Smoke and
 Mirrors Collaborative, Dixon Place, Washington Shakespeare Company, 
Capitol Fringe Festival, OperaAlterna, and Active 
Cultures Theatre. Director Lab West Alumnus and guest writer for the LA 
Stage Times. She received her BA from Catholic University of America and
 studied at the Shakespeare Institute in Stratford-Upon-Avon. www.MeganKosmoski.comKate Pressman (Co-Founder, Literary Manager) A Brooklyn based playwright. Co-founder of [subject to change] playwright group. Her full length play Piano For Four Hands was read as Red Fern Theatre Company’s Dark Night series and workshopped in December 2012 at the Kraine Theater. In the past year various plays and shorter works have been read at Big Words ETC, The Access Theatre and Play on Words. Kate has worked as a stage-manager, dramaturg, script reader and designer all over the city and she is recently assistant directed the World Premiere of Isaac’s Eye by Lucas Hnath at Ensemble Studio Theatre.Gina Femia (Director of the Playwright Group) work has been presented as a part of the Williamstown
Theatre Festival, The New Ideas Festival in Toronto, New York Madness at HERE
Arts Center and the Estrogenius Festival. 
She was recently a featured playwright for Independent Actor’s Theatre’s
Short Plays by Women Festival.  Her work
has been developed at the Samuel French Institute, Dixon Place, Play on Words
Productions, Sarah Lawrence College and Looking Glass Theatre.  MFA Sarah Lawrence College, Lipkin Award in
playwriting.Amanda Lea Mason (Casting Director) graduated from the Boston University School of
 Theatre in 2011 and has been living in Brooklyn ever since. In 2010, 
she completed the Classical Acting Semester at the London Academy of 
Dramatic Art  (LAMDA). Some favorite roles include Cari in Where It Feels, Bad dates/Jill/Nurse Ortega in Jewtopia, and Hertha in Spring Storm.Thomas Wood (Director of Artistic Audience Engagement) Recent New York Credits include Demetrius in Midsummer Night’s Dream, an interactive night of Shakespeare and Improv with Annie’s Shakespeare Shakedown, and George in War of the Roses with Take Wing and Soar. He also recently wrapped his first feature film, Shankman’s,
 which will be out later this year. You can often find him making way 
too much noise on his twitter account (@thomaswood) or his website (www.thoamsdwood.com).Cassie Foote (Producer)
What your money goes toward:

Our Reading SeriesReadings of short plays October, November, March, and April. Our WorkshopsA 10-day Push to Production-Ready workshopA Complete Waste of Time by Leon Pease, December 7-17thPranks by Suzanne Dottino, May 2014We are also hoping to host networking events and seminars for emerging artists.
More Specifically, Why We Need the Money:

$8: domain name (so artists can find us)$10: one script printed ($60, scripts for the cast and director for only one show)$15: one hour in the rehearsal room ($45 for a night, $405 for a 9 day workshop)$20: promote an event on social media (to get audiences to see our artists' work)$30: business cards (to connect with other artists and the community)$50: rent space for a play reading$90: one month session for our playwright group (to develop and inspire work)$100: season postcards$150: rent for a one night presentation of our season workshop $200: insurance for our artists (and equity participation)That is not even counting artist fees, playwright commissions, administration payroll (we don't really have payroll yet... but a company can dream) and miscellaneous fees.Thank you!!

story:
WHAT WE NEED

Production Budget: $11,000

Theatre Hire Costs:
•   Venue Hire  $2,800 
•   FOH manager 17 performances @ $30/hour: $1,700*
•   Opening Night Function $250*
•   Production photographer $100* 
•   Public Liability Insurance $595 

Production Costs:
•   Production Rights/Royalties $2040
•   Rehearsal Venues $200
•   Set and Costume $2000
•   Additional Marketing: SMH theatre listing, printing of postcards and posters: $800


DONATE $20 OR MORE AND GO INTO OUR AWESOME PRIZE DRAW


We have loads of awesome perks like Crumpler bags, In2ski passes and Dendy tickets and DVDs, but anyone who donates $20 or more automatically goes into our prize draw. 

Valued at $450 it includes:

2 x Dendy Lounge passes

1 x Bottle of Moet and Lindt chocolates donated by Sophie Jermyn Management

2 x Bottles of wine from Wine Selectors

1 x 30min session with a personal trainer at St Peters Fit N Fast Gym

A selection of Tom Organic Tampons and Pads

1 x Alchemy Produx Candle 

2 x Cushions and 1 x lampshade from Ulterior motif valued at $200

We'll draw it as soon as the campaign ends and be in touch.


A LITTLE ABOUT OUR SHOW

"It's the odd moments and the little things"

Seven women gather for a dinner party. Victoria is a painter facing creative stagnation; Jenny is Victoria's elder sister and patron, a barrister trying to make it as a woman in a man's world; Rowena, Jenny's lover, is completing her PhD in Women's Studies; Rowena's adopted Samoan sister Bridget is a health professional working with dying patients; Anne is at home all day with a young daughter; Emma is television's most popular newsreader; and Dominique has re-entered their lives after a bitter period of estrangement. As the play moves backward and forwards in time, sisters and friends confront their long-standing rivalries, jealousies and resentments. And all the while, one of the seven moves unknowingly towards her own death.

2014 will see Mad March Hare Theatre Co stage the award-winning play, A Moment on the Lips by revered Australian playwright, Jonathan Gavin. This play addresses the difficult search for meaning and fulfillment in life, our ability to rise to the challenges it throws at us, and the powers we all have for transformation.

Winner of the Philip Parsons Young Playwright Award 2003.
 
"...an excellent sense of character construction... a satisfying richness - poignant, hilarious and deeply human... genuinely exciting work..." STEPHEN DUNNE, SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Directed by Mackenzie Steele

Cast includes: Beth Aubrey, Sarah Aubrey, Claudia Barrie, Sonya Kerr, Ainslie McGlynn, Sabryna Te'o and Lucy Goleby.




THANK YOU TO THESE AMAZING COMPANIES




ABOUT MAD MARCH HARE THEATRE COMPANY

  Mad March Hare Theatre Company is an artist driven company. Its goal is to produce a variety of Australian and International works that challenge, inspire and entertain audiences. Founded in 2011 by Claudia Barrie, MMH provides a platform for artists to work on exciting productions and collaborate with other emerging and professional creatives. Claudia is a graduate of the University of Western Sydney's Theatre Nepean. MORE


Past Productions of Mad Mad Hare Theatre Co

MMH has staged two very successful theatre productions since its inception in 2011:

Baby with the Bathwater by Christoper Durang
New Theatre/Sydney Fringe Festival 2011
Directed by Andrew Johnston
Cast: Amy Kersey, Michael Howlett, Julia Kennedy-Scott,
Claudia Barrie and Brendan Maclean.
 
Mad March Hare made its debut on the New Theatre stage in 2011 with Christopher Durang’s hilarious black comedy, Baby with the Bathwater. Part of the Sydney Fringe Festival and directed by Andrew Johnston (Bell Shakespeare), the production was received well by critics, loved by audiences and hugely successful.
 
Still by Jane Bodie
Old 505 Theatre 2012
Directed by: Fiona Hallenan-Barker, Scarlett McGlynn,
Lara Kerestes, Jess Tuckwell, Cathy Hunt
Cast: Kellie Jones, Matt Hyde, Mat Millay, Amelia Ryan,
Beccy Iland, Luke McKenzie and Ben Wood.
 
In 2012, MMH moved to a much more intimate space,
the Old 505 Theatre in Surry Hills.  For our second
production, we collaborated with 5 different directors
to stage the writings of Australian playwright, Jane Bodie.
A collection  of monologues all exploring the theme of
‘wanting’, Still enjoyed a short sell out season in March.


Why we need your help

MMH was founded to provide a platform for existing and emerging artists to continue to forge a successful career in the theatre industry. AND so we can tell stories we are passionate about! But putting on a show is expensive.  There are numerous costs involved:Royalties, Set and Costume, Rehearsal Venues, Insurance, Marketing- the list goes on! Independent theatre exists because of your support. Without you, we wouldn't exist. Fundraising and resource sourcing is a ongoing part of running an independent theatre company and every little bit helps!


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can’t contribute financially, you can help us out by sharing this campaign with your friends, family, social media contacts, postman! you name it! Indiegogo has great SHARE tools to make sharing this campaign easy.

Thanks in advance!

story:
Hello! My name is Jess and I am the director for the beautiful show Anna Bella Eema by Lisa D'Amour with music by Chris Sidorfsky. The cast and crew working on this production are all current students here at Pace University. We cannot explain how excited we are to put up this unique and challenging show--but we need your help! To make this production as visually stimulating as possible, we need a bit of financial help. If you're interested, you've come to the right place! Please pass this a long to any other family or friends who might be willing to donate.

The show will be November 6th-10th in Schaeberle Studio at 141 Park Row on the 10th floor. A link to brown paper tickets will be designed by next week for reserving tickets. We'll keep you updated. 

Wed Nov 6th- Thurs Nov 7th- 8pm Invited Dress (Name must be added to the list)

Fri Nov 8th and Sat Nov 9th-- 8pm performance

Sunday Nov 10th--- 2pm performance 

Hope to see you there! Thanks for taking the time to check out our campaign. 

Here are suggested perk donations, but you can donate as little as $1.00 and as much as 4 billion!!
